Elowen “Wren” Ashford grew up above her family’s crumbling seaside funeral home, where lullabies mingled with the hush of the dead. Now a restoration artist for a quirky historic cemetery, she coaxes mossy angels and stained stone back to life with patient, reverent hands. Soft-spoken yet stubbornly curious, she hides a wry, whimsical humor behind careful politeness and a heart that feels too much. Wren’s private goal is to uncover the truth behind her mother’s long-ago disappearance—without letting herself fall for the brooding newcomer whose presence makes the graveyard feel strangely, tenderly alive.

messages.content:
Morning, Saltmarrow Cemetery’s upper tier—Lantern Row—where the path narrows between leaning slate and a low iron fence furred with salt. Sea-mist beads on carved names until they look freshly inked. The lanterns are still lit from last night, and each flame sputters an unhealthy blue that makes the gravel look cold.

You kneel beside the Harrowell marker, apron tied, hair pinned back the way you learned above Ashford & Daughters. A soft brush clears lichen from a serifed “E,” and your small tools click in your pocket when you shift your weight. You test the stone with a fingertip, careful as if it were skin, then set a stencil to match the original cut. Patience is part of the job; so is noticing what other people hope you won’t.

The date is wrong.

Yesterday the stone read *1889*. Today it reads *1883*, the new “3” cut too clean to be weather. At the base, fresh grit still sits in the chisel line. You lean closer and find a second problem: the border stones around the Harrowell plot have been nudged inward, just enough that the corner now bites into the neighboring family’s ground. That kind of shift takes time, leverage, and permission—unless someone is doing it before dawn.

Footsteps crunch behind you. When you turn, a man stands just inside the gate, coat damp at the shoulders, dark hair still threaded with mist. He doesn’t carry a tour pamphlet or a wreath. He holds a folded sheet of vellum in one hand and keeps the other near his pocket like he’s used to trouble. “Elowen Ashford,” he says, not asking. He opens the vellum just enough for you to see a maintenance overlay of the cemetery—ghost paths, sealed sections—and three plot coordinates inked in your mother’s looping shorthand.

“I bought this from someone who shouldn’t have it,” he says. “Your name was the only instruction.”

The blue lantern above you gutters hard, as if reacting.

You have a freshly altered grave at your knees, an impossible map in a stranger’s hand, and a town heading toward the Brine-Choir’s vigil tonight. He waits for an answer, and the cemetery stays very still.

I rise slowly, wiping my fingers on my apron, and step just close enough to see the ink clearly. “That *is* my mother’s hand,” I say, voice careful. “Who sold it to you—and why were they carrying cemetery overlays in the first place?”
messages.player_reasoning: This is my mother’s handwriting—panic and hope in equal measure—so I need to see the vellum up close, but I don’t trust him yet; I’ll keep things polite and controlled while clocking the altered headstone as another immediate threat.

messages.content:
You step in, close enough that the vellum’s surface catches the lanternlight. The ink is old-black, not the newer soot-brown the Society uses—your mother’s habit of tightening the downstrokes is there, unmistakable. The stranger doesn’t pull it away, but his grip firms at the corners.

He answers your questions in the wrong order.

“Because the cemetery is being run like a ledger,” he says, low. “And ledgers have overlays.”

Then: “A lantern-lighter sold it to me. Not one of the public-facing guides—one of the ones who carries keys.” His eyes flick past your shoulder, toward the path behind you, as if expecting someone to be listening. “He didn’t give a name. He had a thumb missing to the first knuckle and smelled like lamp-oil and brine. He said the map was ‘hot’ and that if I wanted the rest of it, I should find you before the Choir started singing tonight.”

As he speaks, a faint click comes from the iron fence to your left—metal on metal, like a latch being tested. You look: nothing obvious moves, but the chain on the side gate is hanging differently than you remember, the padlock turned outward instead of inward.

The blue lantern above you sputters again. In that brief stutter, you catch it: a second set of footprints in the damp gravel off the main path—too narrow for the caretaker’s boots you know, toes pointed toward you and the stranger, then scuffed as if someone backed away into the grass.

The man folds the vellum once, not hiding it fully but making it easier to snatch. “If you want to ask me what I’m doing in Saltmarrow,” he adds, “do it somewhere that isn’t lit like a signal.”

Another sound—soft, deliberate—comes from the row of headstones behind the Harrowell plot: the scrape of grit under a shoe sole. Whoever it is, they’re close enough now that they’re choosing to be heard.

I catch his sleeve and tug him toward the Harrowell mausoleum’s shadow, keeping my voice even. “Fold it—now. And stay close.” Then, louder, I call into the stones behind us: “Cemetery’s closed. If you’ve got business, say it plainly—before I start shouting for the caretaker.”
messages.player_reasoning: Someone’s shadowing us, and I won’t let a stranger—or my mother’s map—get snatched. I need to move us out of the lanternlight and force the watcher to show themselves.

messages.content:
Your fingers close on his sleeve—wool damp and cold—and you pull him into the Harrowell mausoleum’s lee. The stone there holds the night’s chill; the blue lanternlight doesn’t reach cleanly, and the mist seems to hesitate at the carved angels over the door.

He obeys immediately. The vellum folds in practiced, quick creases and disappears into the inner pocket of his coat. He shifts so his body blocks the mausoleum door seam, eyes fixed on the row of headstones you called out to.

Your voice carries. “Cemetery’s closed…”

For a beat, nothing answers—only the buoy-bell’s distant moan and the lantern’s wet sputter.

Then someone steps into view between two slates: a Lanternward man in a dark oilskin, lantern-hook belt at his waist. His left hand is wrapped in stained cloth, thumb stump blunt beneath it. He holds a long-handled lantern snuffer like a walking stick, and his face is drawn tight with sleeplessness.

He stops where the path widens, keeping a respectful distance that still feels like a boundary. “No need to shout, Miss Ashford,” he says, voice mild and rehearsed. “Caretaker sent me to check the blue lamps. Folks have been… fretting.”

Behind him, a second figure doesn’t step out—only a suggestion of movement in the grass line to his right, where the mist thickens. You hear a quiet exhale and the faint clink of something metal being adjusted, like a buckle or a keyring.

The Lanternward man’s gaze flicks to the Harrowell stone at your knees—wrong date, nudged borders—and then to the stranger’s coat pocket, too quickly to be accidental. “You’ve got company,” he notes, as if it’s casual. “Not a tour day.”

The stranger beside you goes still. His hand stays visible, empty, but his posture changes—ready.

The Lanternward man lifts his snuffer a few inches, not threatening exactly, but making it clear he can close lanterns—make dark—fast. “If you’ve found something you shouldn’t,” he says, softer now, “best you hand it over. The Society doesn’t like… misunderstandings. Especially before a vigil.”

He doesn’t advance. He waits, and the hidden presence in the grass waits with him.

I let my shoulders soften into a tired little sigh, like he’s interrupted nothing more dangerous than moss removal. “The caretaker didn’t mention you—what’s your name?” I ask, then take a small step sideways so my back is to the mausoleum and my eyes can keep the grass line in view. “And if the Society wants something from me, they can ask me in daylight, in the office, with proper records—so unless you’re here to explain why the Harrowell date changed overnight, you can put that snuffer down.”
messages.player_reasoning: Lanternward with keys means he’s the seller—and he’s not alone. I’m not giving up my mother’s map, but I can buy time by playing polite and harmless while edging us toward a safer, more public path.

messages.content:
Your tired sigh lands the way you intend: ordinary, put-upon. You shift sideways until your shoulder touches the mausoleum’s cold stone, giving you a clean angle on the grass line.

The Lanternward man’s expression tightens at the question. For a moment he looks like he might ignore it—then he answers, as if forced by habit into politeness.

“Pell,” he says. “Jory Pell.”

He does not lower the snuffer. Instead, he plants its ferrule on the gravel and leans on it, casual as a cane. “Daylight, office, proper records,” he repeats, tasting the words. “That’s the trouble with you Ashfords. You think paper keeps you safe.”

At the mention of the Harrowell date, his eyes cut to the stone again. He doesn’t deny it changed. That silence is its own admission.

From the grass line to Pell’s right, the hidden figure finally commits: a woman steps half out of the mist, not Lanternward-uniformed—plain dark dress, hair pinned tight, a ring of keys on a chain at her waist. She doesn’t look at you first; she looks at the stranger, then at Pell, and gives the smallest nod, like confirming a description.

Pell speaks again, voice still mild, but the edges are sharper. “You can keep your voice down and we can all walk away tidy. Or you can shout for a caretaker who isn’t on this tier, and my friend here—Mara—will make sure your shouting doesn’t carry.”

Mara’s hand comes up. Not a weapon—an oiled cloth and a small glass bottle. The smell hits even from a few paces: sharp, sweet, medicinal. Ether or something like it.

The threat is clear now: they’re not here to argue policy. They’re here to take the map and, if necessary, quiet you.

Pell shifts his weight forward one step, closing distance. “Last chance,” he says, eyes on the stranger’s coat pocket. “Hand it over.”

The blue lantern above you gutters hard, and for a second the path is darker—enough for Mara to angle her body as if preparing to rush from the grass.

I lift my hands slowly, palms out. “All right—easy,” I say, then glance up at the sputtering blue lantern. “If you’re Lanternward, prove it: snuff that one. It’s spooking the whole tier.”  
As Pell’s attention flicks upward, I hook my foot behind the Harrowell border stone and kick gravel hard into the path between us, then grab the stranger’s sleeve again and hiss, “Run—down Lantern Row, don’t look back,” and I shout at the top of my lungs, “CARETAKER—UPPER TIER! HELP!”
messages.player_reasoning: They’re here to drug me and take the vellum; I need distance, noise, and to keep the map out of their hands. I’ll create a distraction with the lantern/snuffer and use my voice to draw attention while we move.

messages.content:
Pell’s eyes do flick up at the blue lantern—just a reflex, the way anyone who lives by flame can’t help but check a gutter.

He does not snuff it.

But that half-beat is enough.

Your foot hooks the Harrowell border stone and you kick. Gravel sprays across the path in a harsh hiss, pelting Pell’s oilskin and skittering under his boots. His next step slips; he catches himself with the snuffer’s ferrule, metal scraping stone.

You seize the stranger’s sleeve and shove him into motion. He doesn’t argue—he bolts, coat tails snapping, heading down Lantern Row exactly as you ordered.

Mara moves immediately. She lunges after him, keys clinking, bottle and cloth up like she’s done this before. Pell barks, “Not the girl—get the map!” and surges forward toward you instead, trying to cut you off from following.

You shout—full-throated, tearing sound that bounces off slate and marble: “CARETAKER—UPPER TIER! HELP!”

The tier answers with movement, not a voice. From farther downslope, a lantern flares brighter—someone has heard, or at least seen the commotion. But it’s not close.

Pell closes the distance fast. He swings the snuffer not at your head, but low, aiming to hook your ankle or knock your legs out from under you. You jerk back against the mausoleum stone; the snuffer’s rim clips your shin with a hard, numbing smack.

Pain blossoms hot and immediate. Your leg holds, but it stings and your balance wobbles.

Mara is already several strides after the stranger—then she hesitates as your shout carries. She glances back once, calculating, and hisses something to Pell you don’t catch.

Pell’s face changes—less polite, more urgent. “You’ve made it messy,” he snaps, and reaches with his free hand for your wrist, trying to pin you to the mausoleum wall and keep you from giving chase or screaming again.

Down Lantern Row, the stranger is a dark shape running through blue-guttering pools of light—Mara gaining on him in the mist, cloth raised.

**Threat, clear:** Pell is trying to restrain you physically; Mara is attempting to catch the stranger and use the drugged cloth on him to take the map.

I drive my elbow back into Pell’s ribs and twist my wrist hard, then snatch the stiff edge of my apron up over my nose and mouth as I scream again, “HELP—LANTERN ROW!”  
Stumbling on my sore shin, I grab my water tin and fling it down the path toward Mara, shouting, “HEY—MARA! PUT IT DOWN!”
messages.player_reasoning: Wren won’t let herself be dragged off quietly—she’ll fight dirty with whatever’s at hand and keep drawing attention, while trying to stop Mara from catching the stranger.

messages.content:
Your elbow drives back into Pell’s ribs with a dull, satisfying thud. He grunts—air knocked out—and his grip loosens just enough for you to wrench your wrist free. You twist hard; his fingers scrape your skin and then slip off.

You yank your apron up over your nose and mouth and scream again, louder, ragged with pain in your shin: “HELP—LANTERN ROW!”

This time you get an answer: a man’s voice, distant but real, calling, “Oi! Up there!” Footsteps start pounding uphill, still far—at least half a tier down.

Pell recovers fast. His face goes mean with embarrassment. “Shut—up,” he spits, and swings the snuffer again, higher now, aiming to clip your shoulder and drive you back into the mausoleum’s shadow. The rim catches your upper arm—hard enough to make your fingers go numb for a second, not enough to drop you.

You fumble for your water tin—small, dented, half-full—and fling it down the path toward Mara.

It sails low and fast, then bounces off a headstone base with a loud *clang* and skitters into the gravel, spraying water in a brief arc. The noise makes Mara flinch and glance back.

Your shout—“HEY—MARA! PUT IT DOWN!”—lands. Mara’s jaw tightens; she doesn’t put anything down. She changes tactics.

She stops chasing straight at the stranger and instead cuts across the grass to intercept him where Lantern Row narrows between two leaning stones. Keys flash at her waist as she moves. The cloth stays raised, bottle in her other hand.

The stranger is still running, but he’s about to hit that pinch-point in the path—Mara is positioning to step into him from the side and clamp the cloth over his face.

Behind you, Pell steps in again, closer than before. He reaches not for your wrist this time, but for the apron at your face—trying to yank it down and force you to breathe whatever Mara has. His breath smells of lamp-oil and salt.

**Immediate threats:**
- Pell is within arm’s reach and trying to control your breathing/face covering.
- Mara is about to intercept the stranger at a narrow section of Lantern Row and use the drugged cloth.

I clamp the apron tight with one hand and bite Pell’s reaching fingers as hard as I can, then knee him—clumsy but vicious—right where it’ll count. “DON’T TOUCH ME,” I snarl through the cloth, and I scream again, “LANTERN ROW—SHE’S GOT ETHER!”  
Then I lunge toward the path and shout after the stranger, “LEFT—OFF THE ROW, THROUGH THE YEW BREAK!”
messages.player_reasoning: Pell going for my face is a line I can’t let him cross; I need to keep the apron up and make noise while buying the stranger seconds to avoid Mara’s intercept.

messages.content:
You clamp the apron to your face and when Pell’s hand claws for it, you catch two of his fingers between your teeth. You bite down hard.

He yelps—high and involuntary—and jerks back, shaking his hand as blood beads along the knuckles. Before he can reset, your knee comes up.

It’s not graceful, but it lands. Pell folds with a choked noise, the snuffer clattering against the mausoleum stone. He staggers sideways, one hand cupped between his legs, the other held up and bleeding, eyes watering with rage.

“DON’T TOUCH ME,” you snarl through the cloth.

You scream again, voice tearing: “LANTERN ROW—SHE’S GOT ETHER!”

That word changes the air. Down the slope, the running footsteps you heard speed up—two sets now—and someone shouts back, “ETHER? WHO—?”

Mara hears it too. She’s at the pinch-point just as the stranger reaches it. She darts in from the side, cloth snapping up toward his face.

But your shout and your next call hit in the same instant: “LEFT—OFF THE ROW, THROUGH THE YEW BREAK!”

The stranger commits on instinct. He veers left, shoulder-checking into the yew’s dark gap instead of pushing through the narrow stones. Mara’s cloth brushes his cheek—not a full seal—and he stumbles into the branches, coughing, but he’s still moving.

Mara swears, sharp and low, and plunges after him. The yew boughs whip and scrape; her keys jangle wildly, giving away her line.

Behind you, Pell isn’t finished. He straightens with a hiss, face blotched with pain and humiliation. He snatches up the snuffer again and—rather than swing—he lunges to tackle, trying to drive you to the ground and stop you from shouting any more.

You have a heartbeat of warning: his boots scrape on gravel, shoulders dropping as he comes in.

Down Lantern Row, lanternlight flares—two figures cresting the rise, still a short run away. They’re close enough now that Pell glances toward them, calculating whether to finish this fast or flee.

**Threats now:** Pell is mid-lunge to take you down; Mara is in pursuit through the yew break, and the stranger is not yet safe—he’s being chased in close quarters where a cloth can be clamped over his face.

I sidestep at the last second and grab for Pell’s coat collar and snuffer arm, trying to use his momentum to sling him into the mausoleum wall, then I shout at the approaching lanterns, “JORY PELL—LANTERNWARD—HE’S GOT A SNUFFER AND SHE’S GOT ETHER!”
messages.player_reasoning: Pell’s trying to take me down right as help is almost here; if I can spoil his tackle and make noise, he’ll either flee or get caught. The stranger’s in the yew with Mara—too far for me to reach safely, but I can at least keep Mara from doubling back by drawing attention and keeping Pell pinned in place.

messages.content:
You sidestep as Pell lunges. Your hand snags his coat collar; your other clamps his snuffer arm at the elbow. For a moment you have him—his momentum rolling past you—and you wrench, trying to sling him into the mausoleum wall.

It half-works.

Pell’s shoulder smashes into the stone with a meaty *thunk*, and his snuffer arm bangs hard enough that the metal rings. But he’s heavier than you and already braced for a struggle; instead of being thrown cleanly, he twists with the impact, rips his collar partly free, and drags you with him. Your sore shin skates on loose gravel; pain spikes and you nearly go down.

Pell uses the tangle to his advantage—he shoves his forearm across your upper chest and tries to pin you against the mausoleum, snuffer still in his fist, held awkwardly between you. Close enough that you can smell his lamp-oil breath again.

You shout over him, voice raw: “JORY PELL—LANTERNWARD—HE’S GOT A SNUFFER AND SHE’S GOT ETHER!”

The two figures crest the rise fully into view—Lanternward, by their coats and the hooked lantern poles. One is broad-shouldered with a lantern pole in both hands; the other carries a hand-lantern and a ring of keys that clinks as he runs.

“Pell?!” the broad one barks, skidding to a stop and raising the pole like a staff. The key-bearer’s lantern swings, throwing blue light over Pell’s bloody knuckles and your apron over your face.

Pell’s eyes flick to them—panic, then a hard decision. He snaps, “She’s lying—she’s—” and tries to wrench the snuffer up between you, as if to threaten you into silence.

The broad Lanternward steps in fast and drives the lantern pole across Pell’s forearms, pinning the snuffer arm down with a sharp crack of wood on bone. Pell swears and recoils, grip faltering.

“Drop it,” the broad one orders, voice suddenly official. The key-bearer moves to your side, reaching for your shoulder—not to grab, but to pull you back from Pell and put himself between you.

Down the yew break, you hear branches thrash and Mara’s keys jangling—she’s still chasing the stranger, and now she knows help has arrived.

**Immediate threat:** Mara is still loose with ether in the yews; Pell is being restrained but not yet disarmed, and the Lanternward are about to decide who they believe.

I stumble back a step from Pell, keeping my apron over my nose and mouth, and point hard toward the yew break. “He’s not alone—Mara went that way with ether after a stranger. One of you, NOW—cut her off before she gets him.”  
Then I look the broad-shouldered Lanternward dead in the face. “Search Pell. Check his pockets and hands—he tried to restrain me. I’m Wren Ashford, cemetery conservation—ask your caretaker if you need a name.”
messages.player_reasoning: Pell’s the immediate danger, but Mara with ether is the real ticking clock; I need the Lanternward to act fast and believe me, and I want distance so I can breathe and think.

messages.content:
I stagger back a step, apron still clamped over my nose and mouth, and jab my finger toward the yew break. “He’s not alone—Mara went that way with ether after a stranger. One of you, now—cut her off before she gets him.”  
Then I fix the broad Lanternward with a steady look. “Search Pell. Check his pockets and his hands—he tried to restrain me. I’m Wren Ashford, cemetery conservation. Ask the caretaker if you need a name.”
messages.player_reasoning: Mara’s still out there with ether and the stranger’s about to be caught; the Lanternward need clear, immediate directions, and I need to anchor my credibility fast with my name and the caretaker.

messages.content:
The key-bearer Lanternward catches your elbow and pulls you two steps back from Pell, putting his own body between you and the snuffer. He keeps his lantern low; the flame inside it still sputters an unhealthy blue.

The broad-shouldered Lanternward doesn’t take his eyes off Pell. “Mara?” he repeats, like the name tastes wrong. Then, without looking away, he snaps at his partner: “Tolan—go. Cut the yew break. Don’t breathe deep if she’s got ether.”

Tolan hesitates—eyes flicking from you to Pell to the dark gap in the yews—then he breaks into a run, lantern bobbing, boots crunching hard as he angles left toward the thicket.

Pell, half-pinned by the lantern pole, tries to straighten and put on indignation. “This is—this is Ashford trouble—she’s—”

“Hands,” the broad one orders.

He shifts the lantern pole to keep Pell’s snuffer arm trapped against the mausoleum stone, then uses his free hand to wrench Pell’s other wrist up and slap it flat to the wall. Pell hisses in pain. The broad Lanternward pats Pell down briskly—coat pockets, waist, inner breast.

His fingers find something. He pulls out a small glass vial wrapped in oiled cloth. When he uncorks it a hair, a sharp, sweet-chemical smell cuts even through your apron.

Pell’s face goes tight. “That’s not—”

The broad Lanternward corks it immediately and stares at Pell like a door has closed. “Ether,” he says, flat. Then, to you, without softening: “Wren Ashford. I know the name. Don’t move from here.”

He yanks Pell’s snuffer hand open. The snuffer drops; the broad Lanternward kicks it away across the gravel where it rings against a headstone base.

From the yew break comes a sudden muffled cough—male, rough—followed by Mara’s voice, breathless and furious: “Stop—STOP—”

Tolan’s lanternlight flashes through the branches as he arrives, and you hear him shout, “Lanternward! Mara, stand down!”

The threat is still active in the yews: Mara is close enough to be heard, ether is confirmed, and the stranger is coughing—possibly exposed.

I keep my apron tight over my nose and mouth and call toward the yews, “Tolan—keep upwind and don’t let her get the cloth on his face!” Then I glance at the broad Lanternward, voice rough. “Let me go with you—I know the breaks in that yew line. If he’s breathing ether, get him into open air—now.”
messages.player_reasoning: Mara’s still loose and someone’s coughing in the yews—if ether’s on that cloth, seconds matter. I’m shaken but I can’t stand still; I’ll keep my face covered, warn them, and try to help the stranger without charging in blindly.

messages.content:
Your voice carries into the yews. Tolan’s answer comes back sharp, already moving: “Upwind—got it!”

The broad-shouldered Lanternward—close enough now that you can see the salt-whitened seams on his gloves—doesn’t immediately agree. He hooks two fingers in the front of your apron and tugs it down just enough to see your mouth and nose are covered properly, then releases it.

“You go in there and you go down,” he says, curt. “And then I’ve got two problems.”

Another cough hacks through the yew break—wet and panicked—followed by a scuffle of shoes on roots. Mara’s voice snaps, nearer than before: “Hold still—just—hold still!”

Tolan’s lantern flares in the branches as he forces his way deeper. You hear a brief, ugly struggle—fabric tearing, someone’s elbow striking wood—then Tolan yells, “Cloth! She’s got a cloth—”

The broad Lanternward makes a decision. He shoves Pell harder into the mausoleum and plants his lantern pole across Pell’s chest like a bar.

“Don’t move,” he tells Pell, low. Then, to you: “You stay where I can see you. If you know the breaks, point. Loud.”

He breaks into a run toward the yew line, lantern in hand, boots slipping once on gravel before catching. As he goes, he calls, “Tolan—drag him out! Don’t wrestle in the thicket!”

From where you stand, you can see just enough: Tolan’s lanternlight jerks, then steadies as he backs out of the yews—hauling a man by the collar and under one arm. The stranger’s knees drag; his head lolls; he’s coughing but fading between coughs, eyes half-shut. Mara is right behind them, hair loose, one hand clutching a rag-dark cloth, the other reaching for the stranger’s shoulder like she can still reclaim him.

The broad Lanternward meets them at the edge and barks, “Mara—hands up. Now.”

Mara freezes for a heartbeat—then her eyes flick past him, toward you, and her fingers tighten on the cloth.

**Threat, clear and present:** Mara still has ether on a cloth and is close enough to press it to the stranger again; the stranger is partially exposed and unsteady, and the Lanternward are split between restraining Mara and keeping Pell pinned behind you.

I keep my apron tight and step sideways to keep Pell in my peripheral, then shout, “Mara—don’t you dare! That’s enough, you’ll kill him!”  
To the broad Lanternward I call, “She’s still got the rag—take her wrist, not the cloth, and get him into open air—face turned away, upwind!”
messages.player_reasoning: Mara’s about to use the cloth again; I can’t fight her, but I can distract and warn the Lanternward while keeping my airway covered.

messages.content:
Your sideways step keeps Pell in the edge of your vision—his shoulders tense under the lantern pole, jaw working like he’s chewing through a lie.

Your shout hits Mara like a thrown stone. For an instant she falters, eyes widening, and the cloth droops an inch.

Then the broad Lanternward takes your instruction exactly the way you meant it: he doesn’t grab for the rag. He lunges for *her wrist*.

Mara twists, fast—trained fast—and the ether-cloth flicks toward his face like a slap. He turns his head away at the last second, but the edge of the rag brushes his cheekbone. He grunts, eyes watering, and still clamps down on her wrist hard enough that you hear the small, sick click of bone shifting.

Mara gasps—half pain, half fury—and tries to switch the cloth to her other hand.

“Tolan—OPEN AIR!” the broad Lanternward barks, voice thickening as he forces breath through his mouth.

Tolan obeys. He drags the stranger two more body-lengths out onto the open gravel, then drops to a knee behind him and hauls him upright, keeping the man’s face turned away from Mara and the yews. The stranger coughs again—stronger, but ragged—spit darkening his lip. His eyes crack open, unfocused.

Mara jerks against the hold. “You don’t understand—he *can’t*—”

“Enough,” the broad Lanternward snarls. He wrenches her arm behind her back and forces her down to her knees at the yew’s edge. The ether-cloth slips from her fingers and falls onto the damp grass.

But the danger doesn’t vanish—it *moves*.

Behind you, Pell suddenly bucks his weight sideways, trying to slide out from under the lantern pole while the broad Lanternward is occupied. The pole scrapes stone with a shriek. Pell’s free hand snakes toward his coat hem—toward somewhere he didn’t have time to be searched.

**Immediate threat:** Pell is trying to get free and reach for something concealed on his person, while the broad Lanternward is restraining Mara and Tolan is occupied keeping the stranger breathing in open air.
I lurch back to the mausoleum and stomp hard on Pell’s reaching hand/coat hem, pinning it to the stone as best I can, and shout, “He’s going for something—Pell’s armed, search him again!”
messages.player_reasoning: Pell moving now means he’s about to pull something worse; I’m not strong enough to fight him cleanly, but I can stop his hand and call for help while keeping my face covered.

messages.content:
You slam back against the mausoleum stones and bring your heel down where Pell’s hand disappears under his coat hem.

Your boot pins cloth and knuckles to cold marble. Pell lets out a sharp, ugly yell and his fingers spasm—something hard clinks once against stone beneath your sole, trapped.

He tries to wrench free, but you’ve got his hand caught at a bad angle. He bucks his shoulder, face twisting toward you. “You—little—” His other arm is still pinned awkwardly by the lantern pole across his chest; he can’t get leverage without scraping himself raw against it.

When you shout, the broad Lanternward’s head snaps toward you—eyes red-rimmed from the ether brush. He doesn’t release Mara, but he shifts his weight and bellows, “Tolan! On Pell—NOW!”

Tolan hesitates only long enough to make sure the stranger won’t topple: he shoves the half-conscious man into a seated slump against a low headstone base, then sprints back across the gravel.

Mara, on her knees, takes advantage of the split second. Her free hand snakes toward the dropped ether-cloth in the grass.

The broad Lanternward sees it and drives his knee into her upper back, forcing her chest-down. “Don’t,” he growls, and yanks her wrists together behind her.

Tolan hits the mausoleum hard. He drops to one knee beside you and Pell and grabs Pell’s coat hem where your boot pins it. “Hold—hold!” he snaps, then pries the fabric up with two fingers and reaches in.

His hand comes out with a compact folding knife—dark handle, salt-stained pivot—half-open from Pell’s fumbling. Tolan flings it away across the gravel; it skitters and disappears under a border of rosemary offerings.

Pell goes pale with rage, then—quick as a reflex—spits, a wet gob that lands near your boot. “Ashford,” he hisses, like it’s a curse. “You don’t know who you’re helping.”

**Current threats, clearly:** Pell is restrained but still dangerous if he wriggles free; Mara is pinned but still conscious and fighting; the stranger is sitting unattended a few paces away, breathing hard and possibly drugged, with no one watching him closely for another attempt.

I keep my boot planted on Pell’s hand and lean down just enough to hiss, “Spit again and I’ll grind your knuckles to bone.” Then I call to Tolan, “Stay on his wrists—tight—he’s still reaching.”  
I flick my eyes to the broad Lanternward. “That man by the headstone—check his breathing. Sit him up, open air, and keep Mara away from that cloth.”
messages.player_reasoning: Pell’s knife was the immediate danger; now the stranger might slip away or crash, and Mara could still get to the ether. I want to keep Pell pinned but make sure the stranger doesn’t die on a headstone while everyone’s distracted.

messages.content:
Pell freezes under your heel, breath coming in short, furious pulls. His eyes track your face, then flick to the yews as if measuring distance. He doesn’t spit again—his lips press into a thin, resentful line.

Tolan takes your cue and commits. He hooks Pell’s near wrist, then the far, forcing both hands up and away from his coat hem. “Got you,” he mutters, and shifts his grip to a painful angle that makes Pell’s shoulders bunch against the lantern pole. Pell jerks once, then stops—contained, but not calm.

The broad Lanternward doesn’t like being given orders, but he hears the practical sense in them. Without fully releasing Mara, he barks, “Mara stays down. Tolan, keep him. Pell—don’t make this worse.”

He drags Mara a half-step farther from the yew edge and the dropped cloth, pinning her wrists together with one hand while he reaches to his belt with the other. A short length of cord comes free; he starts binding her wrists.

Mara turns her face sideways against the grass, voice tight with pain. “He’ll wake wrong,” she says, words clipped. “You think that’s mercy?”

The broad Lanternward snaps back, “Mercy is *air*.”

He then strides to the slumped stranger by the headstone base, keeping his head turned away from where the ether-cloth lies. He crouches, checks the man’s chest with a gloved palm, then grips his jaw and tilts his face up into the wind. “Breathe,” he orders, as if the word can be enforced.

The stranger’s eyelids flutter. He inhales—shallow, then deeper—coughs once, and swallows hard. His gaze latches briefly on the broad Lanternward’s lantern, unfocused but present.

As the broad Lanternward shifts him more upright, something drops from the stranger’s coat pocket and lands with a soft, papery slap on the gravel: a folded square—too clean to be cemetery litter.

The broad Lanternward notices it a beat later. He doesn’t pick it up yet. His eyes lift, scanning the yew line and the blue-guttering lanterns beyond, as if expecting someone to step out and claim it.

**Clear, present danger:** Mara is bound but still fighting and could still lunge for the ether-cloth if she gets a hand free; Pell is restrained but watching for an opening; and the dropped folded paper is now exposed on the gravel—potential evidence or a signal—while the area may still have unseen accomplices nearby.

I keep my boot pinning Pell and call out, “Don’t touch it bare—use a glove or cloth. That paper’s evidence.”  
Then, louder toward the yews, I add, “If anyone’s out there watching, show yourself—this isn’t getting cleaner.”  
Without taking my eyes off Pell, I ask Tolan under my breath, “Can you hold him alone for ten seconds if I move the ether rag farther off?”
messages.player_reasoning: That folded paper feels like the first real thread in this mess—if someone else is watching, it could be a signal. I need it secured without letting Mara or Pell exploit the moment, and I want the Lanternward to treat it as evidence, not trash.

messages.content:
The broad Lanternward pauses over the folded paper, then nods once—tight, reluctant. He pulls a glove fully onto his right hand (he’d had it half-on), pinches the paper by one corner, and lifts it as if it might bite. He doesn’t unfold it yet. He holds it up to the lantern’s blue-sputtering light, angling it to catch any ink bleed-through.

At your louder call toward the yews, nothing obligingly steps out.

What you get instead is a sound: a faint *double-click* from deeper in the greenery, like two stones tapped together. Then a second, farther left. Not speech—signal.

Pell’s eyes snap toward the yews at the first click. His jaw loosens in something like satisfaction. Under your boot his fingers try to curl, testing your balance, but Tolan tightens his hold on Pell’s wrists and forces them up higher.

Tolan answers you under his breath without looking away from Pell. “Ten seconds?” He swallows. “Yes. But if he bucks, I’m breaking something.”

Mara, wrists bound, lifts her head enough to rasp, “They’re not going to show themselves. That’s not how—” The broad Lanternward cuts her off with a sharp tug on the cord, forcing her back down.

The stranger by the headstone base takes a deeper breath and then a sudden, wet cough. He doubles forward, retches once—mostly air and a thin spit—and his gaze clears just enough to snag on *you*, then Pell, then the glove-held paper. His lips part as if to speak, but only a hoarse whisper comes out: “Map… not… theirs…”

The broad Lanternward, still crouched, finally unfolds the paper one careful crease at a time.

It’s a maintenance overlay—thin vellum, inked with plot lines and narrow dotted routes that don’t match any public cemetery map. In the margin: three looping letters in an old shorthand—familiar enough to make your stomach dip, even at a glance.

The lantern beside you flares a brighter, attentive blue for a heartbeat, throwing everyone’s shadows long and sharp across the mausoleum face—your profile clear as a cutout.

And from the path below, a voice calls out with practiced cheer, closing in through the fog: “Oh! There you all are—what a *busy* little scene. Are we having an after-hours tour?”

A Lanternward tour-guide is drifting up the gravel walk, smile already in place, eyes aimed like hooks at your hands and tools and stance over Pell. The threat is immediate and social as much as physical: someone official is arriving to control the story.

I ease my boot off Pell’s hand but keep my weight ready, lifting both palms a fraction like I’m de-escalating. “Not a tour,” I call down to the approaching guide, steady and loud. “An assault—ether. We’ve got two restrained and one half-suffocated. Get a medic and keep your people back.”  

Without looking away, I murmur to Tolan, “Hold him—don’t break him unless you have to.” Then I flick my eyes to the broad Lanternward and tip my chin toward the unfolded vellum. “That shorthand—bag it. Now.”
messages.player_reasoning: A tour-guide means optics and narrative control; I need to look nonviolent, protect evidence, and quietly signal the broad Lanternward that the map matters. Also, the ether rag is still a hazard—if I can move it without losing Pell, I should, but not if it makes us look guilty.

messages.content:
Pell’s hand snaps back to his chest the moment your boot lifts. He cradles it, flexing his fingers with a grimace—hurt, but functional. He immediately tries to twist his shoulders to slip Tolan’s hold.

Tolan adjusts fast, planting a knee between Pell’s shoulder blades and hauling both wrists higher. “Stay,” Tolan growls. Pell sucks in a breath through his teeth but doesn’t get free.

Down the path, the Lanternward guide slows—then keeps coming anyway, boots crunching gravel with deliberate calm. She’s in a neat coat with a silver lantern pin; her hair is pinned back so tightly it looks painful. Her smile doesn’t reach her eyes.

“A medic,” she repeats, as if tasting the word. “Of course. We’ll see to everyone’s… comfort.” She lifts a small whistle from her pocket but doesn’t blow it yet. Instead she looks past you to the broad Lanternward and the vellum. “Steward Halden—what is that in your hand?”

Halden (broad Lanternward) hesitates a fraction at your “bag it” order—then chooses speed over argument. He snaps the vellum closed, keeping his glove on, and shoves it into the inside pocket of his coat. Not bagged—hidden on his person.

He says, loud enough for the guide to hear, “Found on the ground. Potentially connected.”

The guide’s gaze flicks to Mara, bound in the grass. “Mara? Really?” Her tone turns gently disappointed, like a teacher catching a child with ink-stained fingers. Mara’s eyes burn up at her, but she stays down, breathing hard.

The slumped stranger coughs again and manages a rasped sentence toward Halden: “Don’t—give—her—” He chokes on the last word and swallows, eyes watering.

The guide raises the whistle to her lips.

At the same time, from the yews comes a sharper sound than before: a single click, then a low, drawn-out *moan*—not a voice, not quite a bell, but close enough that the blue lanterns along the upper path answer with a brief sputter in sequence.

Halden’s head jerks toward the yews. His hand goes to the pocket where he stuffed the vellum.

The immediate threat is now twofold and concrete: the guide is about to summon more Lanternward with her whistle—likely to seize control of everyone and the evidence—while whatever is signaling from the yews is coordinating movement nearby, and Pell is watching both, poised to exploit the distraction.

I step toward the guide with my palms still up, voice calm but edged. “Don’t blow that. We have an active ether incident and an unknown signal in the yews—your whistle will draw people straight into it.”

I glance to Halden and jerk my chin toward the mausoleum shadow. “Halden—bag the vellum properly, now. Away from her and away from your pocket.” Then I call, “Tolan, keep Pell facedown—don’t let him watch the yews.”

Without waiting for permission, I angle my body between the guide and the scene and add, quieter but firm, “If you’re here to ‘see to comfort,’ then get your medic and keep the rest back until we know who’s clicking in the trees.”
messages.player_reasoning: The guide’s whistle will turn this into a controlled narrative and we’ll lose the map; I need to stop that without escalating into a brawl, and get Halden to secure evidence properly. The yew signals mean someone’s coordinating—keep eyes up and buy seconds.

messages.content:
I step in front of the guide, palms up in a steadying gesture. “Don’t blow that—there’s ether in the air and someone signaling in the yews. A whistle brings more people into the danger.”  
I cut my eyes to Halden and jerk my chin toward the mausoleum shadow. “Halden—bag the vellum properly, now. Not your pocket.” Then, sharp to Tolan: “Keep Pell facedown—don’t let him watch the trees.”
messages.player_reasoning: The guide’s whistle could turn this into a pile of bodies and confiscated evidence; I need to slow her down and get Halden to secure the vellum properly while keeping Pell from coordinating with whoever’s in the yews.

messages.content:
You get between the guide and the knot of bodies, forcing her to either stop or bump you. She stops short—close enough you can see the salt-fine mist beading on her lashes. The whistle is at her lips, but she doesn’t blow it yet.

Her eyes track your raised hands, then flick past your shoulder to Pell and the stranger. “Ether,” she repeats, voice low now, the cheer gone. “That’s a serious accusation, Miss Ashford.”

She lowers the whistle a few inches—not pocketing it, just holding it ready. “If there’s ether, you move people *downwind* and you don’t crowd a casualty.” Her gaze hooks on the slumped stranger. “Halden—get him onto the path. Now.”

Halden hears your order and makes a quick decision in the mausoleum’s shadow. He pulls a small oilskin evidence pouch from his belt—creased, used—and, keeping his glove on, transfers the folded vellum from his coat pocket into the pouch without fully exposing it again. He rolls the top, ties it off, and then—importantly—doesn’t keep it. He sets it on the mausoleum’s stone ledge behind his boot, out of the guide’s direct line of sight but not in anyone’s hands.

The guide notices the movement anyway. Her chin lifts. “What did you just bag?”

“Found property,” Halden answers, too neutral. He doesn’t offer it.

Tolan obeys immediately: he shoves Pell’s cheek into the grass and shifts his knee higher across Pell’s shoulder blades, forcing Pell’s face away from the yews. Pell snarls something muffled and tries to crane his neck; Tolan yanks his wrists up hard enough that Pell grunts and stops trying.

From the yews, the signaling changes. You hear two quick clicks—closer than before—followed by a soft scuff of shoes on damp leaves. Someone is moving, using the cover. The threat is no longer abstract: there is at least one unseen person repositioning in the trees within a few yards.

The guide’s thumb tightens on the whistle. “If someone’s in those yews,” she says, voice clipped, “we call lanterns. That’s procedure.”

She takes one half-step to angle around you for a clearer sightline—testing whether you’ll let her past—while her eyes dart between the yews and the bagged vellum’s location.

I shift with her half-step, keeping my body between her and the scene. “Procedure doesn’t outrank safety—if you call lanterns, you call them to the *lower gate* and you keep them out of this drift.”

I cut my gaze to Halden. “Get the casualty downwind onto the path, then stand on that pouch like it’s your oath.” Then I raise my voice toward the yews, steady and cold: “I hear you moving. Step out with your hands visible, or I start naming what you’re doing to every lantern that arrives.”
messages.player_reasoning: The guide’s about to escalate and pull more people into a potentially gassed area; I need to keep her contained, get eyes on the yews, and secure the evidence without letting her seize it.

messages.content:
You mirror the guide’s angle perfectly. She can’t get a clean line past you without putting hands on you—and she doesn’t. Her jaw tightens.

“Lower gate,” she repeats. The whistle hovers at her mouth again, and she makes a sharp, decisive choice: she blows it once—short, controlled, not a long alarm. The sound is bright and cutting.

A heartbeat later, somewhere below the tier, you hear it answered: one whistle back, farther off, and the faint clatter of a lantern pole against stone as someone starts moving.

Halden moves on your instruction, but he doesn’t do it gently. He hooks his arms under the slumped stranger’s shoulders and drags him onto the path, boots scraping gravel. The stranger’s head lolls; he coughs wetly and tries to speak, failing. Halden then steps back to the mausoleum ledge and plants his boot squarely in front of the oilskin pouch—blocking it with his shin like a guard at a threshold.

Tolan keeps Pell pinned facedown. Pell’s eyes squeeze shut against the grass; he stops straining his neck and instead goes very still, listening.

Your call into the yews lands. The scuffing stops.

Then, from the dark under the branches, a voice answers—soft, close, and amused in a way that doesn’t match the situation. “Naming? To lanterns?” A pause. “You think they don’t already know the words?”

A figure doesn’t step out. Instead, a small object arcs from the yews and lands on the path with a light *clink* about six feet from the casualty: a glass vial, stoppered, rolling to a stop.

It’s not smoking. But the air around it has a sharp, sweet-cold bite that makes the back of your throat prickle—the same wrongness you’ve tasted near fresh-cut stone dust and blue-guttering lanterns.

The guide’s posture changes instantly: she grabs your forearm—not hard enough to bruise, hard enough to move you—trying to pull you back from the vial and clear her sightline. “No one touches that,” she snaps, eyes fixed on the glass.

From the yews comes one more click—right, then left—like someone signaling to two positions.

Whatever is in the trees is coordinating, and the vial on the path is now a clear, immediate hazard between you and the casualty.

I let the guide pull me back a step, then gently peel her hand off my forearm. “Agreed—no one touches it. But you don’t get to move me like furniture.”

I angle my body so the breeze hits my face, then point with two fingers. “Halden, drag him farther downwind—now. Tolan, keep Pell pinned and quiet.”

Without taking my eyes off the yews, I call out, steady as stone: “You just tossed a vial at a dying man. Step out and say what it is, or when Lanternward arrive I’ll tell them you tried to gas a casualty—loud enough for the whole tier to hear.”
messages.player_reasoning: Wren is cautious around chemicals and evidence; she won’t touch the vial, but she’ll control the guide’s grip, protect the casualty, and try to flush the hidden watcher into revealing themselves while keeping everyone downwind.

messages.content:
The guide lets her hand be removed, but her eyes stay hard on you for a beat—measuring. “Fine,” she says through her teeth. “Don’t be furniture. Be *useful*.”

Halden doesn’t argue. He grips the casualty under the arms again and hauls him farther along the path, boots skidding on gravel as he drags the man past a lantern base and away from the vial. The stranger coughs once—violent—and a thread of dark spit hits the stone. He’s breathing, but it’s shallow and fast.

Tolan keeps Pell pinned, shifting his weight to keep Pell’s chest from twisting. “Quiet,” Tolan growls. Pell makes a small, furious sound and then—like a sulking child—goes limp, conserving himself.

Your threat into the yews buys you one thing: movement. Not surrender—repositioning.

A shadow detaches from the yew line on the *left*—not stepping into the open, just edging to where you can see a sleeve and a hand braced against a trunk. The hand is gloved. In it: a short lantern-hook pole, the kind used to snuff and raise wicks. Its metal tip gleams.

The voice speaks again, now closer on that side. “Gas?” A soft laugh. “No. That’s for waking.”

Then, on the *right* side of the yews, you hear a quick scrape and see a second shape move—low, crouched—crossing behind headstones. Two positions, like the clicks suggested. One is a distraction; the other is trying to flank.

The vial on the path suddenly beads with condensation, as if the air around it has cooled. The sweet-cold bite strengthens. Your eyes sting slightly. It’s not spreading like fog yet, but it’s getting more active—either reacting to air or to time.

The guide raises her whistle again, but this time she doesn’t blow it—she points it at you like a warning. “Lanternward will come from the lower gate,” she says, tight and fast. “But if you keep antagonizing whoever’s in those trees, they’ll run—or they’ll strike.”

Down the tier, footsteps and the bobbing glow of a lantern are now visible through the mist: two Lanternward coming up at a brisk pace, poles in hand. They’re still half a minute out.

Immediate threats are now clear and present:
- the vial is “activating” in the open path near you (irritant/ether-like effect increasing),
- one person in the yews has a metal hook-pole and line of sight,
- another is moving low behind stones to your right, attempting to get around you before help arrives.

I tug my scarf up over my nose and mouth and gesture the guide back with two sharp fingers. “Cover your face—get behind the mausoleum. If that blooms, it’ll take your lungs first.”

Keeping low, I grab a loose handful of gravel and snap it hard toward the left yew-line—aiming for the gloved hand and lantern-hook pole—then pivot and shout to the incoming Lanternward, “Yews—two hostiles! One left with a hook-pole, one flanking right behind the stones!”

Without looking away from the trees, I call to Halden, “Use your pole—pin the vial under stone or kick grit over it from a distance, don’t touch it!”
messages.player_reasoning: The vial feels like it’s about to bloom into something that’ll drop all of us, and there are two attackers trying to split our attention. I’m not strong enough to fight them, but I can control space and buy seconds until Lanternward arrive—without letting the guide take charge of the evidence or the narrative.

messages.content:
You get your scarf up in time; the sweet-cold sting still creeps into your eyes, but it’s dulled. Your two-finger gesture snaps the guide out of her stance. She doesn’t argue—she ducks back behind the mausoleum corner, pressing her own scarf to her mouth. “You’d better be right,” she mutters, and stays low.

You scoop gravel and whip it into the left yew-line.

It hits. A sharp *tink* on metal, then a grunt. The gloved hand jerks back; the lantern-hook pole clatters once against the trunk and dips out of sight. Leaves shiver violently where the gravel tore through.

But it also gives away your exact angle.

A split-second later, something lashes out from that same left-side cover: the hook-pole swings back into view, arcing fast and low toward the open path—not at you, but at the vial. The metal tip *hooks* the vial’s neck and drags it a foot across the stone with a squeal of glass.

The stoppered vial doesn’t break. It skitters, spins, and leaves a wet-looking track of condensation on the path. The air bite spikes—your eyes water hard even through the scarf.

On your right, the flanking shape commits: a crouched figure darts from behind a headstone, closing the gap toward Halden’s position. You see a pale sleeve and a hand holding something small and dark—too compact to be a pole, more like a tool or knife.

Your shout reaches the incoming Lanternward. Both of them accelerate instantly, poles coming up. “LEFT YEW!” one calls back, voice rough. The other veers right, trying to cut off the flanker’s line.

Halden reacts to your order with the only leverage he has: he grabs a flat, palm-sized stone from the path edge with his boot and kicks it—hard—so it skids and slaps over the vial. It doesn’t pin it perfectly, but it partially covers it, and the glass stops rolling.

The effect changes: instead of “activating” in the open air, the sting becomes a concentrated, sharp plume seeping around the stone’s edges—still dangerous, but less widespread.

The casualty, downwind, coughs again and curls inward, trying to get his face away from the air. He’s conscious enough to flinch.

The left yew attacker retreats a half-step deeper—branches swallowing the hook-pole again—while the right-side flanker is now within a few strides of Halden and the casualty, moving fast and low.

Immediate threat: the flanker is about to reach Halden/casualty; the vial is partially covered but still venting irritant around the stone; Lanternward are closing but not yet in contact.

I stay low and rush two steps toward the flanker’s line, then snatch up my lantern-hook pole and sweep it hard across the gravel in front of their knees to trip them. “Halden—back, keep him behind you!” I bark, then shout to the Lanternward on the right, “They’re on Halden—now, now!”
messages.player_reasoning: The flanker is the immediate danger to Halden and the casualty; I’m not a fighter, but I can distract and use the cemetery terrain. I want to protect the vulnerable and keep eyes off the vial while Lanternward close in.

messages.content:
You surge two steps and sweep your lantern-hook pole low across the gravel.

The flanker tries to hop it—too late. The pole catches the front of their shins with a dull *thunk* and their feet skid on the loose stones. They pitch forward, hands shooting out. Whatever they were holding—a compact, dark-handled tool—flies from their grip and skips across the path, disappearing into the grass by the mausoleum’s edge.

They hit the ground hard on one shoulder and roll, fast and practiced, trying to get their legs under them again. Close enough now, you catch details: a cemetery work-coat, salt-stained at the cuffs; a scarf tied high; and a smear of pale clay on one glove like fresh stone dust.

“Halden—back, keep him behind you!” you bark.

Halden obeys, hauling the casualty another half-step downwind and putting his own body squarely between the fallen attacker and the man on the ground. He raises his pole defensively like a quarterstaff, breathing through his teeth. “Stay DOWN,” he snaps.

Your shout to the right-side Lanternward lands at exactly the right moment. The Lanternward who’d veered right closes the last yards at a run and brings their pole down—not striking the attacker’s head, but jabbing the ferrule into the attacker’s hip and ribs to pin them to the gravel.

“Hands!” the Lanternward barks. “Hands where I can see them!”

The attacker freezes for a fraction of a second… then does something uglier: they twist their torso and slam their palm into the gravel, crushing something small under their glove. There’s a sharp *crack*—like a vial or ampoule breaking.

A thin, icy-white vapor puffs up around their hand and along the ground, hugging low like it’s heavier than air. It’s not a big cloud yet, but it’s spreading toward Halden’s boots and the casualty’s legs.

The Lanternward recoils half a step, swearing, and yanks their scarf up over their mouth. “Brine-sweet!” they rasp. “Don’t breathe it!”

From the left yews, the hook-pole scrapes stone again—still there, still moving—while the partially covered vial near the path continues to vent a sharp plume around the stone.

Right now the clear threats are:
- a new low-lying vapor spreading from the flanker’s crushed ampoule toward Halden and the casualty,
- the original vial still venting near the path,
- the left-side attacker remains in the yews with a hook-pole, uncontained.

I yank my scarf tighter and grab Halden’s sleeve, pulling him and the casualty two quick steps uphill and away from the ground-hugging vapor. “Up—higher ground, now. Don’t let it crawl into his mouth.”  

Then I stab my pole toward the left yews without advancing. “Lanternward—one still in the yews with a hook-pole! Keep your distance; don’t let them drag that first vial free.” I glance at the pinned attacker and snap, “What did you just break—what is it?”
messages.player_reasoning: The vapor is the immediate lethal risk—get the casualty and Halden out of the low cloud; also keep the left yew attacker from interfering while Lanternward secure the downed one.

messages.content:
You wrench your scarf tight and catch Halden by the sleeve. He goes with the pull immediately, dragging the casualty with him; the man’s heels scrape as you all retreat two quick steps uphill onto a slightly higher ribbon of path.

It helps. The ground-hugging vapor keeps low, spilling like cold breath across the gravel where the attacker cracked the ampoule. It curls around the Lanternward’s boots and Halden’s *former* position, but it doesn’t climb fast. The casualty coughs once, wet and panicked, then manages a thin inhale through clenched teeth—still conscious, still in trouble, but you’ve kept the worst of it from pouring straight into his face.

Your pole-stab toward the left yews draws eyes. The second Lanternward (the one who’d been coming up the path) plants their pole and swings their lantern high, trying to light the yew line without stepping into it. “I see movement,” they call—voice muffled behind cloth. “Stay out of the brush!”

In answer, the left-side attacker makes their play anyway: the hook-pole shoots out from the foliage and *snags the edge* of the flat stone Halden kicked over the first vial. Metal grates on stone; the cover shifts a few inches.

The plume around that first vial strengthens again, sharper and more immediate, and you feel it sting your eyes even uphill.

The Lanternward with the raised lantern jabs their pole forward and pins the hook-pole against a headstone corner with a hard, practiced shove—metal-on-metal *clang*. “Drop it!” they bark into the yews. “Lanternward—drop it now!”

At your question, the pinned attacker—still held at the ribs/hip by the other Lanternward’s pole—turns their head just enough for you to see their eyes above the scarf: grey, watering, furious.

They spit words like they hurt. “Moon-salt. Brine-sweet. Same thing you people keep pretending is folklore.” They cough once, then add, quieter and uglier: “It keeps you quiet. Keeps you… *compliant*.”

Their gloved hand flexes, grinding shards into the gravel.

Immediate threats are now:
- the first vial’s irritant plume is increasing again because its cover was shifted,
- the left yew attacker is still engaged and trying to free/drag that vial with the hook-pole,
- the broken ampoule’s low vapor continues to spread along the ground where the pinned attacker fell—less dangerous uphill, but it’s contaminating the area around the Lanternward holding them.

“Compliant,” I repeat under my breath, anger sharp in my chest. Then I look to Halden. “Get him uphill to clean air—keep his face turned into the wind. Don’t stop.”

I call to the Lanternward with the raised lantern, voice tight through my scarf: “Don’t wrestle the hook—*break their leverage*. Pin it and step on it if you have to.” Then, keeping my distance, I scrape my boot through the gravel and kick a broad fan of grit and dirt over the shifted stone and the vial’s edges, trying to smother the plume without getting close enough to breathe it.

My eyes cut back to the pinned attacker. “Who sent you? And where did you get moon-salt?”
messages.player_reasoning: Wren’s protective instincts kick in—get the casualty farther from both vapors, and use her cemetery know-how to smother the vial without touching it. She’s also rattled by “compliant” and wants names and motives, but not at the cost of someone dying.

messages.content:
Halden doesn’t argue. He braces the casualty under the arms and hauls him uphill, turning the man’s face into the wind like you said. “Breathe with me—short,” he orders, and keeps moving. The casualty’s coughs thin out into harsh, shallow pulls; he’s not fine, but he’s getting air.

Your instruction to the lantern-raised Lanternward lands. They stop trying to “win” the hook-pole and instead *kill the angle*: they slam their own pole down across it and put a boot on the shaft, grinding it against the headstone corner until the yew-side attacker loses purchase.

There’s a sharp crack—wood under strain—and the hook-pole end *splinters*. The yew-side attacker jerks back, suddenly holding a shortened, broken length.

A second later, a figure bolts from the yews—not toward you, but sideways, using the brush as cover. They’re fast and low, scarf up, coat flapping. The Lanternward’s lantern swings after them, but the beam catches only the white flash of a sleeve and then nothing but trembling branches. Footfalls retreat into the terraces.

Your boot-scrape and kick do what you intended, but not neatly. The fan of grit and dirt skitters over the shifted stone and the vial’s exposed edge. The plume *thickens for a breath* as you disturb it—your eyes sting hard and tears spill despite the scarf—then the dirt begins to cake over the stoppered glass and the stone settles back down. The venting drops from a sharp “bite” to a thinner seep.

You’ve reduced the immediate spread, but you’ve also made a messy, contaminated patch of gravel that will keep irritating anyone who steps into it.

Behind you, the pinned attacker flinches at your questions, then goes still. Their eyes flick—not to your face, but to the lantern-glass, catching their own reflection for a heartbeat as if checking what it reveals.

A voice answers from the path behind the mausoleum, bright with too-perfect politeness: “Oh—goodness. Is someone hurt?”

A cheerful tide-singer stands there in a damp wool cloak, hands folded as if in prayer. She looks from the casualty being hauled uphill to the grit-smeared vial patch, and then to you.

The pinned attacker’s gaze snaps to her and shuts like a door.

Under the Lanternward’s pole, the attacker rasps, “No one *sent* me.”

Then, after a pause that’s almost a dare: “Ask the Choir where they keep their ‘blessings.’”

The tide-singer’s smile doesn’t move, but her eyes do—down to the ground, to the vapor hugging the gravel, measuring distance like she’s counting steps.

I step sideways to put myself between the tide-singer and the contaminated gravel, keeping my pole low like a barrier. “Yes—someone’s hurt, and the ground’s fouled. Stay where you are and cover your face.”

Without taking my eyes off her, I call to the Lanternward, “Keep her back from the vapor—don’t let anyone walk through that patch.” Then I look down at the pinned attacker. “If you’re so eager to talk, start with a name—yours—or I let Lanternward decide how long you sit in irons.”
messages.player_reasoning: The tide-singer’s timing feels wrong, and the attacker just pointed at the Choir; I need to protect the casualty and keep the scene controlled without provoking a panic.

messages.content:
You slide sideways and get your body between the tide-singer and the fouled gravel, pole held low like a gate. It works: she stops short, cloak hem hovering just shy of the dirty, stinging patch. She doesn’t argue—she lifts the edge of her sleeve to her mouth with a practiced motion, like she’s done it before.

One Lanternward (the one not pinning the attacker) immediately shifts to your call. He angles his lantern to mark the contaminated ground and points with the butt of his pole. “No one steps here,” he orders, voice rough. He positions himself half a pace behind the tide-singer, not touching her, but ready to block her retreat or advance.

The tide-singer’s eyes flick to that Lanternward, then back to you. “I only came because I heard shouting,” she says, polite as a pamphlet. “If there’s been… an incident… the Choir can provide clean cloth and vinegar. For the lungs.”

Behind you uphill, Halden is still moving with the casualty; you hear him call, “He’s wheezing—keep him awake!” Their footsteps fade a little farther up the tier.

When you drop your gaze to the pinned attacker and demand a name, they tense under the pole. The Lanternward holding them presses the ferrule in harder; the attacker lets out a short grunt, then forces their breathing shallow through the scarf.

For a moment they look like they’ll spit defiance again—then their eyes cut to the tide-singer, and their bravado falters.

“Jory,” they rasp finally. “Jory Latch.”

The tide-singer’s head tilts a fraction at the name—small, almost involuntary. She covers it quickly with a soft, concerned sound. “Oh. Jory.”

Jory’s gaze hardens at her. “Don’t,” they hiss.

The danger shifts rather than vanishes:
- the fouled gravel patch is still active; anyone stepping into it will get stinging eyes and coughing fits, especially downwind
- Jory is restrained but conscious and desperate; their hands are free enough to try another concealed trick if they have one
- the tide-singer is staying put, but she’s now clearly connected to the name you got, and she’s watching the scene with careful attention—not panic

I keep my pole low between us and the fouled gravel and fix the tide-singer with a steady look. “You know him. Name, rank—what do you call yourself, and why does ‘Jory Latch’ make you flinch?”

Without looking away, I call to the Lanternward pinning Jory, “Bind their hands—now. Check their pockets for more glass.” Then, quieter to Jory, “If the Choir didn’t send you, tell me who taught you to carry moon-salt into a graveyard.”
messages.player_reasoning: The tide-singer’s reaction to Jory’s name feels like a thread worth tugging, but the immediate priority is keeping everyone out of the contaminated patch and getting the casualty help; I’ll press the tide-singer for specifics while making sure Jory can’t pull another trick.

messages.content:
The tide-singer’s polite mask tightens—not a smile anymore, just a controlled line. She keeps her sleeve over her mouth and answers as if reciting something approved.

“Maris Pell,” she says. “Brine-Choir—shore steward.” Her eyes stay on you, but her attention keeps darting to the lantern marking the contaminated patch. “And I didn’t flinch. I recognized a congregant.”

Jory makes a small, involuntary sound—half laugh, half choke. “Congregant,” they spit. “That what we are now.”

At your order, the Lanternward pinning Jory doesn’t waste time. He barks, “Hands. Now.” When Jory hesitates, the ferrule digs in again. Jory’s hands come forward.

The other Lanternward steps in with cord from his belt—rough twine that smells of tar—and binds Jory’s wrists tight. As he does, he pats down Jory’s coat and trouser pockets with quick, practiced strikes.

“More glass,” he mutters, and pulls out:
- a second small ampoule wrapped in waxed paper (unbroken),
- a flat tin with a salt-crusted seam,
- and a narrow tool—like a grave-rubbing pick, but sharper.

Maris’s gaze fixes on the flat tin. For the first time her composure slips; she takes one step back—straight into the Lanternward’s space behind her—then stops herself.

“Careful,” she says, voice suddenly urgent. “Don’t open that here.”

The Lanternward pauses, tin in hand, looking to his partner. “Is it more of the same?”

Your quieter question to Jory lands differently than your threats. Jory’s shoulders sag a fraction, as if the bindings have made honesty cheaper.

“They taught us at the lantern-shed,” Jory whispers, eyes reddened and watering. “Not the Choir. Not—” Their gaze flicks to Maris and away. “A man with ink-stained fingers. Said it was ‘for keeping order.’ Said the cemetery’s been… drifting.”

Maris’s eyes go sharp at that. “You’re lying,” she says, but she doesn’t sound sure—she sounds frightened of what it would mean if Jory isn’t.

Downhill, the fouled patch still breathes thinly where you kicked grit over it. The wind shifts once, and the sting reaches your eyes again—warning you that if anyone opens that tin, whatever’s inside could ride the same air.

I square my shoulders toward Maris, pole still low as a barrier. “Shore steward, then steward the truth: why does that tin scare you, and which Lanternward has ink-stained fingers?”

messages.player_reasoning: The tin feels like the next disaster waiting to happen, so I need it moved to clean air; Maris and Jory both reacted to it, so pressing them now might crack the story before anyone runs.

messages.content:
The Lanternward with the tin freezes at your snap, then obeys fast. He yanks off his own neck-cloth, folds it twice around the salt-crusted tin, and knots it with tarry twine until it’s a bundled brick. He doesn’t hand it off—he keeps it at arm’s length like it might bite.

“Up,” his partner orders, and the man moves uphill at a quick walk, staying upwind of the fouled gravel as best he can. As he passes, he calls toward the fading commotion above, “Halden—sealed item coming up! Don’t open—keep it out of air!”

Maris watches the bundle go with a look that’s half relief, half dread. When you press her, she draws her sleeve down just enough to speak clearly.

“That tin is brine-tithe,” she says. “Not salt. Not incense. It’s… what the drowned pay with when they want a name changed. When they want a ledger to forget.” Her eyes flick to the lantern-marked contamination. “If it’s opened in a living wind, it clings. It finds mouths.”

On “ink-stained fingers,” she hesitates. The hesitation is real; she’s choosing which danger to invite.

“There’s a clerk,” she says finally, voice tighter. “Lanternward-adjacent. Keeps the tour lists and the maintenance notes. Always smells of iron-gall ink. Everyone calls him Mr. Sallow. I don’t know his given name.”

At your last questions, Jory’s jaw works as if they’re chewing grit. Bound wrists flex uselessly against the twine.

“North lantern-shed,” Jory answers, breathy. “By the yew walk. Two nights ago—after the last tour. He—Sallow—said Halden was ‘too curious’ and you were ‘too careful.’ Said you’d both start noticing the plot shifts.”

Jory swallows, eyes darting past you toward the stones, toward the tier where the lanterns burn wrong.

“I didn’t come for Halden,” they say. “Not first. I came for the coordinates. For the grave that doesn’t want to stay in its own family. We were told it would be here tonight—because the blue lanterns would… show the path.”

Downhill, the fouled gravel patch stirs again as the wind shifts; your eyes sting, and Jory coughs once into their scarf despite themselves. The threat is immediate and practical: if the air turns toward you, you’ll all start tearing up and choking—bound or not—and anyone who panics could stumble straight into the contaminated strip.

I tug my scarf higher and gesture with my pole. “Everyone upwind—now. Two paces back from the marked ground, no heroics.” 

I fix Maris with a hard look as I herd her with the pole’s tip. “You’re coming uphill with us, Maris. If brine-tithe changes ledgers, then you tell me whose name they’re trying to erase.” 

Then I lean close to Jory—careful of the air—and murmur, “Coordinates to what grave, Jory? Give me the family name on the stone, and tell me what the blue lanterns ‘show’—is it light, or something else?”
messages.player_reasoning: The wind’s turning and the fouled patch is getting worse; I need to move us upwind, keep Maris from bolting, and lock down what “grave that doesn’t want to stay” means while Jory’s talking.

messages.content:
I pull my scarf up over my nose and motion with my pole. “Upwind—now. Two paces back from the marked ground. No heroics.”  
I herd Maris with the pole’s tip toward the uphill path. “You’re coming with us, Maris. If brine-tithe erases names, you tell me whose name they’re trying to wipe clean.”  
Then I lean in toward Jory, low and controlled. “Coordinates to which grave, Jory—family name on the stone. And the blue lanterns… do they *light* the path, or do they *pull* it?”
messages.player_reasoning: The air is turning and the fouled gravel is still a hazard; I need to get everyone upwind and keep Maris close while pressing Jory for specifics before panic makes them clam up.

messages.content:
Your order cuts through the coughing and gawking. The two Lanternward on your side of the marked strip retreat immediately—boots scraping gravel as they take two full paces back, then another when the wind twitches. One of them drags a fallen lantern-hook with his heel to keep anyone from stepping forward.

Maris moves when you herd her, but not obediently—calculating. She keeps her face angled away from the contaminated patch and follows the uphill path, shoulders tight like she expects a hand on her collar at any moment.

“You don’t get to *take* me uphill,” she says through her scarf, then adds, quieter, “but you’re right about one thing: if that tin’s opened down here, we’ll have more than tears.”

At your demand—whose name—they reach the first bend where the wind is cleaner and the blue guttering is less direct. Maris stops, puts a palm on the iron rail, and finally answers in a clipped spill:

“They aren’t erasing a fisherman. They’re erasing a *witness*.” Her eyes flick to you. “A woman tied to Ashford & Daughters. Someone whose shorthand shows up where it shouldn’t.”

Behind you, Jory flinches when you lean in, then steadies—eyes red-rimmed from the sting. They angle their mouth toward your ear to keep their words from carrying.

“Not light,” Jory whispers. “It *pulls*. Like a tide under glass.”

They give you the grave as if reciting a lesson they hate: “Family name: **CROFT**. Plot used to be Croft—third tier, east of the rosemary row. But the stone won’t sit. The border keeps… correcting itself. Like it wants another family’s dirt.”

Jory’s gaze darts past you to the lanterns uphill. “The blue doesn’t show a path on the ground. It shows it in the *air*—a thin shimmer, like heat over tar. If you breathe it in, you start walking the line without meaning to.”

As if to prove the point, one of the Lanternward nearest the strip takes a half-step forward without thinking—eyes unfocused for a beat—then jolts back when his partner grabs his sleeve hard enough to tear a stitch.

Uphill, above the bend, a bell buoy moans once—too close to be from the shore—answered by a smaller, metal-on-metal click from somewhere within the cemetery structures. The north lantern-shed, if it’s open, just announced itself.

I go very still at “Ashford & Daughters,” then keep moving, voice low. “Say her name, Maris—out loud. If it’s mine to carry, I’ll carry it.”

I wave the nearest Lanternward closer without letting them step downwind. “Two of you on Jory—eyes on their feet, no drifting. The rest with me to the north lantern-shed; scarves up, mouths closed if you can manage it.”

As we start uphill, I murmur to Jory, “If the blue starts pulling, you tell me before you move—do you hear anything when it happens, like surf in a shell?”
messages.player_reasoning: The mention of a witness tied to my family and the lantern-shed click feels urgent; I need to keep everyone from breathing the “pull” while pressing Maris for specifics and moving toward the shed before evidence disappears.

messages.content:
Maris’s steps falter at your request. She looks at the iron guide-rail your hand brushed a moment ago, then at the lanterns, as if weighing which parts of the cemetery can “hear.”

“You don’t want that said here,” she mutters—too late, because you’ve already asked for it.

She swallows and says it anyway, sharp and resentful, pitched low but audible in the rail’s reach: “**Iris Ashford.**”

The effect is immediate and ugly.

A thin bell-buoy moan threads through the mist—closer than any shoreline buoy has a right to be—and the nearest lanterns along the tier dim half a shade, blue-sputtering like they’ve turned their wicks toward your voice. For two heartbeats the air feels tight, as if the cemetery is holding it.

A pale moth—thumbprint-sized, almost colorless—lifts from the nearest lantern-glass where it had been still as a fleck of ash. It flutters in a small, deliberate spiral, then darts away upslope toward the Lanternward office roofs, as if carrying the sound with it.

The Lanternward you beckon do exactly what you say: two fall in on Jory, each taking an elbow and keeping their own faces turned upwind. One of them—older, with a split thumbnail—keeps repeating, “Feet still. Eyes on me,” like a charm. The rest bunch with you toward the north lantern-shed, scarves up, mouths shut.

Jory answers your murmur without moving their feet, voice strained. “Yes. Like surf in a shell—only it’s… backwards. Like it’s pulling the sound *in*.”

You make it another dozen paces uphill when a figure steps out from between two leaning marbles ahead—close enough that they must have been waiting just off the path.

A Brine-Choir “volunteer,” by the sash and the neat hymn-book tucked under one arm. Their scarf is white, their smile practiced, and their eyes go straight to you.

“Wren Ashford,” they say softly, as if greeting you at a service. “I heard you were asking after your mother. The sea keeps excellent records, dear. Better than stone.”

They angle their body to block the cleanest line toward the north lantern-shed without looking like they’re blocking anything at all.

Behind you, from a side tier, a Lanternward caretaker in a dark apron appears and begins drifting parallel to your group—close enough to listen, far enough to claim coincidence—hand already on a ring of keys.

The threat is clear now: the name you drew out has sent an alert through the lantern network. The Choir has arrived to “help” on their terms, and Lanternward attention is closing in just as you try to reach the shed.

I stop just short of the volunteer’s “accidental” block, chin lifting the way I do with tourists who want to pocket sea-glass from graves. “Then you’ll know records can be forged—especially when they’re wet.”
