character_sheet.name: Elowen "Wren" Ashford
character_sheet.background: Wren was raised above Ashford & Daughters Funeral Home on a salt-stung coast, learning early to treat grief with gentleness and to listen to what people won’t say out loud. Her mother vanished when Wren was a teen, leaving behind a few unsettling clues and a family that learned to survive on quiet routines. She now lives in a small apartment near the cemetery she tends, collecting sea-glass charms and keeping her questions carefully folded behind impeccable manners.
character_sheet.profession: Restoration artist and conservation specialist for a quirky historic cemetery
character_sheet.personal_goal: Uncover the truth behind her mother’s long-ago disappearance by following the scattered hints hidden in old funeral home records and cemetery plots—while resisting (or surviving) her growing attachment to the brooding newcomer who makes the graveyard feel unexpectedly alive.

seed_chunks: Salt wind combs the ironwork like fingers through hair, leaving a faint rust-tang on the tongue. The cemetery lies in quilted tiers of leaning slate and white marble, lichens blooming in quiet greens, sea-mist beading on carved names until they shine like wet ink. Lanterns along the path sputter with moth-wing shadows; somewhere a bell buoy moans, answered by the soft, punctual click of Wren’s tools in her pocket. Earth smells of peat and crushed rosemary from offerings left too long. Underfoot, gravel gives a patient crunch—then hush—where grass swallows sound. Even the air feels careful, as if holding its breath around secrets.

Saltmarrow’s upper tiers have never liked strangers, but lately they don’t even like themselves. The lanterns gutter blue as if the flame has learned a different language, and each morning you find your careful restorations subtly undone—names shaved thinner, dates re-cut with a hand steadier than any vandal’s, plot borders nudged a few inches so the dead wake up in the wrong families. The Lanternward Society smiles too quickly when you mention tool marks. Someone has started using your work as an alibi.

Then the brooding newcomer arrives at your apartment door with sea-mist in his hair and a map of Saltmarrow Cemetery that shouldn’t exist: a maintenance overlay showing “ghost paths,” sealed sections, and a set of plot coordinates inked in your mother’s old shorthand—three looping letters you haven’t seen since the night she vanished above Ashford & Daughters. He doesn’t ask if you remember. He asks what you know. As if forgetting was never an option.

Across town, Ashford & Daughters locks its private annex and pretends it’s only “inventory.” Inside, the unsanctioned ledgers you grew up dusting are being moved—quietly, urgently—as if the paper itself has started to accuse. And tonight the Brine-Choir’s Moon-Collecting Vigil will draw half the town to the shore, where buoy-bells will moan and bargains will be sung under respectable hymns. Three fishermen have already washed up with tongues stitched in brine-thread: an old warning, meant for someone who listens.

You are suddenly useful to too many people. The cemetery is being rewritten. Your family’s records are being sealed. And your mother’s trail—once cold—has begun to shine like wet ink.

message_history.content:
Morning, Saltmarrow Cemetery’s upper tier—Lantern Row—where the path narrows between leaning slate and a low iron fence furred with salt. Sea-mist beads on carved names until they look freshly inked. The lanterns are still lit from last night, and each flame sputters an unhealthy blue that makes the gravel look cold.

You kneel beside the Harrowell marker, apron tied, hair pinned back the way you learned above Ashford & Daughters. A soft brush clears lichen from a serifed “E,” and your small tools click in your pocket when you shift your weight. You test the stone with a fingertip, careful as if it were skin, then set a stencil to match the original cut. Patience is part of the job; so is noticing what other people hope you won’t.

The date is wrong.

Yesterday the stone read *1889*. Today it reads *1883*, the new “3” cut too clean to be weather. At the base, fresh grit still sits in the chisel line. You lean closer and find a second problem: the border stones around the Harrowell plot have been nudged inward, just enough that the corner now bites into the neighboring family’s ground. That kind of shift takes time, leverage, and permission—unless someone is doing it before dawn.

Footsteps crunch behind you. When you turn, a man stands just inside the gate, coat damp at the shoulders, dark hair still threaded with mist. He doesn’t carry a tour pamphlet or a wreath. He holds a folded sheet of vellum in one hand and keeps the other near his pocket like he’s used to trouble. “Elowen Ashford,” he says, not asking. He opens the vellum just enough for you to see a maintenance overlay of the cemetery—ghost paths, sealed sections—and three plot coordinates inked in your mother’s looping shorthand.

“I bought this from someone who shouldn’t have it,” he says. “Your name was the only instruction.”

The blue lantern above you gutters hard, as if reacting.

You have a freshly altered grave at your knees, an impossible map in a stranger’s hand, and a town heading toward the Brine-Choir’s vigil tonight. He waits for an answer, and the cemetery stays very still.

Ing Lanterns.location_description: Ing Lanterns are older than the path they pretend to illuminate—each glass is faintly salted from the inside, as if it has wept sea-mist for years. The lanternposts bear tiny, polite chisel-marks (a caretakers’ shorthand) that map which graves are meant to be remembered and which are meant to be merely visited. When the wind turns, the flames lean as if listening, and the shadows they cast occasionally resemble moths with too many wings.

watchers.name: Moth-Counter Hest Finch
watchers.description: Pretends to be tallying moths drawn to the lanterns for a 'Lanternward census,' but is actually watching for anyone lingering at posts with altered chisel-marks. She listens for names spoken twice and notes which tools are carried in pockets.

watchers.name: Brother Sedge of the Brine-Choir
watchers.description: Sits on a low stone like a patient hymn, humming softly to 'steady the flame.' He’s watching for anyone who reacts to buoy-bell calls or mentions drowned names; he reads faces the way sailors read weather.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternwick Warden (a chained flame-sprite)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Inside the third lantern on the left after the rosemary offering-stone, its base etched with a Lanternward seal that looks like a keyhole wearing a halo.
weaknesses: Do not touch the latch; instead, speak a caretaker’s courtesy (a simple apology) and step back
Cover the lantern briefly with a dark cloth to calm the sprite without opening it
Scatter a pinch of salt in a small circle at your feet to keep it from leaping out

fail_conditions.name: Touching the chisel-marks on the lanternpost
fail_conditions.description: The marks are a quiet alarm: skin-oil completes the etched circuit and tells the Lanternward exactly who handled it, even in fog. It’s designed to catch 'helpful' restorers who notice inconsistencies.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The nearest lantern flame flares an attentive blue and throws your shadow long enough to be recognizable. Within minutes, an overly friendly tour-guide drifts close, asking questions that are shaped like compliments but bite like hooks.
escape_conditions: Wipe the post with a rosemary cloth as if performing routine maintenance to smear the signal
Move immediately into the grass-hush where sound is swallowed and line of sight breaks
Redirect attention by asking about a public tour route and walking with purpose

fail_conditions.name: Speaking a drowned name aloud beneath Ing Lanterns
fail_conditions.description: The Brine-Choir uses lantern acoustics as a listening shell; certain names make the glass resonate and carry farther than they should. In mist, the sound can be 'answered' by a buoy-bell that isn’t anywhere nearby.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A bell-note arrives through the fog like a cold fingertip pressed to the ear, and the lanterns sputter in unison as if taking a breath. Someone begins following at a courteous distance—close enough to be sure, far enough to deny it—until you are guided toward the shoreward gate without realizing you’ve turned.
escape_conditions: Switch to writing the name instead of speaking and keep your voice to mundane topics
Step into a cluster of lanterns and hum a steady counter-note to break the resonance
Seek a Lanternward tour group as cover; the Choir avoids open confrontation under civic eyes

secrets.description: One lantern’s glass is etched with a microscopic map of cemetery tiers—only visible when the flame leans sideways—marking a single plot number that does not exist in the public ledger. The number is paired with a tiny symbol used in Ashford & Daughters internal records: a sea-glass charm shape, the kind Wren collects.

Beneath the rosemary offering-stone is a flat, sealed tin meant to look like a maintenance cap. Inside are three moth wings pressed into paper and a sliver of ledger-page with a name carefully scraped away—except for the last two letters, still clinging like a stubborn smile.

Ing Guide.location_description: Ing Guide is a narrow, lantern-sputtering lane-map kiosk and tour placard tucked between two leaning angel statues, where the Lanternward posts “helpful” directions that subtly reroute visitors away from edited plots. Salt mist has glued a film of mica to the signage so it sparkles when breathed on, and the iron guide-rail hums faintly with buoy-bell resonance if you rest a hand on it too long.

watchers.name: Mist-Quill Moth
watchers.description: A pale moth the size of a thumbprint that keeps returning to the same lantern-glass, as if reading the tour placard. It drifts close when names are spoken aloud, then flutters away toward the Lanternward office to be “translated” by whoever knows how to listen.

watchers.name: Sister Celandine-of-the-Tide
watchers.description: A cheerful tide-singer in a damp wool cloak who pretends to be lost and asks for directions with too-perfect politeness. She watches reflections more than faces—puddles, polished marble, lantern-glass—listening for the shape of a secret in someone’s pause.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternward Whisper-Lock beneath the Ing Guide rail
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Bolted under the iron guide-rail where visitors lean to read the map; it’s disguised as a decorative bracket shaped like a curled fern.
weaknesses: Keep hands off the rail while speaking sensitive words
Speak only in questions (it listens for declarative intent)
Wrap the bracket in rosemary or salt-damp cloth to mute its resonance briefly

fail_conditions.name: Reading the Ing Guide placard aloud in full
fail_conditions.description: The placard is inked with a subtle call-and-response cadence; reciting it activates a buoy-bell mimic that flags the speaker as a compliant tour-goer—and a useful target for rerouting or recruitment.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The lanterns along the path sputter in sequence, as if applauding, and the air grows politely attentive. Within minutes, a Lanternward guide arrives with impeccable timing to “assist,” gently steering the conversation away from names that matter and noting Wren’s interest for the ledgers.
escape_conditions: Interrupt the recitation with a cough and change the wording mid-line
Step off the gravel onto grass to break the cadence
Ask for a different map copy instead of continuing

fail_conditions.name: Mentioning Wren’s mother by name within arm’s reach of the guide-rail
fail_conditions.description: The ironwork is tuned to carry certain names like a wire carries a storm; the Whisper-Lock treats them as keys and sends a quiet alert through the cemetery’s lantern network.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A thin, bell-buoy moan threads through the mist, and the nearest lanterns dim as though listening harder. A Brine-Choir “volunteer” arrives with a sympathetic hymn and an offer of help that feels like a hook; shortly after, a Lanternward caretaker begins hovering near the relevant tiers, ready to intercept any search.
escape_conditions: Move away from ironwork and speak into open air (no metal nearby)
Use a nickname or omit the name entirely
Create a harmless distraction (drop tools, ask about tour times) to muddy the alert’s focus

secrets.description: Behind the Ing Guide placard, a second layer of paper has been pasted over the original map. If peeled back carefully, the older print shows a now-“nonexistent” section labeled in tiny type as the Siltward Tier, with three plots marked by faint sea-glass green circles—one bearing an Ashford initial that does not match any public ledger.

A hollow in the stone base of the guide-post hides a curled strip of funeral-home receipt paper, salt-stiff and smelling of rosemary. It lists an item returned from the shore—“brass buoy key, teeth-marked”—and a date that aligns with the first week of Wren’s mother’s disappearance, stamped with Ashford & Daughters’ private annex seal.

Gether.location_description: Beneath Saltmarrow’s lantern-path, the gravel is newer than it pretends—freshly scattered to hide a narrow drag-mark that leads toward the oldest tier. Several headstones here have hairline seams, as if their names were peeled off and re-set like careful wallpaper; the lichen grows in tidy, unnatural borders around the altered letters. A buoy-bell’s moan drifts in on the mist at intervals that feel counted, not coastal.

watchers.name: Moth-Count Lysa (Lanternward Lamp-Tender)
watchers.description: She appears to be trimming wicks and shooing moths from lantern glass, but she is actually counting footfalls and listening for names said aloud—especially Ashford and any ‘missing’ ones. She watches reflections more than faces, using the lantern panes to track where Wren’s gaze lingers.

watchers.name: Brother Sedge of the Brine-Choir
watchers.description: He stands near a sailor’s stone as if praying, humming under his breath to ‘steady the dead,’ while his fingers tap a rhythm that matches the buoy-bell out at sea. He’s listening for mentions of bargains, bells, or drowned bodies, and watching for anyone who pockets sea-glass charms or touches offerings.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternward “Wick-Warden” Sconce (a disguised ward-lantern)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Third lantern on the left past the rosemary offerings, its ironwork is braided like a crown; a thin chalk-salt sigil is scratched under the mounting bracket.
weaknesses: Do not touch the mounting bracket or disturb the chalk-salt sigil
Approach with hands visible and speak only of ‘maintenance’ or ‘cleaning’
A pinch of rosemary rubbed on the fingertips dulls the lantern’s notice for a few minutes

fail_conditions.name: Disturbing an edited headstone seam
fail_conditions.description: Some stones have been re-faced; the seams are baited with a quiet ward that treats curiosity like vandalism. It’s meant to summon Lanternward attention fast and make the guilty feel clumsy enough to leave fingerprints.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air turns suddenly metallic-sweet, and the nearest lantern flares with moth-shadow shapes that spiral toward the offender’s hands. A thin soot-mark blooms on the fingers like a glove, impossible to hide in lanternlight, while a distant bell answers as if acknowledging a report.
escape_conditions: Stop immediately and place both palms flat on your own coat to avoid leaving marks on stone
Rub fingers with crushed rosemary offerings to break the soot-glove’s contrast
Move into thicker grass where sound is swallowed and wait for the lantern flare to settle

fail_conditions.name: Speaking a concealed name at the wrong plot
fail_conditions.description: Certain plots are tuned to ‘missing’ names; saying one aloud is like knocking on a locked door that still remembers how to open. The Brine-Choir and Lanternward both use this to locate nosy tongues.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The mist tightens, and the buoy-bell’s moan shifts into a nearer, more personal note—like someone humming directly behind your ear. A cold wetness beads on your lips as if you’ve swallowed sea-air, and for a moment the carved letters on nearby stones rearrange themselves into listening mouths.
escape_conditions: Immediately switch to a harmless cover topic (tour routes, lantern oil, restoration methods) and physically step off the plot’s border stones
Hum a steady, simple tune to ‘overwrite’ the listening cadence until the bell pattern breaks
Place a small sea-glass charm on an offering spot as a decoy ‘payment’ and leave without looking back

secrets.description: Under a rosemary offering jar, a flat slate chip has been wedged like a shim; on its underside is a tiny penciled map of the cemetery tiers with one plot circled and annotated: ‘ANNEX ENTRY—NOT IN LEDGER.’ The handwriting resembles a funeral-home clerk’s neat hand, but the last stroke trembles as if written in a hurry.

A ‘restored’ marble angel has a hairline crack filled with pale salt-resin; pressed into the filler is a single dark hair and a pinprick of blue-green sea-glass dust. The resin smells faintly of the Mourning House’s embalming soap—suggesting the statue was repaired there, not on-site, and recently.

Ing Boots.location_description: Ing Boots is a narrow, soot-sweet cobbler’s shop tucked between fogged storefronts, where boot trees stand like polite wooden skeletons in the window. The public floor smells of beeswax and salt-damp leather; behind the counter, a curtained workroom hides a ledger niche and a bell-pull that doesn’t ring here so much as “answers” elsewhere. The shop’s floorboards are subtly numbered in chalk under the rugs—an old tour-route code used by caretakers who prefer errands that don’t become questions.

watchers.name: Orin Pike (the 'measuring lad')
watchers.description: A quiet assistant who offers to size feet and fetch laces, but mostly watches hands: which pockets they reach for, which names make their voice hitch. He listens for mentions of plots, edits, and buoy-bells, then steps out to 'take out scraps' when he has something worth passing along.

watchers.name: Sister Muir-in-Mittens
watchers.description: A Brine-Choir singer disguised as a customer with damp hems and too-bright eyes, pretending to fuss over waterproofing. She watches for grief-softened faces and anyone asking after old boots, sailors, or missing women, then hums a low note into the shop’s speaking-tube as if clearing her throat.

hidden_guards.name: The Wax-Lace Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Coiled inside a tin of boot-wax beneath the counter; it unspools into a thin, glossy cord that can knot around wrists or ankles.
weaknesses: Offer a coin or button as 'payment' before touching anything under the counter
A drop of saltwater or brine makes the wax slacken and lose its grip
Heat from a lantern held close softens it into harmless shine

fail_conditions.name: Pulling the wrong bell-pull
fail_conditions.description: The bell-pull behind the curtain is not for the shop; it is a signal line that routes through old coastal wiring and answers to the Brine-Choir’s buoy network. Touching it with the wrong intent marks you as a caller, and callers are expected to pay in secrets.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A distant buoy-bell moans in reply, and the shop’s air briefly tastes like low tide. Within minutes, a 'customer' arrives who knows one private detail they shouldn’t, and presses for another—politely, firmly, as if completing a transaction. Refusing escalates into quiet coercion: lost items, misdirected records, and footsteps that always seem to follow.
escape_conditions: Immediately apologize aloud and state a mundane reason ("I thought it was for the back room") while offering a small charm or coin as a 'misdial fee'
Cut the connection by tying the pull-cord into a simple sailor’s knot and sprinkling it with salt
Leave the premises and avoid mentioning buoy-bells for the rest of the day

fail_conditions.name: Asking for the 'Ing' pair by name
fail_conditions.description: There is a code phrase used by Lanternward couriers to request altered-tour supplies and ledger paste. Saying it in the open flags you as either a courier—or a spy—and the shop’s watchers respond accordingly.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: Orin’s friendliness goes lacquer-still, and he excuses himself to the back with your size written too neatly on a slip. The next time you visit the cemetery, a lantern-lighter happens to be in every aisle you choose, and someone has already checked out the ledger you came for. The town remains polite, but doors begin to close a beat early.
escape_conditions: Immediately pivot to a harmless explanation ("I meant the brand stamp") and buy something small
Ask a sincere, mundane cobbler question to reframe the conversation
Leave before Orin returns and vary your route home

secrets.description: Under the second rug by the boot trees, faint chalk numerals match a Lanternward tour-route code; one number is overwritten with a newer hand, pointing to a cemetery tier that no longer appears on public maps.

A thin strip of leather tucked into the seam of a display boot contains a pressed sea-glass sliver and a funeral-home inventory tag stamped 'A&D Annex—Return Unlogged.' The handwriting on the tag matches the style used in old Ashford ledgers from the year Wren’s mother vanished.

Ward The Yard.location_description: Ward The Yard is the Lanternward Society’s busiest tier: a “public” stretch of path where lanterns are kept bright and jokes are kept gentle. Beneath the whimsy—tour placards with rhyming epitaphs, rosemary tied in tidy bows—there are quiet seams: gravel that crunches too evenly, headstones that sit a fraction too new, and a salt-sweet draft that seems to exhale from certain plots as if the earth is practicing speech.

watchers.name: Moth-Lantern Warden (Pip Sallow)
watchers.description: A lantern-lighter with ink-stained fingertips who pretends to fuss over sputtering wicks, watching reflections in the lantern glass to see who lingers by altered stones. They’re looking for anyone who reads names aloud or sketches plot maps from memory.

watchers.name: Buoy-Bell Listener (Sister Nacre)
watchers.description: A Brine-Choir tide-singer posing as a mourner, humming softly near the ironwork to ‘hear’ the bell buoy’s reply. She watches for anyone handling sea-glass charms or speaking of drownings, and listens for names that taste like salt on the air.

hidden_guards.name: The Lichen-Script Ward
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Threaded through the green lichen on three adjacent leaning slates near the rosemary offerings; the script only aligns when viewed from the lantern path’s third post.
weaknesses: Approach from the grass where sound is swallowed; the ward listens for crunching gravel
Use a soft brush and distilled water only—abrasion wakes it
Cover the stone briefly with a cloth to break lanternlight; the ward ‘reads’ illumination

hidden_guards.name: Gravel-Quiet Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Under the neatest stretch of gravel between the tour placard and the iron gate, coiled around a buried chain that tugs when footsteps hesitate.
weaknesses: Walk with steady, unhurried steps; it reacts to stuttered pacing and sudden stops
Scatter crushed rosemary—its attention drifts to the scent
Keep to the grass verge; it cannot travel where the ground won’t ‘answer’ with crunch

fail_conditions.name: Reading the Wrong Name Aloud
fail_conditions.description: Some names here were edited out of ledgers but not fully erased from the ground. Speaking one aloud invites the cemetery to ‘correct’ the record, and the correction is not gentle.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The lanterns gutter as if embarrassed, and the air thickens with rust-tang. Letters on nearby stones bead with sea-mist and begin to rearrange, making a new name that points accusingly toward the speaker. A watcher takes note, and the path seems to subtly reroute Wren back toward the public tour line.
escape_conditions: Apologize softly and offer rosemary at the base of the nearest slate
Switch to silent reading and keep hands visible
Step onto the grass where sound is swallowed and wait for the lanterns to steady

fail_conditions.name: Attempting to Lift a Recently ‘Settled’ Stone
fail_conditions.description: Several markers are decoys set over empty peat pockets; moving them triggers a quiet alarm through ironwork and buoy-bell resonance, drawing both civic and coastal attention.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The gravel hushes unnaturally, and a low moan answers from the distant buoy as if the sea has been informed. The iron fence vibrates with a fingernail-on-glass tremor, and a thin line of wet ink appears on Wren’s fingertips as though the cemetery has signed her name. Within minutes, a lantern-lighter ‘happens’ to arrive, and a tide-singer’s hymn drifts closer than it should.
escape_conditions: Release the stone immediately and smooth the gravel to erase tool marks
Blame a restoration inspection and produce legitimate tools/cloths to appear routine
Leave a sea-glass charm as a decoy offering and depart along the grass edge, not the main path

secrets.description: Behind a whimsical tour placard (painted with a smiling skull and a pun about ‘resting faces’), a second set of plot coordinates is etched into the iron bracket in tiny, precise numerals—too careful to be a prank. The coordinates match an unlisted row where the ground smells of crushed rosemary even when none is present.

One slate bears a lichen bloom shaped like a wren in flight; when viewed at an angle, the ‘bird’ aligns with a hairline seam in the stone. Pressing there doesn’t open anything—yet—but it makes the lantern nearest the path sputter in a pattern like Morse, spelling out a single word: ANNEX.

Door Seam.location_description: At the door seam—where chapel oak meets salt-swollen frame—the paint has split into a hairline smile. The gap tastes faintly of brine and old varnish, and a thin thread of sea-mist keeps trying to slip indoors as if it has an appointment.

watchers.name: Lampwick Lenore
watchers.description: A lantern-lighter who pretends to fuss with a sputtering wick nearby, watching reflections in the glass rather than looking directly. She’s listening for names spoken too carefully and for anyone who lingers at the seam as if expecting it to answer back.

hidden_guards.name: The Seam-Moth Ward
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Nested in the door jamb’s hollow, disguised as a peppering of moth-wing shadows where the lanternlight stutters.
weaknesses: Approach with steady, quiet breath; sudden exhalations stir it
Offer a pinch of crushed rosemary at the threshold to lull it
Use a soft brush and speak politely (it responds to gentleness and slows)

fail_conditions.name: Forcing the seam
fail_conditions.description: The wood is salt-swollen and warded; brute pressure makes the jamb complain in a voice that carries. The cemetery’s quiet is not empty—it repeats what it hears to the wrong listeners.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The seam shivers and releases a papery flutter as the ward wakes, and the lantern nearby flares bright as an accusation. A watcher takes note, and the door’s gap tightens as if offended, making further entry harder and noisier.
escape_conditions: Stop immediately and switch to careful restoration tools
Soothe the threshold with rosemary or a sea-glass charm placed flat to the seam
Redirect attention by engaging the lantern-lighter with harmless tour talk

fail_conditions.name: Speaking the wrong name at the threshold
fail_conditions.description: Names have weight here; the seam is a listening line between sanctioned history and what was edited out. Certain names act like a bell-buoy—summoning interest from factions that prefer silence.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air turns careful-er, and the lantern’s moth-shadows arrange themselves into a brief, unmistakable sigil before dissolving. Within the hour, someone will come to "assist"—politely—by removing access, changing schedules, or escorting Wren away from the door under the pretense of safety.
escape_conditions: Mask the conversation with mundane cemetery maintenance terms
Use coded euphemisms (e.g., 'the extra book', 'the wet choir')
Leave the seam and relocate to a noisier path where words don’t carry

secrets.description: A thin strip of paper has been tucked into the seam and varnished over—an index-tab torn from a funeral ledger, stamped with a tiny lantern icon and a handwritten tide-time that doesn’t match any local chart.

Under the lowest hinge, a rust-bloom forms a deliberate shape: a small brine-bell motif scratched into the metal, with three pinprick holes nearby that can whistle when the wind hits—an improvised signal point for meetings.

Jory’s For A Second.location_description: Jory’s For A Second looks like a cheerful secondhand shop wedged between salt-stained brick, but its back room is a hush-pocket where sound dulls as if wrapped in velvet. The air tastes faintly of clove, lamp oil, and sea-rust; mirrors hang where they shouldn’t, reflecting angles the room doesn’t have. A buoy-bell chime sometimes arrives from nowhere, and the shop’s little clock occasionally ticks backward for one breath, as if reconsidering.

watchers.name: Mira Quell (the ‘button lady’)
watchers.description: She pretends to sort jars of mismatched buttons near the counter while tracking who asks after names, plots, or old records. She listens for grief spoken too neatly and watches hands for cemetery calluses and ink-stains from ledgers.

watchers.name: Brother Sedge (tide-singer in plain clothes)
watchers.description: He lingers by the cracked mirror stand, humming under his breath to ‘hear’ what the glass repeats. He’s looking for anyone chasing drowned secrets—especially mentions of buoy-bells, coastal bargains, or a woman who didn’t stay gone properly.

hidden_guards.name: The Receipt-Wasp Ward
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Inside the brass receipt-printer under the counter; the paper roll is a coiled nest of thin, ink-scented wings.
weaknesses: Pay properly (even a token coin) before handling protected items
Offer a written apology on any scrap of paper and leave it under the printer
Dampen the receipt roll with a single drop of saltwater to lull the ward

hidden_guards.name: The Umbrella Stand Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: A tall umbrella stand by the door packed with canes and parasols; one is not wood but jointed bone lacquered black.
weaknesses: Approach openly and ask permission to browse ‘weathered goods’ (polite phrasing disarms it)
Keep both hands visible; it reacts to concealed tools
A sprig of rosemary placed at its base makes it go still for a few minutes

fail_conditions.name: Mentioning erased burials too plainly
fail_conditions.description: Jory’s walls are sympathetic; certain words make the shop ‘remember’ old edits and alert the people who did the editing. Speaking the right names here is like tapping a lantern-glass in a dark stairwell.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A thin draft slides through the shop, snuffing the warmest lamp and making the mirrors briefly show a lantern-lit cemetery path instead of the room. Within the hour, a Lanternward ‘tour volunteer’ arrives to browse too closely and to note faces, questions, and exits.
escape_conditions: Shift the topic into harmless genealogy or ‘local history’ tour chatter
Leave immediately and take two unnecessary turns before heading anywhere important
Buy a small item and request it wrapped—paperwork noise breaks the shop’s ‘listening’

fail_conditions.name: Asking for the back-room ledger without the right courtesy
fail_conditions.description: The shop’s threshold etiquette is a real boundary; skipping it is treated as trespass by older, stranger rules. The whimsical veneer turns sharp when manners are neglected.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The door-curtain to the back room stiffens like wet sailcloth turned to ice, and the Umbrella Stand Sentinel clacks forward on borrowed joints. At the same time, a buoy-bell note rings from the wrong direction, as if someone has been signaled. The shop becomes a trap of polite silence: no one shouts, but no one lets you go easily.
escape_conditions: Apologize aloud using the phrase ‘for a second’ and step back from the curtain
Offer a small trade (sea-glass, a charm, or a personal trinket) as ‘proper asking’
Exit with empty hands and do not look into any mirror until outside

secrets.description: Behind a framed advertisement for ‘Lantern Oil & Comforts’ is a thin slit in the wall holding a folded, salt-crisp receipt dated the week Wren’s mother vanished. The item line reads only: “ONE SECOND, KEPT.” and the signature is a looping hand that matches Ashford & Daughters intake forms.

The cracked mirror stand is backed with a hidden ribbon of paper—an index strip torn from a cemetery plot book—listing three names that have been overwritten with lantern-soot. If held near a flame, the soot thins and reveals the original ink: one is a coastal alias tied to the Brine-Choir’s bell-signals.

Ed On The Seam I.location_description: Ed On The Seam I is a narrow, terraced seam between the upper and lower cemetery tiers where the gravel path turns into a stitched ribbon of grass and slate. The lantern here burns with a polite, intermittent cough, and the iron fence hums faintly in the salt wind as if remembering hymns. Someone has recently re-inked a few carved names with a too-fresh black that beads like wet eyes, and the rosemary offerings smell bruised, as though handled in a hurry.

watchers.name: Lanternward Ledger-Mender ("Mr. Quill")
watchers.description: A tour guide who never quite leads a tour—he lingers near the seam with a clipboard, pretending to count lantern wicks while listening for questions about missing names. He watches hands more than faces, looking for anyone carrying tools, charcoal rubbings, or old record pages.

watchers.name: Brine-Choir Bell-Listener
watchers.description: A harmless-seeming volunteer with a satchel of sea-glass charms who pauses whenever the buoy moans, as if taking the tide’s pulse. They watch for anyone speaking names into the wind or touching ironwork too deliberately, and they memorize which graves draw grief like moths to light.

hidden_guards.name: The Stitch-Lantern’s Moth-Sentinels
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Inside the sputtering lantern at the seam’s bend; the moth-wing shadows are not shadows at all but tiny, ink-dark moths nesting in the glass.
weaknesses: Approach with a covered light and speak softly; they settle if offered a pinch of crushed rosemary
Avoid sudden movement or metal-on-glass sounds
Step back into the grass where sound is swallowed and wait for the lantern to calm

fail_conditions.name: Rubbing or copying an edited headstone in plain view
fail_conditions.description: At the seam, the Lanternward’s edits are freshest and most guarded; making a rubbing here is treated like theft of civic history. The wind carries charcoal-scratch sounds farther than it should, and the lantern’s sputter draws eyes to any fussing hands.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A polite interruption becomes a practiced containment: the watcher asks for permits, then subtly blocks the path downhill with a tour group that wasn’t there a moment ago. If pressed, they escort Wren toward the Society’s office to “verify records,” buying time to warn others and to remove the stone’s fresh ink before she can compare it.
escape_conditions: Switch to a restoration pretext (cleaning lichen, checking mortar) and put materials away
Move into the sound-swallowing grass and wait until the watcher is drawn off by the buoy bell
Offer to volunteer for a tour in exchange for leaving immediately

fail_conditions.name: Speaking a vanished name into the ironwork
fail_conditions.description: The seam’s fence is a listening instrument in salt wind; certain names catch on it like burrs and ring down the line. The Brine-Choir uses buoy-bells to answer such rings, and they do not like uninvited invocations.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air tightens as if the cemetery holds its breath; the lantern flame leans toward the speaker, and the buoy moan answers too quickly, too close. A Brine-Choir listener appears with a gentle smile and an offer of “blessing,” but the questions that follow feel like hooks dressed as kindness, and refusal turns the path subtly wrong—steps leading back to the same stone again and again.
escape_conditions: Change the subject to a neutral grave blessing and physically step away from ironwork
Use Wren’s tools to create a small, mundane ritual (tidy offerings, straighten a marker) to ground the space
Follow the rosemary scent toward the upper tier until the buoy sound fades

secrets.description: Behind the seam’s lantern post, a thin brass plaque has been screwed over an older dedication. Salt has loosened one corner; beneath it is a tiny stamped sigil used by Ashford & Daughters to mark “unsanctioned transfers,” and a date that matches the week Wren’s mother vanished.

One slate marker nearby bears lichen arranged like accidental lace, but the pattern is too tidy: it hides a second set of initials cut shallowly into the stone—initials that do not match the name above. The shallow cuts are recent, as if someone re-remembered the dead and tried to tuck the truth back under green velvet.

inventory: Folded strip of thin clean linen
Rusted tin with a few bent nails

message_history.content:
Morning, Saltmarrow Cemetery’s upper tier—Lantern Row—where the path narrows between leaning slate and a low iron fence furred with salt. Sea-mist beads on carved names until they look freshly inked. The lanterns are still lit from last night, and each flame sputters an unhealthy blue that makes the gravel look cold.

You kneel beside the Harrowell marker, apron tied, hair pinned back the way you learned above Ashford & Daughters. A soft brush clears lichen from a serifed “E,” and your small tools click in your pocket when you shift your weight. You test the stone with a fingertip, careful as if it were skin, then set a stencil to match the original cut. Patience is part of the job; so is noticing what other people hope you won’t.

The date is wrong.

Yesterday the stone read *1889*. Today it reads *1883*, the new “3” cut too clean to be weather. At the base, fresh grit still sits in the chisel line. You lean closer and find a second problem: the border stones around the Harrowell plot have been nudged inward, just enough that the corner now bites into the neighboring family’s ground. That kind of shift takes time, leverage, and permission—unless someone is doing it before dawn.

Footsteps crunch behind you. When you turn, a man stands just inside the gate, coat damp at the shoulders, dark hair still threaded with mist. He doesn’t carry a tour pamphlet or a wreath. He holds a folded sheet of vellum in one hand and keeps the other near his pocket like he’s used to trouble. “Elowen Ashford,” he says, not asking. He opens the vellum just enough for you to see a maintenance overlay of the cemetery—ghost paths, sealed sections—and three plot coordinates inked in your mother’s looping shorthand.

“I bought this from someone who shouldn’t have it,” he says. “Your name was the only instruction.”

The blue lantern above you gutters hard, as if reacting.

You have a freshly altered grave at your knees, an impossible map in a stranger’s hand, and a town heading toward the Brine-Choir’s vigil tonight. He waits for an answer, and the cemetery stays very still.

I rise slowly, wiping my fingers on my apron, and step just close enough to see the ink clearly. “That *is* my mother’s hand,” I say, voice careful. “Who sold it to you—and why were they carrying cemetery overlays in the first place?”

You step in, close enough that the vellum’s surface catches the lanternlight. The ink is old-black, not the newer soot-brown the Society uses—your mother’s habit of tightening the downstrokes is there, unmistakable. The stranger doesn’t pull it away, but his grip firms at the corners.

He answers your questions in the wrong order.

“Because the cemetery is being run like a ledger,” he says, low. “And ledgers have overlays.”

Then: “A lantern-lighter sold it to me. Not one of the public-facing guides—one of the ones who carries keys.” His eyes flick past your shoulder, toward the path behind you, as if expecting someone to be listening. “He didn’t give a name. He had a thumb missing to the first knuckle and smelled like lamp-oil and brine. He said the map was ‘hot’ and that if I wanted the rest of it, I should find you before the Choir started singing tonight.”

As he speaks, a faint click comes from the iron fence to your left—metal on metal, like a latch being tested. You look: nothing obvious moves, but the chain on the side gate is hanging differently than you remember, the padlock turned outward instead of inward.

The blue lantern above you sputters again. In that brief stutter, you catch it: a second set of footprints in the damp gravel off the main path—too narrow for the caretaker’s boots you know, toes pointed toward you and the stranger, then scuffed as if someone backed away into the grass.

The man folds the vellum once, not hiding it fully but making it easier to snatch. “If you want to ask me what I’m doing in Saltmarrow,” he adds, “do it somewhere that isn’t lit like a signal.”

Another sound—soft, deliberate—comes from the row of headstones behind the Harrowell plot: the scrape of grit under a shoe sole. Whoever it is, they’re close enough now that they’re choosing to be heard.

I catch his sleeve and tug him toward the Harrowell mausoleum’s shadow, keeping my voice even. “Fold it—now. And stay close.” Then, louder, I call into the stones behind us: “Cemetery’s closed. If you’ve got business, say it plainly—before I start shouting for the caretaker.”

Your fingers close on his sleeve—wool damp and cold—and you pull him into the Harrowell mausoleum’s lee. The stone there holds the night’s chill; the blue lanternlight doesn’t reach cleanly, and the mist seems to hesitate at the carved angels over the door.

He obeys immediately. The vellum folds in practiced, quick creases and disappears into the inner pocket of his coat. He shifts so his body blocks the mausoleum door seam, eyes fixed on the row of headstones you called out to.

Your voice carries. “Cemetery’s closed…”

For a beat, nothing answers—only the buoy-bell’s distant moan and the lantern’s wet sputter.

Then someone steps into view between two slates: a Lanternward man in a dark oilskin, lantern-hook belt at his waist. His left hand is wrapped in stained cloth, thumb stump blunt beneath it. He holds a long-handled lantern snuffer like a walking stick, and his face is drawn tight with sleeplessness.

He stops where the path widens, keeping a respectful distance that still feels like a boundary. “No need to shout, Miss Ashford,” he says, voice mild and rehearsed. “Caretaker sent me to check the blue lamps. Folks have been… fretting.”

Behind him, a second figure doesn’t step out—only a suggestion of movement in the grass line to his right, where the mist thickens. You hear a quiet exhale and the faint clink of something metal being adjusted, like a buckle or a keyring.

The Lanternward man’s gaze flicks to the Harrowell stone at your knees—wrong date, nudged borders—and then to the stranger’s coat pocket, too quickly to be accidental. “You’ve got company,” he notes, as if it’s casual. “Not a tour day.”

The stranger beside you goes still. His hand stays visible, empty, but his posture changes—ready.

The Lanternward man lifts his snuffer a few inches, not threatening exactly, but making it clear he can close lanterns—make dark—fast. “If you’ve found something you shouldn’t,” he says, softer now, “best you hand it over. The Society doesn’t like… misunderstandings. Especially before a vigil.”

He doesn’t advance. He waits, and the hidden presence in the grass waits with him.

I let my shoulders soften into a tired little sigh, like he’s interrupted nothing more dangerous than moss removal. “The caretaker didn’t mention you—what’s your name?” I ask, then take a small step sideways so my back is to the mausoleum and my eyes can keep the grass line in view. “And if the Society wants something from me, they can ask me in daylight, in the office, with proper records—so unless you’re here to explain why the Harrowell date changed overnight, you can put that snuffer down.”

Your tired sigh lands the way you intend: ordinary, put-upon. You shift sideways until your shoulder touches the mausoleum’s cold stone, giving you a clean angle on the grass line.

The Lanternward man’s expression tightens at the question. For a moment he looks like he might ignore it—then he answers, as if forced by habit into politeness.

“Pell,” he says. “Jory Pell.”

He does not lower the snuffer. Instead, he plants its ferrule on the gravel and leans on it, casual as a cane. “Daylight, office, proper records,” he repeats, tasting the words. “That’s the trouble with you Ashfords. You think paper keeps you safe.”

At the mention of the Harrowell date, his eyes cut to the stone again. He doesn’t deny it changed. That silence is its own admission.

From the grass line to Pell’s right, the hidden figure finally commits: a woman steps half out of the mist, not Lanternward-uniformed—plain dark dress, hair pinned tight, a ring of keys on a chain at her waist. She doesn’t look at you first; she looks at the stranger, then at Pell, and gives the smallest nod, like confirming a description.

Pell speaks again, voice still mild, but the edges are sharper. “You can keep your voice down and we can all walk away tidy. Or you can shout for a caretaker who isn’t on this tier, and my friend here—Mara—will make sure your shouting doesn’t carry.”

Mara’s hand comes up. Not a weapon—an oiled cloth and a small glass bottle. The smell hits even from a few paces: sharp, sweet, medicinal. Ether or something like it.

The threat is clear now: they’re not here to argue policy. They’re here to take the map and, if necessary, quiet you.

Pell shifts his weight forward one step, closing distance. “Last chance,” he says, eyes on the stranger’s coat pocket. “Hand it over.”

The blue lantern above you gutters hard, and for a second the path is darker—enough for Mara to angle her body as if preparing to rush from the grass.

I lift my hands slowly, palms out. “All right—easy,” I say, then glance up at the sputtering blue lantern. “If you’re Lanternward, prove it: snuff that one. It’s spooking the whole tier.”  
As Pell’s attention flicks upward, I hook my foot behind the Harrowell border stone and kick gravel hard into the path between us, then grab the stranger’s sleeve again and hiss, “Run—down Lantern Row, don’t look back,” and I shout at the top of my lungs, “CARETAKER—UPPER TIER! HELP!”

Pell’s eyes do flick up at the blue lantern—just a reflex, the way anyone who lives by flame can’t help but check a gutter.

He does not snuff it.

But that half-beat is enough.

Your foot hooks the Harrowell border stone and you kick. Gravel sprays across the path in a harsh hiss, pelting Pell’s oilskin and skittering under his boots. His next step slips; he catches himself with the snuffer’s ferrule, metal scraping stone.

You seize the stranger’s sleeve and shove him into motion. He doesn’t argue—he bolts, coat tails snapping, heading down Lantern Row exactly as you ordered.

Mara moves immediately. She lunges after him, keys clinking, bottle and cloth up like she’s done this before. Pell barks, “Not the girl—get the map!” and surges forward toward you instead, trying to cut you off from following.

You shout—full-throated, tearing sound that bounces off slate and marble: “CARETAKER—UPPER TIER! HELP!”

The tier answers with movement, not a voice. From farther downslope, a lantern flares brighter—someone has heard, or at least seen the commotion. But it’s not close.

Pell closes the distance fast. He swings the snuffer not at your head, but low, aiming to hook your ankle or knock your legs out from under you. You jerk back against the mausoleum stone; the snuffer’s rim clips your shin with a hard, numbing smack.

Pain blossoms hot and immediate. Your leg holds, but it stings and your balance wobbles.

Mara is already several strides after the stranger—then she hesitates as your shout carries. She glances back once, calculating, and hisses something to Pell you don’t catch.

Pell’s face changes—less polite, more urgent. “You’ve made it messy,” he snaps, and reaches with his free hand for your wrist, trying to pin you to the mausoleum wall and keep you from giving chase or screaming again.

Down Lantern Row, the stranger is a dark shape running through blue-guttering pools of light—Mara gaining on him in the mist, cloth raised.

**Threat, clear:** Pell is trying to restrain you physically; Mara is attempting to catch the stranger and use the drugged cloth on him to take the map.

I drive my elbow back into Pell’s ribs and twist my wrist hard, then snatch the stiff edge of my apron up over my nose and mouth as I scream again, “HELP—LANTERN ROW!”  
Stumbling on my sore shin, I grab my water tin and fling it down the path toward Mara, shouting, “HEY—MARA! PUT IT DOWN!”

Your elbow drives back into Pell’s ribs with a dull, satisfying thud. He grunts—air knocked out—and his grip loosens just enough for you to wrench your wrist free. You twist hard; his fingers scrape your skin and then slip off.

You yank your apron up over your nose and mouth and scream again, louder, ragged with pain in your shin: “HELP—LANTERN ROW!”

This time you get an answer: a man’s voice, distant but real, calling, “Oi! Up there!” Footsteps start pounding uphill, still far—at least half a tier down.

Pell recovers fast. His face goes mean with embarrassment. “Shut—up,” he spits, and swings the snuffer again, higher now, aiming to clip your shoulder and drive you back into the mausoleum’s shadow. The rim catches your upper arm—hard enough to make your fingers go numb for a second, not enough to drop you.

You fumble for your water tin—small, dented, half-full—and fling it down the path toward Mara.

It sails low and fast, then bounces off a headstone base with a loud *clang* and skitters into the gravel, spraying water in a brief arc. The noise makes Mara flinch and glance back.

Your shout—“HEY—MARA! PUT IT DOWN!”—lands. Mara’s jaw tightens; she doesn’t put anything down. She changes tactics.

She stops chasing straight at the stranger and instead cuts across the grass to intercept him where Lantern Row narrows between two leaning stones. Keys flash at her waist as she moves. The cloth stays raised, bottle in her other hand.

The stranger is still running, but he’s about to hit that pinch-point in the path—Mara is positioning to step into him from the side and clamp the cloth over his face.

Behind you, Pell steps in again, closer than before. He reaches not for your wrist this time, but for the apron at your face—trying to yank it down and force you to breathe whatever Mara has. His breath smells of lamp-oil and salt.

**Immediate threats:**
- Pell is within arm’s reach and trying to control your breathing/face covering.
- Mara is about to intercept the stranger at a narrow section of Lantern Row and use the drugged cloth.

I clamp the apron tight with one hand and bite Pell’s reaching fingers as hard as I can, then knee him—clumsy but vicious—right where it’ll count. “DON’T TOUCH ME,” I snarl through the cloth, and I scream again, “LANTERN ROW—SHE’S GOT ETHER!”  
Then I lunge toward the path and shout after the stranger, “LEFT—OFF THE ROW, THROUGH THE YEW BREAK!”

You clamp the apron to your face and when Pell’s hand claws for it, you catch two of his fingers between your teeth. You bite down hard.

He yelps—high and involuntary—and jerks back, shaking his hand as blood beads along the knuckles. Before he can reset, your knee comes up.

It’s not graceful, but it lands. Pell folds with a choked noise, the snuffer clattering against the mausoleum stone. He staggers sideways, one hand cupped between his legs, the other held up and bleeding, eyes watering with rage.

“DON’T TOUCH ME,” you snarl through the cloth.

You scream again, voice tearing: “LANTERN ROW—SHE’S GOT ETHER!”

That word changes the air. Down the slope, the running footsteps you heard speed up—two sets now—and someone shouts back, “ETHER? WHO—?”

Mara hears it too. She’s at the pinch-point just as the stranger reaches it. She darts in from the side, cloth snapping up toward his face.

But your shout and your next call hit in the same instant: “LEFT—OFF THE ROW, THROUGH THE YEW BREAK!”

The stranger commits on instinct. He veers left, shoulder-checking into the yew’s dark gap instead of pushing through the narrow stones. Mara’s cloth brushes his cheek—not a full seal—and he stumbles into the branches, coughing, but he’s still moving.

Mara swears, sharp and low, and plunges after him. The yew boughs whip and scrape; her keys jangle wildly, giving away her line.

Behind you, Pell isn’t finished. He straightens with a hiss, face blotched with pain and humiliation. He snatches up the snuffer again and—rather than swing—he lunges to tackle, trying to drive you to the ground and stop you from shouting any more.

You have a heartbeat of warning: his boots scrape on gravel, shoulders dropping as he comes in.

Down Lantern Row, lanternlight flares—two figures cresting the rise, still a short run away. They’re close enough now that Pell glances toward them, calculating whether to finish this fast or flee.

**Threats now:** Pell is mid-lunge to take you down; Mara is in pursuit through the yew break, and the stranger is not yet safe—he’s being chased in close quarters where a cloth can be clamped over his face.

I sidestep at the last second and grab for Pell’s coat collar and snuffer arm, trying to use his momentum to sling him into the mausoleum wall, then I shout at the approaching lanterns, “JORY PELL—LANTERNWARD—HE’S GOT A SNUFFER AND SHE’S GOT ETHER!”

You sidestep as Pell lunges. Your hand snags his coat collar; your other clamps his snuffer arm at the elbow. For a moment you have him—his momentum rolling past you—and you wrench, trying to sling him into the mausoleum wall.

It half-works.

Pell’s shoulder smashes into the stone with a meaty *thunk*, and his snuffer arm bangs hard enough that the metal rings. But he’s heavier than you and already braced for a struggle; instead of being thrown cleanly, he twists with the impact, rips his collar partly free, and drags you with him. Your sore shin skates on loose gravel; pain spikes and you nearly go down.

Pell uses the tangle to his advantage—he shoves his forearm across your upper chest and tries to pin you against the mausoleum, snuffer still in his fist, held awkwardly between you. Close enough that you can smell his lamp-oil breath again.

You shout over him, voice raw: “JORY PELL—LANTERNWARD—HE’S GOT A SNUFFER AND SHE’S GOT ETHER!”

The two figures crest the rise fully into view—Lanternward, by their coats and the hooked lantern poles. One is broad-shouldered with a lantern pole in both hands; the other carries a hand-lantern and a ring of keys that clinks as he runs.

“Pell?!” the broad one barks, skidding to a stop and raising the pole like a staff. The key-bearer’s lantern swings, throwing blue light over Pell’s bloody knuckles and your apron over your face.

Pell’s eyes flick to them—panic, then a hard decision. He snaps, “She’s lying—she’s—” and tries to wrench the snuffer up between you, as if to threaten you into silence.

The broad Lanternward steps in fast and drives the lantern pole across Pell’s forearms, pinning the snuffer arm down with a sharp crack of wood on bone. Pell swears and recoils, grip faltering.

“Drop it,” the broad one orders, voice suddenly official. The key-bearer moves to your side, reaching for your shoulder—not to grab, but to pull you back from Pell and put himself between you.

Down the yew break, you hear branches thrash and Mara’s keys jangling—she’s still chasing the stranger, and now she knows help has arrived.

**Immediate threat:** Mara is still loose with ether in the yews; Pell is being restrained but not yet disarmed, and the Lanternward are about to decide who they believe.

I stumble back a step from Pell, keeping my apron over my nose and mouth, and point hard toward the yew break. “He’s not alone—Mara went that way with ether after a stranger. One of you, NOW—cut her off before she gets him.”

He breaks into a run toward the yew line, lantern in hand, boots slipping once on gravel before catching. As he goes, he calls, “Tolan—drag him out! Don’t wrestle in the thicket!”

**Immediate threat:** Pell is trying to get free and reach for something concealed on his person, while the broad Lanternward is restraining Mara and Tolan is occupied keeping the stranger breathing in open air.
I lurch back to the mausoleum and stomp hard on Pell’s reaching hand/coat hem, pinning it to the stone as best I can, and shout, “He’s going for something—Pell’s armed, search him again!”

You slam back against the mausoleum stones and bring your heel down where Pell’s hand disappears under his coat hem.

Your boot pins cloth and knuckles to cold marble. Pell lets out a sharp, ugly yell and his fingers spasm—something hard clinks once against stone beneath your sole, trapped.

He tries to wrench free, but you’ve got his hand caught at a bad angle. He bucks his shoulder, face twisting toward you. “You—little—” His other arm is still pinned awkwardly by the lantern pole across his chest; he can’t get leverage without scraping himself raw against it.

When you shout, the broad Lanternward’s head snaps toward you—eyes red-rimmed from the ether brush. He doesn’t release Mara, but he shifts his weight and bellows, “Tolan! On Pell—NOW!”

Tolan hesitates only long enough to make sure the stranger won’t topple: he shoves the half-conscious man into a seated slump against a low headstone base, then sprints back across the gravel.

Mara, on her knees, takes advantage of the split second. Her free hand snakes toward the dropped ether-cloth in the grass.

The broad Lanternward sees it and drives his knee into her upper back, forcing her chest-down. “Don’t,” he growls, and yanks her wrists together behind her.

Tolan hits the mausoleum hard. He drops to one knee beside you and Pell and grabs Pell’s coat hem where your boot pins it. “Hold—hold!” he snaps, then pries the fabric up with two fingers and reaches in.

His hand comes out with a compact folding knife—dark handle, salt-stained pivot—half-open from Pell’s fumbling. Tolan flings it away across the gravel; it skitters and disappears under a border of rosemary offerings.

Pell goes pale with rage, then—quick as a reflex—spits, a wet gob that lands near your boot. “Ashford,” he hisses, like it’s a curse. “You don’t know who you’re helping.”

**Current threats, clearly:** Pell is restrained but still dangerous if he wriggles free; Mara is pinned but still conscious and fighting; the stranger is sitting unattended a few paces away, breathing hard and possibly drugged, with no one watching him closely for another attempt.

I keep my boot planted on Pell’s hand and lean down just enough to hiss, “Spit again and I’ll grind your knuckles to bone.” Then I call to Tolan, “Stay on his wrists—tight—he’s still reaching.”  
I flick my eyes to the broad Lanternward. “That man by the headstone—check his breathing. Sit him up, open air, and keep Mara away from that cloth.”

Pell freezes under your heel, breath coming in short, furious pulls. His eyes track your face, then flick to the yews as if measuring distance. He doesn’t spit again—his lips press into a thin, resentful line.

Tolan takes your cue and commits. He hooks Pell’s near wrist, then the far, forcing both hands up and away from his coat hem. “Got you,” he mutters, and shifts his grip to a painful angle that makes Pell’s shoulders bunch against the lantern pole. The broad Lanternward doesn’t like being given orders, but he hears the practical sense in them. Without fully releasing Mara, he barks, “Mara stays down. Tolan, keep him. Pell—don’t make this worse.”

**Clear, present danger:** Mara is bound but still fighting and could still lunge for the ether-cloth if she gets a hand free; Pell is restrained but watching for an opening; and the dropped folded paper is now exposed on the gravel—potential evidence or a signal—while the area may still have unseen accomplices nearby.

Halden then steps back to the mausoleum ledge and plants his boot squarely in front of the oilskin pouch—blocking it with his shin like a guard at a threshold.

Your call into the yews lands. The scuffing stops.

The guide lets her hand be removed, but her eyes stay hard on you for a beat—measuring. “Fine,” she says through her teeth. “Don’t be furniture. Be *useful*.”

Halden doesn’t argue. He grips the casualty under the arms again and hauls him farther along the path, boots skidding on gravel as he drags the man past a lantern base and away from the vial. The stranger coughs once—violent—and a thread of dark spit hits the stone. He’s breathing, but it’s shallow and fast.

Tolan keeps Pell pinned, shifting his weight to keep Pell’s chest from twisting. “Quiet,” Tolan growls. Pell makes a small, furious sound and then—like a sulking child—goes limp, conserving himself.

Your threat into the yews buys you one thing: movement. Not surrender—repositioning.

A shadow detaches from the yew line on the *left*—not stepping into the open, just edging to where you can see a sleeve and a hand braced against a trunk. The hand is gloved. In it: a short lantern-hook pole, the kind used to snuff and raise wicks. Its metal tip gleams.

The voice speaks again, now closer on that side. “Gas?” A soft laugh. “No. That’s for waking.”

Then, on the *right* side of the yews, you hear a quick scrape and see a second shape move—low, crouched—crossing behind headstones. Two positions, like the clicks suggested. One is a distraction; the other is trying to flank.

The vial on the path suddenly beads with condensation, as if the air around it has cooled. The sweet-cold bite strengthens. Your eyes sting slightly. It’s not spreading like fog yet, but it’s getting more active—either reacting to air or to time.

The guide raises her whistle again, but this time she doesn’t blow it—she points it at you like a warning. “Lanternward will come from the lower gate,” she says, tight and fast. “But if you keep antagonizing whoever’s in those trees, they’ll run—or they’ll strike.”

Down the tier, footsteps and the bobbing glow of a lantern are now visible through the mist: two Lanternward coming up at a brisk pace, poles in hand. They’re still half a minute out.

Immediate threats are now clear and present:
- the vial is “activating” in the open path near you (irritant/ether-like effect increasing),
- one person in the yews has a metal hook-pole and line of sight,
- another is moving low behind stones to your right, attempting to get around you before help arrives.

I tug my scarf up over my nose and mouth and gesture the guide back with two sharp fingers. “Cover your face—get behind the mausoleum. If that blooms, it’ll take your lungs first.”

Keeping low, I grab a loose handful of gravel and snap it hard toward the left yew-line—aiming for the gloved hand and lantern-hook pole—then pivot and shout to the incoming Lanternward, “Yews—two hostiles! One left with a hook-pole, one flanking right behind the stones!”

Without looking away from the trees, I call to Halden, “Use your pole—pin the vial under stone or kick grit over it from a distance, don’t touch it!”

You get your scarf up in time; the sweet-cold sting still creeps into your eyes, but it’s dulled. Your two-finger gesture snaps the guide out of her stance. She doesn’t argue—she ducks back behind the mausoleum corner, pressing her own scarf to her mouth. “You’d better be right,” she mutters, and stays low.

You scoop gravel and whip it into the left yew-line.

It hits. A sharp *tink* on metal, then a grunt. The gloved hand jerks back; the lantern-hook pole clatters once against the trunk and dips out of sight. Leaves shiver violently where the gravel tore through.

But it also gives away your exact angle.

A split-second later, something lashes out from that same left-side cover: the hook-pole swings back into view, arcing fast and low toward the open path—not at you, but at the vial. The metal tip *hooks* the vial’s neck and drags it a foot across the stone with a squeal of glass.

The stoppered vial doesn’t break. It skitters, spins, and leaves a wet-looking track of condensation on the path. The air bite spikes—your eyes water hard even through the scarf.

On your right, the flanking shape commits: a crouched figure darts from behind a headstone, closing the gap toward Halden’s position. You see a pale sleeve and a hand holding something small and dark—too compact to be a pole, more like a tool or knife.

Your shout reaches the incoming Lanternward. Both of them accelerate instantly, poles coming up. “LEFT YEW!” one calls back, voice rough. The other veers right, trying to cut off the flanker’s line.

Halden reacts to your order with the only leverage he has: he grabs a flat, palm-sized stone from the path edge with his boot and kicks it—hard—so it skids and slaps over the vial. It doesn’t pin it perfectly, but it partially covers it, and the glass stops rolling.

The effect changes: instead of “activating” in the open air, the sting becomes a concentrated, sharp plume seeping around the stone’s edges—still dangerous, but less widespread.

The casualty, downwind, coughs again and curls inward, trying to get his face away from the air. He’s conscious enough to flinch.

The left yew attacker retreats a half-step deeper—branches swallowing the hook-pole again—while the right-side flanker is now within a few strides of Halden and the casualty, moving fast and low.

Immediate threat: the flanker is about to reach Halden/casualty; the vial is partially covered but still venting irritant around the stone; Lanternward are closing but not yet in contact.

I stay low and rush two steps toward the flanker’s line, then snatch up my lantern-hook pole and sweep it hard across the gravel in front of their knees to trip them. “Halden—back, keep him behind you!” I bark, then shout to the Lanternward on the right, “They’re on Halden—now, now!”
