Into the shed, gentler: “I won’t close it if you stay still. Tell me your name, and slide whatever tool that is away from the threshold—slow.”  

Then I cut my eyes to the Brine-Choir volunteer. “My family’s annex isn’t your hymn-book’s playground,” I say, voice like a blade. “You’re going to tell me what line she was moved to—whose ledger, whose hand—or you can back up and let me speak to the person you’ve cornered.”

The line obeys—mostly. Two Lanternward bend their knees and lower their weight; one does it a heartbeat late and stumbles into the back of the person ahead. The chain holds, but their hands clutch tighter, knuckles whitening. The “pull” through the tier eases just enough that boots stop skittering.

Inside the shed, the unseen person answers your gentle voice with a sharp inhale.

“My—” they start, then stop, like the name hurts to shape.

A small metal tool—thin, hooked, familiar as a grave-knife or etching pick—scrapes across the floorboards. It doesn’t slide away from the threshold. It slides **toward** it, then pauses, as if the person’s arm is being argued with.

Their hands rise higher, palms still out. The lantern-oil sheen on their wrists catches the blue spill.

“I’m not supposed to have one,” they whisper. “If I put it down, it— it sees.”

The caretaker beside you swallows and keeps his hand on the latch, but his eyes flick to the mounting bracket above the door—where a chalk-salt scrawl sits half-hidden under the iron banding. He doesn’t touch it. He looks like he knows better.

Your blade-voice at the Brine-Choir volunteer lands. They finally take a step back—one pace, not a retreat, more like granting you “space” they think they control. Their hymn-book remains open, thumb still marking that inside cover.

“Whose hand?” they echo, and their gaze slides past you to the lantern-glass along the path, watching reflections. “You want a hand, Wren? Watch the ones that never get dirty.”

As they say it, a lamp-tender down the tier—trimming a wick, shooing moths from the glass—stills for half a second, then resumes with exaggerated calm. She doesn’t look at you directly; she watches you in the lantern pane, counting with her thumb against the oil-can.

The blue light in the shed pulses again—stronger. The iron braid on the nearest path-lantern (third on the left past the rosemary offerings) answers with a faint, tight *click* from inside its housing, like a latch engaging.

The threat becomes concrete: the ward-lantern has “woken.” If anyone lunges or grabs at the bracket/sigil area, it will react—fast—like a guard-dog made of light and iron.

Inside the shed, the crouched figure flinches at that click. Their hands shake harder.

“I can tell you the line,” they whisper, voice cracking. “But you have to stop the lantern from listening.”

I keep my hand on the shed door but loosen my shoulders, voice low and steady. “No one touches the lantern. No sudden moves—Lanternward, breathe with me.”

To the caretaker, barely a whisper: “You saw the chalk-salt scrawl. Don’t wipe it—just cover it. Your coat, your hand, anything dull. Slow.”

I angle my face toward the shed crack. “I can’t stop it from listening entirely, but I can keep it calm. Tell me your name—quiet—and tell me the line. If you bolt, it’ll wake fully.”  

Then, without looking at her directly, I call down-tier toward the lamp-tender. “Hands off the wick. Step back from the lantern and show me both palms.”

I don’t move my feet; I just breathe slow and even. “Nobody touches the lantern—nobody.”  

I murmur to the caretaker, “Cover the chalk-salt. Coat sleeve, palm—something dull. Easy.”  

Into the shed, soft: “Tell me your name, and the line Iris was moved to. I’ll keep the door steady.”  

Then, voice carrying down-tier without looking straight at her: “Lamp-tender—step back from the lantern and show me both hands. Now.”

I hold the shed door exactly where it is and breathe out slow. “Stay linked. Knees soft. No one touches any lantern—hear me?”  

To the caretaker, a whisper: “Cover the chalk-salt mark with your sleeve. Don’t rub—just hide it.”  

Into the shed, gentle but firm: “Name and line—now. Help me keep it calm.”  

Down-tier, voice flat: “Lamp-tender. Both hands up where I can see them, and step away from the glass.”

The linked Lanternward line steadies. You hear a few ragged breaths sync with yours; boots stop scraping gravel. No one lunges.

At your whisper, the caretaker shifts—slow, obedient. He slides his sleeve up over his knuckles and *covers* the chalk-salt scrawl without rubbing. The blue pulse in the nearby lantern doesn’t stop, but it dulls a fraction, like an eye half-lidded. He keeps his wrist there, trembling.

Inside the shed, the unseen person swallows hard. A face edges into the crack of the door: young, salt-pale, with lantern-oil on their fingertips and a smear of chalk at the corner of their mouth as if they’ve been biting it.

“L—Lio,” they say, barely a breath. “Lio Marr.”

The hooked tool clinks as it’s set down—carefully, not thrown. Still, the moment metal meets plank, the path-lantern answers with that tight internal *click* again.

And then the ward bites.

The air turns metallic-sweet, like pennies warmed in sugar. The blue lantern nearest you flares, and moth-shadow shapes spiral out of the glass in a tight helix—straight toward your hands on the shed door. They don’t touch your skin like insects; they *print* themselves.

A thin soot-mark blooms across your fingers and up your knuckles like a half-glove—dark, velvety, impossible to miss in lanternlight. Your grip leaves no new smear on the wood, but your hands are now visibly “tagged,” as if the lantern has signed you.

Down-tier, your command lands. The lamp-tender freezes mid-trim. She does step back—one pace—then raises both palms. Her hands are clean. Too clean for oil-work. She speaks without looking at you, voice mild and careful.

“Of course, Miss Ashford. Both hands.”

Behind her, farther down the path, a bell answers—distant, single-toned, not the buoy-bell’s moan but a crisp cemetery bell. It rings once, then again, as if acknowledging a report being received.

Inside the shed, Lio’s eyes go wide when they see the soot on your hands.

“I— I didn’t—” they whisper urgently. “The line— Iris—” Their gaze darts to the lantern, then back to you. “Upper tier, north seam. Line *Geth—*” The rest catches in their throat, like something presses on the word.

The threat is immediate and physical: your marked hands make you identifiable in lanternlight, and the answering bell suggests Lanternward attention is already being summoned up-tier.

I swallow the spike of panic and keep my marked hands on the door anyway. “Lio—look at me. Finish it: *Geth—what?* One more breath and say it.”

Without turning, I murmur to the caretaker, “Keep that scrawl covered. Don’t flinch, no matter what it does.”

Then, to the line, steady and quiet: “We’re backing away from the lantern—together. Three steps on my count, still linked.” I glance down-tier at the lamp-tender’s reflection in the glass. “And you—stay exactly where you are. If that bell is for me, I’d like to meet it with everyone still alive.”

Lio’s eyes lock on yours. Their throat works once, twice—like they’re forcing air past a knot.

“Geth—” they manage, and the lantern gives a sharp *tick* in answer, as if correcting them. Lio flinches, but you don’t move your hands; the door stays steady.

“Geth…erin,” Lio finishes on a thin exhale. “Line Getherin. Upper tier, north seam. Iris was moved to—” They swallow. “—to the seam’s inside row. Not hers. Not her family.”

The moment the full word lands, the soot-mark on your hands tightens—darkening at the creases of your knuckles like ink settling into paper. It doesn’t burn, but it *pulls*, a faint tug as if something has taken hold of your signature.

The caretaker does what you told him. He keeps his sleeve over the chalk-salt scrawl, jaw clenched hard enough you can see it jump. When the lantern ticks again, he stiffens but doesn’t flinch away.

Your instruction to the linked line holds. On your count, they take three careful steps back in unison, arms still hooked. Gravel crunches; the blue flare in the nearest lantern softens from a glare to a mean, steady sputter. The moth-shadow helix loosens, no longer aimed directly at your hands—still present, but circling.

Down-tier, the lamp-tender stays exactly where she is, palms up. In the lantern’s glass you catch her reflection: her mouth curves in a small, controlled smile that doesn’t reach her eyes.

The cemetery bell rings again—closer now, not louder but *nearer*, as if the ringer is moving up-tier. Footsteps follow: two sets, measured, not running. Lanternward boots on stone edging.

A voice calls from the path bend, official and calm. “Hold position. Nobody breaks the chain.”

Another lantern is coming—its light normal-yellow at first, then briefly flickering blue at the edges as it nears the warded one.

Lio whispers fast from the shed crack, panic rising. “They’ll see your hands. They’ll say you touched it. They’ll—”

The immediate threat is clear: Lanternward responders are arriving within moments, and your soot-marked hands are visible proof they can use to accuse you of tampering with a warded lantern.

I keep my hands exactly where they are and raise my voice toward the approaching boots, calm and clear. “Lanternward—Wren Ashford. The ward-lantern tagged me when the tool hit the floor; I have not touched the glass, the wick, or the scrawl. We’re holding position.”

Without looking away from the shed crack, I whisper to Lio, “Breathe. Sit back from the threshold and keep your hands visible—empty. Let them see you’re not a threat.”

Then, to the caretaker in a low murmur, “When they’re close enough to hear, tell them you covered the scrawl on my instruction—no one altered it.”

I keep my marked hands on the shed door and call out, steady, “Lanternward—Elowen Ashford. The ward-lantern tagged me when the tool struck the floor; I have not touched glass, wick, or scrawl. We are holding position and backing away together.”  
Without breaking my stance, I whisper into the crack, “Lio, sit back from the threshold—hands open, empty, where they can see. Breathe with me.”  
To the caretaker, low: “When they’re in earshot, tell them you covered the chalk-salt on my instruction—no rubbing, no changes.”

Your voice carries cleanly up the path. The two sets of Lanternward boots slow, then stop where the lanternlight can reach them without putting them in the ward’s brightest spill.

A man answers first—Lanternward coat, brass badge, lantern on a long hook held out like a cautious offering. “Heard you,” he calls. “Hands where we can see them, Ashford. Don’t step toward the blue.”

Beside him, a woman in a neat oilskin apron lifts a small slate and a stub of chalk. She doesn’t write yet; she watches your soot-marked hands with an appraiser’s stillness. “Tagged,” she repeats, flat. “That’s a claim.”

Your whisper gets through the crack. Lio obeys: you hear a quick shuffle back from the threshold, then both their hands rise into the narrow opening—palms forward, empty, fingers trembling. They match your breathing for two counts, then lose it, then find it again.

The caretaker, still linked to you by the line, does exactly what you told him. He keeps his sleeve pressed over the chalk-salt scrawl like a bandage. Sweat beads at his hairline.

When the Lanternward pair come two steps closer—close enough that you can smell lamp-oil and wet wool—the caretaker speaks, voice hoarse but steady. “On Miss Ashford’s instruction. I covered it. No rubbing. No changes.”

The woman with the slate finally marks something down. The chalk makes a small, sharp sound. “Noted.”

Then she angles her lantern-hook so its light skims the shed door and your hands. The soot-tag doesn’t smear or flake; it sits in the skin’s creases like it’s been *stamped*. Her eyes flick from your knuckles to the shed crack.

“Lio Marr,” she says, as if she’s been expecting the name. “Step out. Slowly. Keep your hands up.”

Inside, Lio’s breath catches. They don’t move yet.

Down-tier, the lamp-tender you spotted earlier lowers her palms—just a fraction—then raises them again, like she’s signaling patience. She stays put, but her head tilts as if listening for something beyond the bell and boots.

The threat is immediate and specific: Lanternward is taking control of the scene, Lio is being ordered to emerge, and your soot-mark is being treated as evidence. If Lio bolts or if anyone breaks the linked line, the ward-lantern’s blue sputter intensifies—its moth-shadow spiral tightens, ready to “snap” toward the nearest moving hands.

I keep my hands where they are, voice even. “Lio—listen to me. Don’t run. Slide forward on your knees until you’re in the light, then stop. Hands up the whole time.”

I call to the woman with the slate without turning my head. “Let me speak them out. They’re responding to my voice—if you rush them, the ward snaps. I’m not moving toward the blue, and the chain stays linked.”

Then, softer into the crack, “You’re not alone, Lio. One breath—then move slow, like you’re wading.”

Lio’s breathing steadies on your count—one breath, then another. You hear fabric rasp against wood. A knee touches the threshold with a soft knock.

They do exactly what you said: they slide forward on their knees into the lantern’s reach, hands lifted high the whole time. Their wrists shake hard enough their fingers flutter, but they don’t drop them. When their face clears the crack, you see salt-stiff hair plastered to their forehead and a thin line of dried blood at one nostril.

The ward-lantern reacts to your voice the way you suspected: the blue sputter sharpens when the Lanternward woman shifts her hook-lantern, then eases when you speak again. The moth-shadow spiral tightens toward Lio for a heartbeat—then loosens, circling wider, as if it’s listening for the next syllable.

The woman with the slate stops advancing. She lifts her free hand, palm out, holding her partner back. “No rush,” she says, clipped. “Ashford’s right about the snap.”

Her partner—badge and hook—keeps his lantern steady and raises his voice toward Lio. “Stop where you are. Good. Don’t stand. Don’t touch the doorframe.”

Lio stops in the light, still on their knees. They swallow and speak, voice breaking. “I didn’t— I didn’t change anything. I saw the seam lantern go blue and I— I hid.”

The caretaker’s sleeve remains pressed over the chalk-salt scrawl; his linked arm trembles with strain, but he doesn’t break contact with you.

Then the down-tier lamp-tender finally moves. Not toward you—sideways, along the lower path, keeping distance from the ward’s spill. She walks with careful, practiced steps and calls up without looking directly at the blue lantern: “Supervisor Harker. You’ll want the ledger-page too, not just the hands.”

The man with the badge glances toward her, and you catch his name in the exchange—Harker, as she said. His jaw tightens. “Stay where you are, Nessa.”

Nessa doesn’t stop. She reaches a post and unhooks a small tin rattle-lantern—an auxiliary light—and begins to climb the side steps, keeping it low.

Concrete threat: Nessa is approaching with another lantern and a “ledger-page” angle, and the ward-lantern is already showing it can snap toward the nearest moving hands if the light pattern or voices change abruptly. If Nessa brings that auxiliary light too close or if Harker decides to seize Lio, the ward may lash out at whoever moves first—most likely Lio’s raised hands or your soot-marked ones.

I keep my soot-marked hands on the shed door and call to Harker, measured. “Supervisor—tell Nessa to stop on that stair. No auxiliary light in the spill until the blue settles; it’s already tracking hands.”

Without looking away from Lio, I soften my voice. “Lio, stay on your knees. Eyes on me, not the lantern. Tell them what you told me—upper tier, north seam, Line Getherin, and Iris moved to an inside row.”

Then, to the Lanternward woman with the slate, quiet but firm: “If you need a statement, take it now while I’m keeping it calm. My hands were tagged when the tool hit—no contact with glass, wick, or the mark.”

Harker snaps his head toward the side steps. “Nessa—hold. Stair. Now.”

Nessa stops mid-ascent with her auxiliary rattle-lantern hanging low at her thigh. She doesn’t argue, but her mouth presses into a thin line. The rattle-lantern’s little tin belly gives one involuntary *chink* as it settles. The ward-lantern’s blue flame tightens toward the sound like an eye narrowing—then, when nothing else moves, it relaxes back into its wider spiral.

Your calm has a measurable effect: the blue sputter steadies from a frantic stutter to a slower, breathing flicker.

Lio keeps their gaze pinned to you and doesn’t look at the lantern. Still on their knees, they speak in short, rehearsed bursts, like repeating directions they’ve walked a hundred times.

“Upper tier,” they say. “North seam. Line—Getherin. The Iris plot—someone moved it. Inside row. Not where it belongs.” Their voice cracks on *belongs*, and their hands wobble but stay up.

The woman with the slate shifts her stance so the light catches both Lio and your soot-marked hands without throwing extra glare into the blue spill. “Statement,” she agrees, brisk. She writes as she speaks, turning your words into record. “Elowen Ashford: tagged when tool struck floor. No contact with glass, wick, or scrawl.”

Harker’s hook-lantern remains extended, steady, but his attention sharpens at “Getherin.” He repeats it as if tasting whether it should exist. “Getherin,” he says. “That line’s sealed.”

He gestures two fingers—minimal movement—to his partner. “Fetch the tier map. Not the annex overlay. The public one.” It’s an order meant to sound routine.

Nessa, still frozen on the stair, calls up quietly, “Supervisor, the public map won’t show the seam breaks.”

Harker doesn’t look at her. “It will show what it’s *supposed* to show.”

Concrete threat: Harker is already steering this toward an “official” version of events. If he decides Lio’s mention of Getherin is too dangerous for the record, he may move to detain them—or compel silence—while using your soot-tag as leverage. The ward-lantern is calmer, but it’s still tracking hands and sound; any sudden grab, lunge, or dropped lantern could make it snap.

I keep my hands planted and meet Harker’s lantern-lit silhouette with my voice. “Supervisor, if Getherin is sealed, then it shouldn’t be answering anyone’s mouth in your ward—yet it is. Put that in the record.”

I angle my words toward the woman with the slate. “Write it exactly: *Lio Marr stated ‘Line Getherin, upper tier north seam,’ and stated the Iris plot was moved to an inside row.* No interpretations.”

Then, careful and quiet, I add for Nessa without looking at her, “If you know the seam breaks, Nessa, say so—out loud—so it’s heard by more than one person.”

Harker doesn’t answer you at first. His lantern-hook dips a fraction—enough to change the angle of light across your soot-marked fingers. The blue flame in the ward-lantern reacts to the shift: it tightens its spiral toward your knuckles, hovering there like a held breath.

The woman with the slate does what you asked. She speaks as she writes, making it audible. “Recorded verbatim: ‘Lio Marr stated, Line Getherin, upper tier north seam,’ and ‘stated the Iris plot was moved to an inside row.’” She underlines *verbatim* with a hard chalk stroke, then pauses, eyes on Harker as if daring him to contradict the page.

Harker’s jaw works. “That line doesn’t ‘answer mouths,’ Ashford,” he says, controlled. “People repeat what they hear.”

Then you press Nessa.

Nessa inhales on the stair. For a moment she looks like she might swallow it back. Instead, she lifts her chin and speaks clearly, projecting up the steps so it carries to all of you.

“I know the seam breaks,” she says. “North seam’s been opening and closing since the first blue-guttering. A hairline shift—enough to move a plot border without cracking the capstones. And the public map won’t show it.”

Harker turns his head sharply toward her. “Nessa.”

She doesn’t stop. “And the Iris plot marker was handled. Fresh tool face. Not weather.”

At the word *tool*, the caretaker flinches—his sleeve presses harder over the chalk-salt scrawl, and his elbow slides just a hair.

That tiny movement is enough.

The ward-lantern snaps.

The blue spiral lashes out in a thin, fast ribbon of light toward the nearest moving hand—the caretaker’s covered forearm—striking like a whip. There’s a sharp *sizzle* and the smell of scorched salt and singed wool. The caretaker jerks, choking on a cry, and his sleeve smokes where the ribbon hit.

His pain reflex yanks his arm—still linked to yours—down and away.

Your linked grip breaks.

The moment contact is lost, the chalk-salt beneath his sleeve flares through the fabric in a bright, cold glow, as if the mark has been waiting for air. The shed door shudders once from the inside, not from Lio—something deeper, like a latch answering a different hand.

Immediate threat: the ward-lantern is now “awake” and reactive, having successfully struck once. The chalk-salt mark has ignited under the caretaker’s sleeve, and the shed door just moved as if something inside responded to the flare.

“Don’t move!” I bark, sharper than I mean to—then drop my tone. “Everyone—freeze. No extra light, no grabbing.”

I edge my soot-marked hands an inch off the door, palms open and visible, and speak steadily to the caretaker. “Look at me. Slow breaths. I’m going to take your sleeve away from the mark—slow—and you’re going to let it happen.”

To Harker, clipped: “Supervisor, order him to hold still and give me one clean cloth—now. If that scrawl’s flaring, it’s answering heat and air.”

Without stepping into the blue, I reach with two fingers only—careful, minimal motion—to pinch the edge of the caretaker’s smoking sleeve and peel it back a fraction at a time, trying to expose the chalk-salt without scraping it. “Lio,” I add without looking, “stay exactly where you are. Don’t touch the frame.”

Your first bark lands like a slap. Everyone actually freezes—because they’ve just watched the lantern strike.

The ward-lantern’s blue ribbon quivers in the air for a beat, searching for the next motion. When you lower your tone and slow your hands, it doesn’t lash again; instead it tightens into a tense, watching coil pointed at the caretaker’s forearm.

The caretaker—young, freckled under soot—locks watery eyes on you and forces his breath to match yours. He’s shaking so hard his teeth click once.

Harker reacts to your order with a hard look, then chooses control over pride. “Jory—hold!” he snaps at the caretaker. To his partner: “Cloth. From the kit. White.”

The Lanternward woman with the slate tucks it under her arm, crouches without suddenness, and pulls a folded linen from a satchel at her hip—clean, pressed, official. She doesn’t throw it. She slides it across the gravel toward you with two fingers so it doesn’t *skitter*.

As you lift your soot-marked hands an inch off the shed door, the door gives a faint answering tremor—like a throat clearing behind wood. The latch does not open, but the seam darkens as if something inside pressed close and then eased away.

You pinch the edge of Jory’s smoking sleeve with two fingers and begin to peel.

The cloth resists at first, singed fibers sticking to whatever’s underneath. You go fraction by fraction. The ward-lantern tracks those two fingers with predatory attention, but it holds—no strike—so long as your motion stays slow and your voice stays even.

When the sleeve finally lifts enough to expose the chalk-salt, you see it clearly:

A scrawl of pale crystals and chalk, threaded with something wet-black, drawn in a looping shorthand that looks uncomfortably like old funeral-home notation—three looping letters repeated and crossed through. The exposed portion flares brighter the moment it hits open air, the glow crawling outward along the lines like frost spreading on glass.

Jory whimpers and tries to pull away on instinct.

Harker barks, “Hold, Jory!”

Jory clamps down, knuckles white, trembling in place.

Lio stays on their knees, hands still up, eyes fixed on you. They don’t touch the frame. They whisper, barely audible, “It’s the same hand.”

Concrete, immediate threat: the mark is actively “feeding” on air exposure—its glow intensifies as you uncover it—and the shed door has already responded once. If the glow reaches the edge of the sleeve line or touches bare skin, it may burn deeper or trigger another door movement; if Jory jerks suddenly, the ward-lantern is poised to strike moving hands again.

I slide the clean linen over the exposed scrawl like I’m laying gauze on fresh paint—no pressure, no rubbing—just sealing it from air. “Jory, keep breathing; don’t yank. Let the cloth do the work.”

Without looking up, I say to the Lanternward woman, “Write that too: *Lio Marr said, ‘It’s the same hand.’*” Then to Harker, tight: “That shorthand—do you recognize it, or are we all going to pretend funeral notation isn’t in your ward?”

I keep my voice low and steady toward the shed seam. “Whatever’s listening in there—no. Stay.”

The linen settles over the glowing scrawl with almost no sound.

The effect is immediate and visible: the chalk-salt flare dims from a hard, icy white to a muted, milk-glow that no longer crawls outward. The singed smell lessens. Jory’s trembling doesn’t stop, but the panic in it eases into something he can hold.

“Good,” Harker says under his breath—more to the situation than to you. He keeps his hook-lantern fixed, but he angles it slightly away from Jory’s forearm, reducing the blue’s direct attention.

Jory swallows and nods once, fast. “I’m—holding,” he manages, voice thin.

The Lanternward woman with the slate speaks as she writes again, crisp and audible. “Recorded: ‘Lio Marr said, It’s the same hand.’” Her chalk pauses at the end of the sentence, then continues—she’s adding more than you asked, the scratch of it quickening as if she doesn’t want to forget what she saw.

At your question about shorthand, Harker’s posture tightens. He doesn’t answer right away.

Then: “I recognize *funeral notation*,” he says carefully, each word measured. “I don’t recognize it belonging here.”

It’s not denial. It’s a boundary being drawn.

Behind the linen, the mark gives one last faint pulse—like a heartbeat muffled under cloth—and then holds steady.

Your quiet warning toward the shed seam is met with a physical response: the door stops shuddering, but the latch gives a small, deliberate *tick* from the inside, as if something tested it and decided against. A thin line of colder air slips out through the seam and brushes your fingers—brine-cold, with the metallic tang of buoy-bells.

Lio’s eyes flick to the seam despite themselves. Their hands stay up. “It hears voices,” they whisper. “Not names. Voices.”

Nessa, still on the stair, doesn’t move, but she watches Harker now instead of the lantern. “Supervisor,” she says, low, “that cloth won’t hold if he sweats through it.”

Concrete threat: the scrawl is contained but not neutralized—if the linen shifts, gets damp, or is pulled off, it may flare again and provoke the ward-lantern or the shed latch. The shed is still “responsive”; it has tested the latch from inside and vented cold air, suggesting something within is awake and listening for cues.

I keep one hand hovering near the linen, the other open at my side. “Nessa’s right—Jory, you’re going to overheat. Harker, have someone bring a dry second layer—waxed oilcloth if you’ve got it—and a length of twine. We bind the linen *lightly* so it can’t slip, and we keep him cool.”

I speak toward Lio without turning my head. “Lio, keep your eyes on me and tell me—what voice did it answer first? Mine, or yours?”

Then, still low, I add for the slate-woman to catch: “And write this: the latch ticked from inside when the mark pulsed.”

Harker doesn’t argue. He points without looking away from Jory’s arm. “Tamsin—oilcloth. Twine. Now. And don’t run.”

A second Lanternward caretaker—Tamsin, older, hair pinned under a cap—backs away from the circle and heads down the path at a fast walk, lantern held low to keep its light from flaring.

Jory nods too quickly. Sweat already beads at his temple. He keeps his forearm held out like it’s someone else’s.

The slate-woman writes as you speak. “Noted: ‘Latch ticked from inside when the mark pulsed.’” Then she adds, almost reluctantly, “Observed: cold air exhaled from seam.” She says *observed* like a shield.

You keep your hand hovering near the linen. The cloth stays in place; the glow beneath remains muted. No new lash from the ward-lantern—its blue coil stays taut, aimed, but still.

Your question to Lio cuts through the hush.

Lio’s eyes stay on you as instructed. Their throat works once. “Yours,” they answer. “It… leaned toward you when you spoke like you meant it. When I talked, it listened—when you talked, it *moved*.”

Harker’s gaze flicks to you at that, sharp and assessing, then back to the covered mark. “So it’s keyed to authority,” he mutters, half to himself.

The shed responds to the conversation in a way you can’t mistake: a slow pressure against the door from the inside—just enough to bow the wood a fraction at the seam—then release. Dust puffs from the hinge line. The latch does not open, but the *tick* repeats, closer in time to your voice than before.

Immediate, concrete threat: the shed is actively reacting to speech cadence and “command” tone; each time it tests the latch, the door flexes and sheds dust. If it finds the right cue—or if the mark is uncovered again—it may open, or something inside may force the seam. Also, Jory is starting to sweat; if moisture seeps into the linen, the containment may fail.

Tamsin has not returned yet. You have a brief window where the mark is stable but vulnerable.

I lower my voice to something almost conversational and stop addressing the shed entirely. “Harker—no more orders near the door. If it’s keyed to authority, you and I are ringing the bell for it.”

Ing Lanterns.location_description: Ing Lanterns are older than the path they pretend to illuminate—each glass is faintly salted from the inside, as if it has wept sea-mist for years. The lanternposts bear tiny, polite chisel-marks (a caretakers’ shorthand) that map which graves are meant to be remembered and which are meant to be merely visited. When the wind turns, the flames lean as if listening, and the shadows they cast occasionally resemble moths with too many wings.

watchers.name: Moth-Counter Hest Finch
watchers.description: Pretends to be tallying moths drawn to the lanterns for a 'Lanternward census,' but is actually watching for anyone lingering at posts with altered chisel-marks. She listens for names spoken twice and notes which tools are carried in pockets.

watchers.name: Brother Sedge of the Brine-Choir
watchers.description: Sits on a low stone like a patient hymn, humming softly to 'steady the flame.' He’s watching for anyone who reacts to buoy-bell calls or mentions drowned names; he reads faces the way sailors read weather.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternwick Warden (a chained flame-sprite)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Inside the third lantern on the left after the rosemary offering-stone, its base etched with a Lanternward seal that looks like a keyhole wearing a halo.
weaknesses: Do not touch the latch; instead, speak a caretaker’s courtesy (a simple apology) and step back
Cover the lantern briefly with a dark cloth to calm the sprite without opening it
Scatter a pinch of salt in a small circle at your feet to keep it from leaping out

escape_conditions: Switch to writing the name instead of speaking and keep your voice to mundane topics

Seek a Lanternward tour group as cover; the Choir avoids open confrontation under civic eyes

secrets.description: One lantern’s glass is etched with a microscopic map of cemetery tiers—only visible when the flame leans sideways—marking a single plot number that does not exist in the public ledger. The number is paired with a tiny symbol used in Ashford & Daughters internal records: a sea-glass charm shape, the kind Wren collects.

Beneath the rosemary offering-stone is a flat, sealed tin meant to look like a maintenance cap. Inside are three moth wings pressed into paper and a sliver of ledger-page with a name carefully scraped away—except for the last two letters, still clinging like a stubborn smile.

Ing Guide.location_description: Ing Guide is a narrow, lantern-sputtering lane-map kiosk and tour placard tucked between two leaning angel statues, where the Lanternward posts “helpful” directions that subtly reroute visitors away from edited plots. Salt mist has glued a film of mica to the signage so it sparkles when breathed on, and the iron guide-rail hums faintly with buoy-bell resonance if you rest a hand on it too long.

watchers.name: Mist-Quill Moth
watchers.description: A pale moth the size of a thumbprint that keeps returning to the same lantern-glass, as if reading the tour placard. It drifts close when names are spoken aloud, then flutters away toward the Lanternward office to be “translated” by whoever knows how to listen.

watchers.name: Sister Celandine-of-the-Tide
watchers.description: A cheerful tide-singer in a damp wool cloak who pretends to be lost and asks for directions with too-perfect politeness. She watches reflections more than faces—puddles, polished marble, lantern-glass—listening for the shape of a secret in someone’s pause.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternward Whisper-Lock beneath the Ing Guide rail
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Bolted under the iron guide-rail where visitors lean to read the map; it’s disguised as a decorative bracket shaped like a curled fern.
weaknesses: Keep hands off the rail while speaking sensitive words
Speak only in questions (it listens for declarative intent)
Wrap the bracket in rosemary or salt-damp cloth to mute its resonance briefly

Cut the connection by tying the pull-cord into a simple sailor’s knot and sprinkling it with salt
Leave the premises and avoid mentioning buoy-bells for the rest of the day

fail_conditions.name: Asking for the 'Ing' pair by name

The town remains polite, but doors begin to close a beat early.

Ask a sincere, mundane cobbler question to reframe the conversation
Leave before Orin returns and vary your route home

Ing Lanterns.location_description: Ing Lanterns are older than the path they pretend to illuminate—each glass is faintly salted from the inside, as if it has wept sea-mist for years. The lanternposts bear tiny, polite chisel-marks (a caretakers’ shorthand) that map which graves are meant to be remembered and which are meant to be merely visited. When the wind turns, the flames lean as if listening, and the shadows they cast occasionally resemble moths with too many wings.

watchers.name: Moth-Counter Hest Finch
watchers.description: Pretends to be tallying moths drawn to the lanterns for a 'Lanternward census,' but is actually watching for anyone lingering at posts with altered chisel-marks. She listens for names spoken twice and notes which tools are carried in pockets.

watchers.name: Brother Sedge of the Brine-Choir
watchers.description: Sits on a low stone like a patient hymn, humming softly to 'steady the flame.' He’s watching for anyone who reacts to buoy-bell calls or mentions drowned names; he reads faces the way sailors read weather.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternwick Warden (a chained flame-sprite)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Inside the third lantern on the left after the rosemary offering-stone, its base etched with a Lanternward seal that looks like a keyhole wearing a halo.
weaknesses: Do not touch the latch; instead, speak a caretaker’s courtesy (a simple apology) and step back
Cover the lantern briefly with a dark cloth to calm the sprite without opening it
Scatter a pinch of salt in a small circle at your feet to keep it from leaping out

fail_conditions.name: Touching the chisel-marks on the lanternpost
fail_conditions.description: The marks are a quiet alarm: skin-oil completes the etched circuit and tells the Lanternward exactly who handled it, even in fog. It’s designed to catch 'helpful' restorers who notice inconsistencies.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The nearest lantern flame flares an attentive blue and throws your shadow long enough to be recognizable. Within minutes, an overly friendly tour-guide drifts close, asking questions that are shaped like compliments but bite like hooks.
escape_conditions: Wipe the post with a rosemary cloth as if performing routine maintenance to smear the signal
Move immediately into the grass-hush where sound is swallowed and line of sight breaks
Redirect attention by asking about a public tour route and walking with purpose

fail_conditions.name: Speaking a drowned name aloud beneath Ing Lanterns
fail_conditions.description: The Brine-Choir uses lantern acoustics as a listening shell; certain names make the glass resonate and carry farther than they should. In mist, the sound can be 'answered' by a buoy-bell that isn’t anywhere nearby.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A bell-note arrives through the fog like a cold fingertip pressed to the ear, and the lanterns sputter in unison as if taking a breath. Someone begins following at a courteous distance—close enough to be sure, far enough to deny it—until you are guided toward the shoreward gate without realizing you’ve turned.
escape_conditions: Switch to writing the name instead of speaking and keep your voice to mundane topics
Step into a cluster of lanterns and hum a steady counter-note to break the resonance
Seek a Lanternward tour group as cover; the Choir avoids open confrontation under civic eyes

secrets.description: One lantern’s glass is etched with a microscopic map of cemetery tiers—only visible when the flame leans sideways—marking a single plot number that does not exist in the public ledger. The number is paired with a tiny symbol used in Ashford & Daughters internal records: a sea-glass charm shape, the kind Wren collects.

Beneath the rosemary offering-stone is a flat, sealed tin meant to look like a maintenance cap. Inside are three moth wings pressed into paper and a sliver of ledger-page with a name carefully scraped away—except for the last two letters, still clinging like a stubborn smile.

Ing Guide.location_description: Ing Guide is a narrow, lantern-sputtering lane-map kiosk and tour placard tucked between two leaning angel statues, where the Lanternward posts “helpful” directions that subtly reroute visitors away from edited plots. Salt mist has glued a film of mica to the signage so it sparkles when breathed on, and the iron guide-rail hums faintly with buoy-bell resonance if you rest a hand on it too long.

watchers.name: Mist-Quill Moth
watchers.description: A pale moth the size of a thumbprint that keeps returning to the same lantern-glass, as if reading the tour placard. It drifts close when names are spoken aloud, then flutters away toward the Lanternward office to be “translated” by whoever knows how to listen.

watchers.name: Sister Celandine-of-the-Tide
watchers.description: A cheerful tide-singer in a damp wool cloak who pretends to be lost and asks for directions with too-perfect politeness. She watches reflections more than faces—puddles, polished marble, lantern-glass—listening for the shape of a secret in someone’s pause.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternward Whisper-Lock beneath the Ing Guide rail
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Bolted under the iron guide-rail where visitors lean to read the map; it’s disguised as a decorative bracket shaped like a curled fern.
weaknesses: Keep hands off the rail while speaking sensitive words
Speak only in questions (it listens for declarative intent)
Wrap the bracket in rosemary or salt-damp cloth to mute its resonance briefly

fail_conditions.name: Reading the Ing Guide placard aloud in full
fail_conditions.description: The placard is inked with a subtle call-and-response cadence; reciting it activates a buoy-bell mimic that flags the speaker as a compliant tour-goer—and a useful target for rerouting or recruitment.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The lanterns along the path sputter in sequence, as if applauding, and the air grows politely attentive. Within minutes, a Lanternward guide arrives with impeccable timing to “assist,” gently steering the conversation away from names that matter and noting Wren’s interest for the ledgers.
escape_conditions: Interrupt the recitation with a cough and change the wording mid-line
Step off the gravel onto grass to break the cadence
Ask for a different map copy instead of continuing

fail_conditions.name: Mentioning Wren’s mother by name within arm’s reach of the guide-rail
fail_conditions.description: The ironwork is tuned to carry certain names like a wire carries a storm; the Whisper-Lock treats them as keys and sends a quiet alert through the cemetery’s lantern network.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A thin, bell-buoy moan threads through the mist, and the nearest lanterns dim as though listening harder. A Brine-Choir “volunteer” arrives with a sympathetic hymn and an offer of help that feels like a hook; shortly after, a Lanternward caretaker begins hovering near the relevant tiers, ready to intercept any search.
escape_conditions: Move away from ironwork and speak into open air (no metal nearby)
Use a nickname or omit the name entirely
Create a harmless distraction (drop tools, ask about tour times) to muddy the alert’s focus

secrets.description: Behind the Ing Guide placard, a second layer of paper has been pasted over the original map. If peeled back carefully, the older print shows a now-“nonexistent” section labeled in tiny type as the Siltward Tier, with three plots marked by faint sea-glass green circles—one bearing an Ashford initial that does not match any public ledger.

A hollow in the stone base of the guide-post hides a curled strip of funeral-home receipt paper, salt-stiff and smelling of rosemary. It lists an item returned from the shore—“brass buoy key, teeth-marked”—and a date that aligns with the first week of Wren’s mother’s disappearance, stamped with Ashford & Daughters’ private annex seal.

Several headstones here have hairline seams, as if their names were peeled off and re-set like careful wallpaper; the lichen grows in tidy, unnatural borders around the altered letters. A buoy-bell’s moan drifts in on the mist at intervals that feel counted, not coastal.

Ward The Yard.location_description: Ward The Yard is the Lanternward Society’s busiest tier: a “public” stretch of path where lanterns are kept bright and jokes are kept gentle. Beneath the whimsy—tour placards with rhyming epitaphs, rosemary tied in tidy bows—there are quiet seams: gravel that crunches too evenly, headstones that sit a fraction too new, and a salt-sweet draft that seems to exhale from certain plots as if the earth is practicing speech.

watchers.name: Moth-Lantern Warden (Pip Sallow)
watchers.description: A lantern-lighter with ink-stained fingertips who pretends to fuss over sputtering wicks, watching reflections in the lantern glass to see who lingers by altered stones. They’re looking for anyone who reads names aloud or sketches plot maps from memory.

watchers.name: Buoy-Bell Listener (Sister Nacre)
watchers.description: A Brine-Choir tide-singer posing as a mourner, humming softly near the ironwork to ‘hear’ the bell buoy’s reply. She watches for anyone handling sea-glass charms or speaking of drownings, and listens for names that taste like salt on the air.

hidden_guards.name: The Lichen-Script Ward
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Threaded through the green lichen on three adjacent leaning slates near the rosemary offerings; the script only aligns when viewed from the lantern path’s third post.
weaknesses: Approach from the grass where sound is swallowed; the ward listens for crunching gravel
Use a soft brush and distilled water only—abrasion wakes it
Cover the stone briefly with a cloth to break lanternlight; the ward ‘reads’ illumination

hidden_guards.name: Gravel-Quiet Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Under the neatest stretch of gravel between the tour placard and the iron gate, coiled around a buried chain that tugs when footsteps hesitate.
weaknesses: Walk with steady, unhurried steps; it reacts to stuttered pacing and sudden stops
Scatter crushed rosemary—its attention drifts to the scent
Keep to the grass verge; it cannot travel where the ground won’t ‘answer’ with crunch

fail_conditions.name: Reading the Wrong Name Aloud
fail_conditions.description: Some names here were edited out of ledgers but not fully erased from the ground. Speaking one aloud invites the cemetery to ‘correct’ the record, and the correction is not gentle.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The lanterns gutter as if embarrassed, and the air thickens with rust-tang. Letters on nearby stones bead with sea-mist and begin to rearrange, making a new name that points accusingly toward the speaker. A watcher takes note, and the path seems to subtly reroute Wren back toward the public tour line.
escape_conditions: Apologize softly and offer rosemary at the base of the nearest slate
Switch to silent reading and keep hands visible
Step onto the grass where sound is swallowed and wait for the lanterns to steady

fail_conditions.name: Attempting to Lift a Recently ‘Settled’ Stone
fail_conditions.description: Several markers are decoys set over empty peat pockets; moving them triggers a quiet alarm through ironwork and buoy-bell resonance, drawing both civic and coastal attention.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The gravel hushes unnaturally, and a low moan answers from the distant buoy as if the sea has been informed. The iron fence vibrates with a fingernail-on-glass tremor, and a thin line of wet ink appears on Wren’s fingertips as though the cemetery has signed her name. Within minutes, a lantern-lighter ‘happens’ to arrive, and a tide-singer’s hymn drifts closer than it should.
escape_conditions: Release the stone immediately and smooth the gravel to erase tool marks
Blame a restoration inspection and produce legitimate tools/cloths to appear routine
Leave a sea-glass charm as a decoy offering and depart along the grass edge, not the main path

secrets.description: Behind a whimsical tour placard (painted with a smiling skull and a pun about ‘resting faces’), a second set of plot coordinates is etched into the iron bracket in tiny, precise numerals—too careful to be a prank. The coordinates match an unlisted row where the ground smells of crushed rosemary even when none is present.

One slate bears a lichen bloom shaped like a wren in flight; when viewed at an angle, the ‘bird’ aligns with a hairline seam in the stone. Pressing there doesn’t open anything—yet—but it makes the lantern nearest the path sputter in a pattern like Morse, spelling out a single word: ANNEX.

watchers.name: Sister Celandine-of-the-Tide
watchers.description: A cheerful tide-singer in a damp wool cloak who pretends to be lost and asks for directions with too-perfect politeness. She watches reflections more than faces—puddles, polished marble, lantern-glass—listening for the shape of a secret in someone’s pause.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternward Whisper-Lock beneath the Ing Guide rail
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Bolted under the iron guide-rail where visitors lean to read the map; it’s disguised as a decorative bracket shaped like a curled fern.
weaknesses: Keep hands off the rail while speaking sensitive words
Speak only in questions (it listens for declarative intent)
Wrap the bracket in rosemary or salt-damp cloth to mute its resonance briefly

fail_conditions.name: Reading the Ing Guide placard aloud in full
fail_conditions.description: The placard is inked with a subtle call-and-response cadence; reciting it activates a buoy-bell mimic that flags the speaker as a compliant tour-goer—and a useful target for rerouting or recruitment.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The lanterns along the path sputter in sequence, as if applauding, and the air grows politely attentive. Within minutes, a Lanternward guide arrives with impeccable timing to “assist,” gently steering the conversation away from names that matter and noting Wren’s interest for the ledgers.
escape_conditions: Interrupt the recitation with a cough and change the wording mid-line
Step off the gravel onto grass to break the cadence
Ask for a different map copy instead of continuing

fail_conditions.name: Mentioning Wren’s mother by name within arm’s reach of the guide-rail
fail_conditions.description: The ironwork is tuned to carry certain names like a wire carries a storm; the Whisper-Lock treats them as keys and sends a quiet alert through the cemetery’s lantern network.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A thin, bell-buoy moan threads through the mist, and the nearest lanterns dim as though listening harder. A Brine-Choir “volunteer” arrives with a sympathetic hymn and an offer of help that feels like a hook; shortly after, a Lanternward caretaker begins hovering near the relevant tiers, ready to intercept any search.
escape_conditions: Move away from ironwork and speak into open air (no metal nearby)
Use a nickname or omit the name entirely
Create a harmless distraction (drop tools, ask about tour times) to muddy the alert’s focus

secrets.description: Behind the Ing Guide placard, a second layer of paper has been pasted over the original map. If peeled back carefully, the older print shows a now-“nonexistent” section labeled in tiny type as the Siltward Tier, with three plots marked by faint sea-glass green circles—one bearing an Ashford initial that does not match any public ledger.

A hollow in the stone base of the guide-post hides a curled strip of funeral-home receipt paper, salt-stiff and smelling of rosemary. It lists an item returned from the shore—“brass buoy key, teeth-marked”—and a date that aligns with the first week of Wren’s mother’s disappearance, stamped with Ashford & Daughters’ private annex seal.

Gether.location_description: Beneath Saltmarrow’s lantern-path, the gravel is newer than it pretends—freshly scattered to hide a narrow drag-mark that leads toward the oldest tier. Several headstones here have hairline seams, as if their names were peeled off and re-set like careful wallpaper; the lichen grows in tidy, unnatural borders around the altered letters. A buoy-bell’s moan drifts in on the mist at intervals that feel counted, not coastal.

watchers.name: Moth-Count Lysa (Lanternward Lamp-Tender)
watchers.description: She appears to be trimming wicks and shooing moths from lantern glass, but she is actually counting footfalls and listening for names said aloud—especially Ashford and any ‘missing’ ones. She watches reflections more than faces, using the lantern panes to track where Wren’s gaze lingers.

watchers.name: Brother Sedge of the Brine-Choir
watchers.description: He stands near a sailor’s stone as if praying, humming under his breath to ‘steady the dead,’ while his fingers tap a rhythm that matches the buoy-bell out at sea. He’s listening for mentions of bargains, bells, or drowned bodies, and watching for anyone who pockets sea-glass charms or touches offerings.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternward “Wick-Warden” Sconce (a disguised ward-lantern)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Third lantern on the left past the rosemary offerings, its ironwork is braided like a crown; a thin chalk-salt sigil is scratched under the mounting bracket.
weaknesses: Do not touch the mounting bracket or disturb the chalk-salt sigil
Approach with hands visible and speak only of ‘maintenance’ or ‘cleaning’
A pinch of rosemary rubbed on the fingertips dulls the lantern’s notice for a few minutes

fail_conditions.name: Disturbing an edited headstone seam
fail_conditions.description: Some stones have been re-faced; the seams are baited with a quiet ward that treats curiosity like vandalism. It’s meant to summon Lanternward attention fast and make the guilty feel clumsy enough to leave fingerprints.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air turns suddenly metallic-sweet, and the nearest lantern flares with moth-shadow shapes that spiral toward the offender’s hands. A thin soot-mark blooms on the fingers like a glove, impossible to hide in lanternlight, while a distant bell answers as if acknowledging a report.
escape_conditions: Stop immediately and place both palms flat on your own coat to avoid leaving marks on stone
Rub fingers with crushed rosemary offerings to break the soot-glove’s contrast
Move into thicker grass where sound is swallowed and wait for the lantern flare to settle

fail_conditions.name: Speaking a concealed name at the wrong plot
fail_conditions.description: Certain plots are tuned to ‘missing’ names; saying one aloud is like knocking on a locked door that still remembers how to open. The Brine-Choir and Lanternward both use this to locate nosy tongues.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The mist tightens, and the buoy-bell’s moan shifts into a nearer, more personal note—like someone humming directly behind your ear. A cold wetness beads on your lips as if you’ve swallowed sea-air, and for a moment the carved letters on nearby stones rearrange themselves into listening mouths.
escape_conditions: Immediately switch to a harmless cover topic (tour routes, lantern oil, restoration methods) and physically step off the plot’s border stones
Hum a steady, simple tune to ‘overwrite’ the listening cadence until the bell pattern breaks
Place a small sea-glass charm on an offering spot as a decoy ‘payment’ and leave without looking back

secrets.description: Under a rosemary offering jar, a flat slate chip has been wedged like a shim; on its underside is a tiny penciled map of the cemetery tiers with one plot circled and annotated: ‘ANNEX ENTRY—NOT IN LEDGER.’ The handwriting resembles a funeral-home clerk’s neat hand, but the last stroke trembles as if written in a hurry.

A ‘restored’ marble angel has a hairline crack filled with pale salt-resin; pressed into the filler is a single dark hair and a pinprick of blue-green sea-glass dust. The resin smells faintly of the Mourning House’s embalming soap—suggesting the statue was repaired there, not on-site, and recently.

Ing Boots.location_description: Ing Boots is a narrow, soot-sweet cobbler’s shop tucked between fogged storefronts, where boot trees stand like polite wooden skeletons in the window. The public floor smells of beeswax and salt-damp leather; behind the counter, a curtained workroom hides a ledger niche and a bell-pull that doesn’t ring here so much as “answers” elsewhere. The shop’s floorboards are subtly numbered in chalk under the rugs—an old tour-route code used by caretakers who prefer errands that don’t become questions.

watchers.name: Orin Pike (the 'measuring lad')
watchers.description: A quiet assistant who offers to size feet and fetch laces, but mostly watches hands: which pockets they reach for, which names make their voice hitch. He listens for mentions of plots, edits, and buoy-bells, then steps out to 'take out scraps' when he has something worth passing along.

watchers.name: Sister Muir-in-Mittens
watchers.description: A Brine-Choir singer disguised as a customer with damp hems and too-bright eyes, pretending to fuss over waterproofing. She watches for grief-softened faces and anyone asking after old boots, sailors, or missing women, then hums a low note into the shop’s speaking-tube as if clearing her throat.

hidden_guards.name: The Wax-Lace Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Coiled inside a tin of boot-wax beneath the counter; it unspools into a thin, glossy cord that can knot around wrists or ankles.
weaknesses: Offer a coin or button as 'payment' before touching anything under the counter
A drop of saltwater or brine makes the wax slacken and lose its grip
Heat from a lantern held close softens it into harmless shine

fail_conditions.name: Pulling the wrong bell-pull
fail_conditions.description: The bell-pull behind the curtain is not for the shop; it is a signal line that routes through old coastal wiring and answers to the Brine-Choir’s buoy network. Touching it with the wrong intent marks you as a caller, and callers are expected to pay in secrets.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A distant buoy-bell moans in reply, and the shop’s air briefly tastes like low tide. Within minutes, a 'customer' arrives who knows one private detail they shouldn’t, and presses for another—politely, firmly, as if completing a transaction. Refusing escalates into quiet coercion: lost items, misdirected records, and footsteps that always seem to follow.
escape_conditions: Immediately apologize aloud and state a mundane reason ("I thought it was for the back room") while offering a small charm or coin as a 'misdial fee'
Cut the connection by tying the pull-cord into a simple sailor’s knot and sprinkling it with salt
Leave the premises and avoid mentioning buoy-bells for the rest of the day

fail_conditions.name: Asking for the 'Ing' pair by name
fail_conditions.description: There is a code phrase used by Lanternward couriers to request altered-tour supplies and ledger paste. Saying it in the open flags you as either a courier—or a spy—and the shop’s watchers respond accordingly.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: Orin’s friendliness goes lacquer-still, and he excuses himself to the back with your size written too neatly on a slip. The next time you visit the cemetery, a lantern-lighter happens to be in every aisle you choose, and someone has already checked out the ledger you came for. The town remains polite, but doors begin to close a beat early.
escape_conditions: Immediately pivot to a harmless explanation ("I meant the brand stamp") and buy something small
Ask a sincere, mundane cobbler question to reframe the conversation
Leave before Orin returns and vary your route home

secrets.description: Under the second rug by the boot trees, faint chalk numerals match a Lanternward tour-route code; one number is overwritten with a newer hand, pointing to a cemetery tier that no longer appears on public maps.

A thin strip of leather tucked into the seam of a display boot contains a pressed sea-glass sliver and a funeral-home inventory tag stamped 'A&D Annex—Return Unlogged.' The handwriting on the tag matches the style used in old Ashford ledgers from the year Wren’s mother vanished.

Ward The Yard.location_description: Ward The Yard is the Lanternward Society’s busiest tier: a “public” stretch of path where lanterns are kept bright and jokes are kept gentle. Beneath the whimsy—tour placards with rhyming epitaphs, rosemary tied in tidy bows—there are quiet seams: gravel that crunches too evenly, headstones that sit a fraction too new, and a salt-sweet draft that seems to exhale from certain plots as if the earth is practicing speech.

watchers.name: Moth-Lantern Warden (Pip Sallow)
watchers.description: A lantern-lighter with ink-stained fingertips who pretends to fuss over sputtering wicks, watching reflections in the lantern glass to see who lingers by altered stones. They’re looking for anyone who reads names aloud or sketches plot maps from memory.

watchers.name: Buoy-Bell Listener (Sister Nacre)
watchers.description: A Brine-Choir tide-singer posing as a mourner, humming softly near the ironwork to ‘hear’ the bell buoy’s reply. She watches for anyone handling sea-glass charms or speaking of drownings, and listens for names that taste like salt on the air.

hidden_guards.name: The Lichen-Script Ward
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Threaded through the green lichen on three adjacent leaning slates near the rosemary offerings; the script only aligns when viewed from the lantern path’s third post.
weaknesses: Approach from the grass where sound is swallowed; the ward listens for crunching gravel
Use a soft brush and distilled water only—abrasion wakes it
Cover the stone briefly with a cloth to break lanternlight; the ward ‘reads’ illumination

hidden_guards.name: Gravel-Quiet Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Under the neatest stretch of gravel between the tour placard and the iron gate, coiled around a buried chain that tugs when footsteps hesitate.
weaknesses: Walk with steady, unhurried steps; it reacts to stuttered pacing and sudden stops
Scatter crushed rosemary—its attention drifts to the scent
Keep to the grass verge; it cannot travel where the ground won’t ‘answer’ with crunch

fail_conditions.name: Reading the Wrong Name Aloud
fail_conditions.description: Some names here were edited out of ledgers but not fully erased from the ground. Speaking one aloud invites the cemetery to ‘correct’ the record, and the correction is not gentle.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The lanterns gutter as if embarrassed, and the air thickens with rust-tang. Letters on nearby stones bead with sea-mist and begin to rearrange, making a new name that points accusingly toward the speaker. A watcher takes note, and the path seems to subtly reroute Wren back toward the public tour line.
escape_conditions: Apologize softly and offer rosemary at the base of the nearest slate
Switch to silent reading and keep hands visible
Step onto the grass where sound is swallowed and wait for the lanterns to steady

fail_conditions.name: Attempting to Lift a Recently ‘Settled’ Stone
fail_conditions.description: Several markers are decoys set over empty peat pockets; moving them triggers a quiet alarm through ironwork and buoy-bell resonance, drawing both civic and coastal attention.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The gravel hushes unnaturally, and a low moan answers from the distant buoy as if the sea has been informed. The iron fence vibrates with a fingernail-on-glass tremor, and a thin line of wet ink appears on Wren’s fingertips as though the cemetery has signed her name. Within minutes, a lantern-lighter ‘happens’ to arrive, and a tide-singer’s hymn drifts closer than it should.
escape_conditions: Release the stone immediately and smooth the gravel to erase tool marks
Blame a restoration inspection and produce legitimate tools/cloths to appear routine
Leave a sea-glass charm as a decoy offering and depart along the grass edge, not the main path

secrets.description: Behind a whimsical tour placard (painted with a smiling skull and a pun about ‘resting faces’), a second set of plot coordinates is etched into the iron bracket in tiny, precise numerals—too careful to be a prank. The coordinates match an unlisted row where the ground smells of crushed rosemary even when none is present.

One slate bears a lichen bloom shaped like a wren in flight; when viewed at an angle, the ‘bird’ aligns with a hairline seam in the stone. Pressing there doesn’t open anything—yet—but it makes the lantern nearest the path sputter in a pattern like Morse, spelling out a single word: ANNEX.

Door Seam.location_description: At the door seam—where chapel oak meets salt-swollen frame—the paint has split into a hairline smile. The gap tastes faintly of brine and old varnish, and a thin thread of sea-mist keeps trying to slip indoors as if it has an appointment.

watchers.name: Lampwick Lenore
watchers.description: A lantern-lighter who pretends to fuss with a sputtering wick nearby, watching reflections in the glass rather than looking directly. She’s listening for names spoken too carefully and for anyone who lingers at the seam as if expecting it to answer back.

hidden_guards.name: The Seam-Moth Ward
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Nested in the door jamb’s hollow, disguised as a peppering of moth-wing shadows where the lanternlight stutters.
weaknesses: Approach with steady, quiet breath; sudden exhalations stir it
Offer a pinch of crushed rosemary at the threshold to lull it
Use a soft brush and speak politely (it responds to gentleness and slows)

fail_conditions.name: Forcing the seam
fail_conditions.description: The wood is salt-swollen and warded; brute pressure makes the jamb complain in a voice that carries. The cemetery’s quiet is not empty—it repeats what it hears to the wrong listeners.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The seam shivers and releases a papery flutter as the ward wakes, and the lantern nearby flares bright as an accusation. A watcher takes note, and the door’s gap tightens as if offended, making further entry harder and noisier.
escape_conditions: Stop immediately and switch to careful restoration tools
Soothe the threshold with rosemary or a sea-glass charm placed flat to the seam
Redirect attention by engaging the lantern-lighter with harmless tour talk

fail_conditions.name: Speaking the wrong name at the threshold
fail_conditions.description: Names have weight here; the seam is a listening line between sanctioned history and what was edited out. Certain names act like a bell-buoy—summoning interest from factions that prefer silence.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air turns careful-er, and the lantern’s moth-shadows arrange themselves into a brief, unmistakable sigil before dissolving. Within the hour, someone will come to "assist"—politely—by removing access, changing schedules, or escorting Wren away from the door under the pretense of safety.
escape_conditions: Mask the conversation with mundane cemetery maintenance terms
Use coded euphemisms (e.g., 'the extra book', 'the wet choir')
Leave the seam and relocate to a noisier path where words don’t carry

secrets.description: A thin strip of paper has been tucked into the seam and varnished over—an index-tab torn from a funeral ledger, stamped with a tiny lantern icon and a handwritten tide-time that doesn’t match any local chart.

Under the lowest hinge, a rust-bloom forms a deliberate shape: a small brine-bell motif scratched into the metal, with three pinprick holes nearby that can whistle when the wind hits—an improvised signal point for meetings.

Jory’s For A Second.location_description: Jory’s For A Second looks like a cheerful secondhand shop wedged between salt-stained brick, but its back room is a hush-pocket where sound dulls as if wrapped in velvet. The air tastes faintly of clove, lamp oil, and sea-rust; mirrors hang where they shouldn’t, reflecting angles the room doesn’t have. A buoy-bell chime sometimes arrives from nowhere, and the shop’s little clock occasionally ticks backward for one breath, as if reconsidering.

watchers.name: Mira Quell (the ‘button lady’)
watchers.description: She pretends to sort jars of mismatched buttons near the counter while tracking who asks after names, plots, or old records. She listens for grief spoken too neatly and watches hands for cemetery calluses and ink-stains from ledgers.

watchers.name: Brother Sedge (tide-singer in plain clothes)
watchers.description: He lingers by the cracked mirror stand, humming under his breath to ‘hear’ what the glass repeats. He’s looking for anyone chasing drowned secrets—especially mentions of buoy-bells, coastal bargains, or a woman who didn’t stay gone properly.

hidden_guards.name: The Receipt-Wasp Ward
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Inside the brass receipt-printer under the counter; the paper roll is a coiled nest of thin, ink-scented wings.
weaknesses: Pay properly (even a token coin) before handling protected items
Offer a written apology on any scrap of paper and leave it under the printer
Dampen the receipt roll with a single drop of saltwater to lull the ward

hidden_guards.name: The Umbrella Stand Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: A tall umbrella stand by the door packed with canes and parasols; one is not wood but jointed bone lacquered black.
weaknesses: Approach openly and ask permission to browse ‘weathered goods’ (polite phrasing disarms it)
Keep both hands visible; it reacts to concealed tools
A sprig of rosemary placed at its base makes it go still for a few minutes

fail_conditions.name: Mentioning erased burials too plainly
fail_conditions.description: Jory’s walls are sympathetic; certain words make the shop ‘remember’ old edits and alert the people who did the editing. Speaking the right names here is like tapping a lantern-glass in a dark stairwell.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A thin draft slides through the shop, snuffing the warmest lamp and making the mirrors briefly show a lantern-lit cemetery path instead of the room. Within the hour, a Lanternward ‘tour volunteer’ arrives to browse too closely and to note faces, questions, and exits.
escape_conditions: Shift the topic into harmless genealogy or ‘local history’ tour chatter
Leave immediately and take two unnecessary turns before heading anywhere important
Buy a small item and request it wrapped—paperwork noise breaks the shop’s ‘listening’

fail_conditions.name: Asking for the back-room ledger without the right courtesy
fail_conditions.description: The shop’s threshold etiquette is a real boundary; skipping it is treated as trespass by older, stranger rules. The whimsical veneer turns sharp when manners are neglected.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The door-curtain to the back room stiffens like wet sailcloth turned to ice, and the Umbrella Stand Sentinel clacks forward on borrowed joints. At the same time, a buoy-bell note rings from the wrong direction, as if someone has been signaled. The shop becomes a trap of polite silence: no one shouts, but no one lets you go easily.
escape_conditions: Apologize aloud using the phrase ‘for a second’ and step back from the curtain
Offer a small trade (sea-glass, a charm, or a personal trinket) as ‘proper asking’
Exit with empty hands and do not look into any mirror until outside

secrets.description: Behind a framed advertisement for ‘Lantern Oil & Comforts’ is a thin slit in the wall holding a folded, salt-crisp receipt dated the week Wren’s mother vanished. The item line reads only: “ONE SECOND, KEPT.” and the signature is a looping hand that matches Ashford & Daughters intake forms.

The cracked mirror stand is backed with a hidden ribbon of paper—an index strip torn from a cemetery plot book—listing three names that have been overwritten with lantern-soot. If held near a flame, the soot thins and reveals the original ink: one is a coastal alias tied to the Brine-Choir’s bell-signals.

inventory: Folded strip of thin clean linen

Ing Lanterns.location_description: Ing Lanterns are older than the path they pretend to illuminate—each glass is faintly salted from the inside, as if it has wept sea-mist for years. The lanternposts bear tiny, polite chisel-marks (a caretakers’ shorthand) that map which graves are meant to be remembered and which are meant to be merely visited. When the wind turns, the flames lean as if listening, and the shadows they cast occasionally resemble moths with too many wings.

watchers.name: Moth-Counter Hest Finch
watchers.description: Pretends to be tallying moths drawn to the lanterns for a 'Lanternward census,' but is actually watching for anyone lingering at posts with altered chisel-marks. She listens for names spoken twice and notes which tools are carried in pockets.

watchers.name: Brother Sedge of the Brine-Choir
watchers.description: Sits on a low stone like a patient hymn, humming softly to 'steady the flame.' He’s watching for anyone who reacts to buoy-bell calls or mentions drowned names; he reads faces the way sailors read weather.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternwick Warden (a chained flame-sprite)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Inside the third lantern on the left after the rosemary offering-stone, its base etched with a Lanternward seal that looks like a keyhole wearing a halo.
weaknesses: Do not touch the latch; instead, speak a caretaker’s courtesy (a simple apology) and step back
Cover the lantern briefly with a dark cloth to calm the sprite without opening it
Scatter a pinch of salt in a small circle at your feet to keep it from leaping out

fail_conditions.name: Touching the chisel-marks on the lanternpost
fail_conditions.description: The marks are a quiet alarm: skin-oil completes the etched circuit and tells the Lanternward exactly who handled it, even in fog. It’s designed to catch 'helpful' restorers who notice inconsistencies.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The nearest lantern flame flares an attentive blue and throws your shadow long enough to be recognizable. Within minutes, an overly friendly tour-guide drifts close, asking questions that are shaped like compliments but bite like hooks.
escape_conditions: Wipe the post with a rosemary cloth as if performing routine maintenance to smear the signal
Move immediately into the grass-hush where sound is swallowed and line of sight breaks
Redirect attention by asking about a public tour route and walking with purpose

fail_conditions.name: Speaking a drowned name aloud beneath Ing Lanterns
fail_conditions.description: The Brine-Choir uses lantern acoustics as a listening shell; certain names make the glass resonate and carry farther than they should. In mist, the sound can be 'answered' by a buoy-bell that isn’t anywhere nearby.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A bell-note arrives through the fog like a cold fingertip pressed to the ear, and the lanterns sputter in unison as if taking a breath. Someone begins following at a courteous distance—close enough to be sure, far enough to deny it—until you are guided toward the shoreward gate without realizing you’ve turned.
escape_conditions: Switch to writing the name instead of speaking and keep your voice to mundane topics
Step into a cluster of lanterns and hum a steady counter-note to break the resonance
Seek a Lanternward tour group as cover; the Choir avoids open confrontation under civic eyes

secrets.description: One lantern’s glass is etched with a microscopic map of cemetery tiers—only visible when the flame leans sideways—marking a single plot number that does not exist in the public ledger. The number is paired with a tiny symbol used in Ashford & Daughters internal records: a sea-glass charm shape, the kind Wren collects.

Beneath the rosemary offering-stone is a flat, sealed tin meant to look like a maintenance cap. Inside are three moth wings pressed into paper and a sliver of ledger-page with a name carefully scraped away—except for the last two letters, still clinging like a stubborn smile.

Ing Guide.location_description: Ing Guide is a narrow, lantern-sputtering lane-map kiosk and tour placard tucked between two leaning angel statues, where the Lanternward posts “helpful” directions that subtly reroute visitors away from edited plots. Salt mist has glued a film of mica to the signage so it sparkles when breathed on, and the iron guide-rail hums faintly with buoy-bell resonance if you rest a hand on it too long.

Speak only in questions (it listens for declarative intent)
Wrap the bracket in rosemary or salt-damp cloth to mute its resonance briefly

Step off the gravel onto grass to break the cadence
Ask for a different map copy instead of continuing
