watchers.description: He stands near a sailor’s stone as if praying, humming under his breath to ‘steady the dead,’ while his fingers tap a rhythm that matches the buoy-bell out at sea. He’s listening for mentions of bargains, bells, or drowned bodies, and watching for anyone who pockets sea-glass charms or touches offerings.

hidden_guards.name: Lanternward “Wick-Warden” Sconce (a disguised ward-lantern)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Third lantern on the left past the rosemary offerings, its ironwork is braided like a crown; a thin chalk-salt sigil is scratched under the mounting bracket.
weaknesses: Do not touch the mounting bracket or disturb the chalk-salt sigil
Approach with hands visible and speak only of ‘maintenance’ or ‘cleaning’
A pinch of rosemary rubbed on the fingertips dulls the lantern’s notice for a few minutes

fail_conditions.name: Disturbing an edited headstone seam
fail_conditions.description: Some stones have been re-faced; the seams are baited with a quiet ward that treats curiosity like vandalism. It’s meant to summon Lanternward attention fast and make the guilty feel clumsy enough to leave fingerprints.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air turns suddenly metallic-sweet, and the nearest lantern flares with moth-shadow shapes that spiral toward the offender’s hands. A thin soot-mark blooms on the fingers like a glove, impossible to hide in lanternlight, while a distant bell answers as if acknowledging a report.
escape_conditions: Stop immediately and place both palms flat on your own coat to avoid leaving marks on stone
Rub fingers with crushed rosemary offerings to break the soot-glove’s contrast
Move into thicker grass where sound is swallowed and wait for the lantern flare to settle

fail_conditions.name: Speaking a concealed name at the wrong plot
fail_conditions.description: Certain plots are tuned to ‘missing’ names; saying one aloud is like knocking on a locked door that still remembers how to open. The Brine-Choir and Lanternward both use this to locate nosy tongues.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The mist tightens, and the buoy-bell’s moan shifts into a nearer, more personal note—like someone humming directly behind your ear. A cold wetness beads on your lips as if you’ve swallowed sea-air, and for a moment the carved letters on nearby stones rearrange themselves into listening mouths.
escape_conditions: Immediately switch to a harmless cover topic (tour routes, lantern oil, restoration methods) and physically step off the plot’s border stones
Hum a steady, simple tune to ‘overwrite’ the listening cadence until the bell pattern breaks
Place a small sea-glass charm on an offering spot as a decoy ‘payment’ and leave without looking back

secrets.description: Under a rosemary offering jar, a flat slate chip has been wedged like a shim; on its underside is a tiny penciled map of the cemetery tiers with one plot circled and annotated: ‘ANNEX ENTRY—NOT IN LEDGER.’ The handwriting resembles a funeral-home clerk’s neat hand, but the last stroke trembles as if written in a hurry.

A ‘restored’ marble angel has a hairline crack filled with pale salt-resin; pressed into the filler is a single dark hair and a pinprick of blue-green sea-glass dust. The resin smells faintly of the Mourning House’s embalming soap—suggesting the statue was repaired there, not on-site, and recently.

Ing Boots.location_description: Ing Boots is a narrow, soot-sweet cobbler’s shop tucked between fogged storefronts, where boot trees stand like polite wooden skeletons in the window. The public floor smells of beeswax and salt-damp leather; behind the counter, a curtained workroom hides a ledger niche and a bell-pull that doesn’t ring here so much as “answers” elsewhere. The shop’s floorboards are subtly numbered in chalk under the rugs—an old tour-route code used by caretakers who prefer errands that don’t become questions.

watchers.name: Orin Pike (the 'measuring lad')
watchers.description: A quiet assistant who offers to size feet and fetch laces, but mostly watches hands: which pockets they reach for, which names make their voice hitch. He listens for mentions of plots, edits, and buoy-bells, then steps out to 'take out scraps' when he has something worth passing along.

watchers.name: Sister Muir-in-Mittens
watchers.description: A Brine-Choir singer disguised as a customer with damp hems and too-bright eyes, pretending to fuss over waterproofing. She watches for grief-softened faces and anyone asking after old boots, sailors, or missing women, then hums a low note into the shop’s speaking-tube as if clearing her throat.

hidden_guards.name: The Wax-Lace Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Coiled inside a tin of boot-wax beneath the counter; it unspools into a thin, glossy cord that can knot around wrists or ankles.
weaknesses: Offer a coin or button as 'payment' before touching anything under the counter
A drop of saltwater or brine makes the wax slacken and lose its grip
Heat from a lantern held close softens it into harmless shine

fail_conditions.name: Pulling the wrong bell-pull
fail_conditions.description: The bell-pull behind the curtain is not for the shop; it is a signal line that routes through old coastal wiring and answers to the Brine-Choir’s buoy network. Touching it with the wrong intent marks you as a caller, and callers are expected to pay in secrets.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A distant buoy-bell moans in reply, and the shop’s air briefly tastes like low tide. Within minutes, a 'customer' arrives who knows one private detail they shouldn’t, and presses for another—politely, firmly, as if completing a transaction. Refusing escalates into quiet coercion: lost items, misdirected records, and footsteps that always seem to follow.
escape_conditions: Immediately apologize aloud and state a mundane reason ("I thought it was for the back room") while offering a small charm or coin as a 'misdial fee'
Cut the connection by tying the pull-cord into a simple sailor’s knot and sprinkling it with salt
Leave the premises and avoid mentioning buoy-bells for the rest of the day

fail_conditions.name: Asking for the 'Ing' pair by name
fail_conditions.description: There is a code phrase used by Lanternward couriers to request altered-tour supplies and ledger paste. Saying it in the open flags you as either a courier—or a spy—and the shop’s watchers respond accordingly.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: Orin’s friendliness goes lacquer-still, and he excuses himself to the back with your size written too neatly on a slip. The next time you visit the cemetery, a lantern-lighter happens to be in every aisle you choose, and someone has already checked out the ledger you came for. The town remains polite, but doors begin to close a beat early.
escape_conditions: Immediately pivot to a harmless explanation ("I meant the brand stamp") and buy something small
Ask a sincere, mundane cobbler question to reframe the conversation
Leave before Orin returns and vary your route home

secrets.description: Under the second rug by the boot trees, faint chalk numerals match a Lanternward tour-route code; one number is overwritten with a newer hand, pointing to a cemetery tier that no longer appears on public maps.

A thin strip of leather tucked into the seam of a display boot contains a pressed sea-glass sliver and a funeral-home inventory tag stamped 'A&D Annex—Return Unlogged.' The handwriting on the tag matches the style used in old Ashford ledgers from the year Wren’s mother vanished.

Ward The Yard.location_description: Ward The Yard is the Lanternward Society’s busiest tier: a “public” stretch of path where lanterns are kept bright and jokes are kept gentle. Beneath the whimsy—tour placards with rhyming epitaphs, rosemary tied in tidy bows—there are quiet seams: gravel that crunches too evenly, headstones that sit a fraction too new, and a salt-sweet draft that seems to exhale from certain plots as if the earth is practicing speech.

watchers.name: Moth-Lantern Warden (Pip Sallow)
watchers.description: A lantern-lighter with ink-stained fingertips who pretends to fuss over sputtering wicks, watching reflections in the lantern glass to see who lingers by altered stones. They’re looking for anyone who reads names aloud or sketches plot maps from memory.

watchers.name: Buoy-Bell Listener (Sister Nacre)
watchers.description: A Brine-Choir tide-singer posing as a mourner, humming softly near the ironwork to ‘hear’ the bell buoy’s reply. She watches for anyone handling sea-glass charms or speaking of drownings, and listens for names that taste like salt on the air.

hidden_guards.name: The Lichen-Script Ward
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Threaded through the green lichen on three adjacent leaning slates near the rosemary offerings; the script only aligns when viewed from the lantern path’s third post.
weaknesses: Approach from the grass where sound is swallowed; the ward listens for crunching gravel
Use a soft brush and distilled water only—abrasion wakes it
Cover the stone briefly with a cloth to break lanternlight; the ward ‘reads’ illumination

hidden_guards.name: Gravel-Quiet Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Under the neatest stretch of gravel between the tour placard and the iron gate, coiled around a buried chain that tugs when footsteps hesitate.
weaknesses: Walk with steady, unhurried steps; it reacts to stuttered pacing and sudden stops
Scatter crushed rosemary—its attention drifts to the scent
Keep to the grass verge; it cannot travel where the ground won’t ‘answer’ with crunch

fail_conditions.name: Reading the Wrong Name Aloud
fail_conditions.description: Some names here were edited out of ledgers but not fully erased from the ground. Speaking one aloud invites the cemetery to ‘correct’ the record, and the correction is not gentle.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The lanterns gutter as if embarrassed, and the air thickens with rust-tang. Letters on nearby stones bead with sea-mist and begin to rearrange, making a new name that points accusingly toward the speaker. A watcher takes note, and the path seems to subtly reroute Wren back toward the public tour line.
escape_conditions: Apologize softly and offer rosemary at the base of the nearest slate
Switch to silent reading and keep hands visible
Step onto the grass where sound is swallowed and wait for the lanterns to steady

fail_conditions.name: Attempting to Lift a Recently ‘Settled’ Stone
fail_conditions.description: Several markers are decoys set over empty peat pockets; moving them triggers a quiet alarm through ironwork and buoy-bell resonance, drawing both civic and coastal attention.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The gravel hushes unnaturally, and a low moan answers from the distant buoy as if the sea has been informed. The iron fence vibrates with a fingernail-on-glass tremor, and a thin line of wet ink appears on Wren’s fingertips as though the cemetery has signed her name. Within minutes, a lantern-lighter ‘happens’ to arrive, and a tide-singer’s hymn drifts closer than it should.
escape_conditions: Release the stone immediately and smooth the gravel to erase tool marks
Blame a restoration inspection and produce legitimate tools/cloths to appear routine
Leave a sea-glass charm as a decoy offering and depart along the grass edge, not the main path

secrets.description: Behind a whimsical tour placard (painted with a smiling skull and a pun about ‘resting faces’), a second set of plot coordinates is etched into the iron bracket in tiny, precise numerals—too careful to be a prank. The coordinates match an unlisted row where the ground smells of crushed rosemary even when none is present.

One slate bears a lichen bloom shaped like a wren in flight; when viewed at an angle, the ‘bird’ aligns with a hairline seam in the stone. Pressing there doesn’t open anything—yet—but it makes the lantern nearest the path sputter in a pattern like Morse, spelling out a single word: ANNEX.

Door Seam.location_description: At the door seam—where chapel oak meets salt-swollen frame—the paint has split into a hairline smile. The gap tastes faintly of brine and old varnish, and a thin thread of sea-mist keeps trying to slip indoors as if it has an appointment.

watchers.name: Lampwick Lenore
watchers.description: A lantern-lighter who pretends to fuss with a sputtering wick nearby, watching reflections in the glass rather than looking directly. She’s listening for names spoken too carefully and for anyone who lingers at the seam as if expecting it to answer back.

hidden_guards.name: The Seam-Moth Ward
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Nested in the door jamb’s hollow, disguised as a peppering of moth-wing shadows where the lanternlight stutters.
weaknesses: Approach with steady, quiet breath; sudden exhalations stir it
Offer a pinch of crushed rosemary at the threshold to lull it
Use a soft brush and speak politely (it responds to gentleness and slows)

fail_conditions.name: Forcing the seam
fail_conditions.description: The wood is salt-swollen and warded; brute pressure makes the jamb complain in a voice that carries. The cemetery’s quiet is not empty—it repeats what it hears to the wrong listeners.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The seam shivers and releases a papery flutter as the ward wakes, and the lantern nearby flares bright as an accusation. A watcher takes note, and the door’s gap tightens as if offended, making further entry harder and noisier.
escape_conditions: Stop immediately and switch to careful restoration tools
Soothe the threshold with rosemary or a sea-glass charm placed flat to the seam
Redirect attention by engaging the lantern-lighter with harmless tour talk

fail_conditions.name: Speaking the wrong name at the threshold
fail_conditions.description: Names have weight here; the seam is a listening line between sanctioned history and what was edited out. Certain names act like a bell-buoy—summoning interest from factions that prefer silence.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air turns careful-er, and the lantern’s moth-shadows arrange themselves into a brief, unmistakable sigil before dissolving. Within the hour, someone will come to "assist"—politely—by removing access, changing schedules, or escorting Wren away from the door under the pretense of safety.
escape_conditions: Mask the conversation with mundane cemetery maintenance terms
Use coded euphemisms (e.g., 'the extra book', 'the wet choir')
Leave the seam and relocate to a noisier path where words don’t carry

secrets.description: A thin strip of paper has been tucked into the seam and varnished over—an index-tab torn from a funeral ledger, stamped with a tiny lantern icon and a handwritten tide-time that doesn’t match any local chart.

Under the lowest hinge, a rust-bloom forms a deliberate shape: a small brine-bell motif scratched into the metal, with three pinprick holes nearby that can whistle when the wind hits—an improvised signal point for meetings.

Jory’s For A Second.location_description: Jory’s For A Second looks like a cheerful secondhand shop wedged between salt-stained brick, but its back room is a hush-pocket where sound dulls as if wrapped in velvet. The air tastes faintly of clove, lamp oil, and sea-rust; mirrors hang where they shouldn’t, reflecting angles the room doesn’t have. A buoy-bell chime sometimes arrives from nowhere, and the shop’s little clock occasionally ticks backward for one breath, as if reconsidering.

watchers.name: Mira Quell (the ‘button lady’)
watchers.description: She pretends to sort jars of mismatched buttons near the counter while tracking who asks after names, plots, or old records. She listens for grief spoken too neatly and watches hands for cemetery calluses and ink-stains from ledgers.

watchers.name: Brother Sedge (tide-singer in plain clothes)
watchers.description: He lingers by the cracked mirror stand, humming under his breath to ‘hear’ what the glass repeats. He’s looking for anyone chasing drowned secrets—especially mentions of buoy-bells, coastal bargains, or a woman who didn’t stay gone properly.

hidden_guards.name: The Receipt-Wasp Ward
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Inside the brass receipt-printer under the counter; the paper roll is a coiled nest of thin, ink-scented wings.
weaknesses: Pay properly (even a token coin) before handling protected items
Offer a written apology on any scrap of paper and leave it under the printer
Dampen the receipt roll with a single drop of saltwater to lull the ward

hidden_guards.name: The Umbrella Stand Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: A tall umbrella stand by the door packed with canes and parasols; one is not wood but jointed bone lacquered black.
weaknesses: Approach openly and ask permission to browse ‘weathered goods’ (polite phrasing disarms it)
Keep both hands visible; it reacts to concealed tools
A sprig of rosemary placed at its base makes it go still for a few minutes

fail_conditions.name: Mentioning erased burials too plainly
fail_conditions.description: Jory’s walls are sympathetic; certain words make the shop ‘remember’ old edits and alert the people who did the editing. Speaking the right names here is like tapping a lantern-glass in a dark stairwell.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A thin draft slides through the shop, snuffing the warmest lamp and making the mirrors briefly show a lantern-lit cemetery path instead of the room. Within the hour, a Lanternward ‘tour volunteer’ arrives to browse too closely and to note faces, questions, and exits.
escape_conditions: Shift the topic into harmless genealogy or ‘local history’ tour chatter
Leave immediately and take two unnecessary turns before heading anywhere important
Buy a small item and request it wrapped—paperwork noise breaks the shop’s ‘listening’

fail_conditions.name: Asking for the back-room ledger without the right courtesy
fail_conditions.description: The shop’s threshold etiquette is a real boundary; skipping it is treated as trespass by older, stranger rules. The whimsical veneer turns sharp when manners are neglected.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The door-curtain to the back room stiffens like wet sailcloth turned to ice, and the Umbrella Stand Sentinel clacks forward on borrowed joints. At the same time, a buoy-bell note rings from the wrong direction, as if someone has been signaled. The shop becomes a trap of polite silence: no one shouts, but no one lets you go easily.
escape_conditions: Apologize aloud using the phrase ‘for a second’ and step back from the curtain
Offer a small trade (sea-glass, a charm, or a personal trinket) as ‘proper asking’
Exit with empty hands and do not look into any mirror until outside

secrets.description: Behind a framed advertisement for ‘Lantern Oil & Comforts’ is a thin slit in the wall holding a folded, salt-crisp receipt dated the week Wren’s mother vanished. The item line reads only: “ONE SECOND, KEPT.” and the signature is a looping hand that matches Ashford & Daughters intake forms.

The cracked mirror stand is backed with a hidden ribbon of paper—an index strip torn from a cemetery plot book—listing three names that have been overwritten with lantern-soot. If held near a flame, the soot thins and reveals the original ink: one is a coastal alias tied to the Brine-Choir’s bell-signals.

Ed On The Seam I.location_description: Ed On The Seam I is a narrow, terraced seam between the upper and lower cemetery tiers where the gravel path turns into a stitched ribbon of grass and slate. The lantern here burns with a polite, intermittent cough, and the iron fence hums faintly in the salt wind as if remembering hymns. Someone has recently re-inked a few carved names with a too-fresh black that beads like wet eyes, and the rosemary offerings smell bruised, as though handled in a hurry.

watchers.name: Lanternward Ledger-Mender ("Mr. Quill")
watchers.description: A tour guide who never quite leads a tour—he lingers near the seam with a clipboard, pretending to count lantern wicks while listening for questions about missing names. He watches hands more than faces, looking for anyone carrying tools, charcoal rubbings, or old record pages.

watchers.name: Brine-Choir Bell-Listener
watchers.description: A harmless-seeming volunteer with a satchel of sea-glass charms who pauses whenever the buoy moans, as if taking the tide’s pulse. They watch for anyone speaking names into the wind or touching ironwork too deliberately, and they memorize which graves draw grief like moths to light.

hidden_guards.name: The Stitch-Lantern’s Moth-Sentinels
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Inside the sputtering lantern at the seam’s bend; the moth-wing shadows are not shadows at all but tiny, ink-dark moths nesting in the glass.
weaknesses: Approach with a covered light and speak softly; they settle if offered a pinch of crushed rosemary
Avoid sudden movement or metal-on-glass sounds
Step back into the grass where sound is swallowed and wait for the lantern to calm

fail_conditions.name: Rubbing or copying an edited headstone in plain view
fail_conditions.description: At the seam, the Lanternward’s edits are freshest and most guarded; making a rubbing here is treated like theft of civic history. The wind carries charcoal-scratch sounds farther than it should, and the lantern’s sputter draws eyes to any fussing hands.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A polite interruption becomes a practiced containment: the watcher asks for permits, then subtly blocks the path downhill with a tour group that wasn’t there a moment ago. If pressed, they escort Wren toward the Society’s office to “verify records,” buying time to warn others and to remove the stone’s fresh ink before she can compare it.
escape_conditions: Switch to a restoration pretext (cleaning lichen, checking mortar) and put materials away
Move into the sound-swallowing grass and wait until the watcher is drawn off by the buoy bell
Offer to volunteer for a tour in exchange for leaving immediately

fail_conditions.name: Speaking a vanished name into the ironwork
fail_conditions.description: The seam’s fence is a listening instrument in salt wind; certain names catch on it like burrs and ring down the line. The Brine-Choir uses buoy-bells to answer such rings, and they do not like uninvited invocations.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air tightens as if the cemetery holds its breath; the lantern flame leans toward the speaker, and the buoy moan answers too quickly, too close. A Brine-Choir listener appears with a gentle smile and an offer of “blessing,” but the questions that follow feel like hooks dressed as kindness, and refusal turns the path subtly wrong—steps leading back to the same stone again and again.
escape_conditions: Change the subject to a neutral grave blessing and physically step away from ironwork
Use Wren’s tools to create a small, mundane ritual (tidy offerings, straighten a marker) to ground the space
Follow the rosemary scent toward the upper tier until the buoy sound fades

secrets.description: Behind the seam’s lantern post, a thin brass plaque has been screwed over an older dedication. Salt has loosened one corner; beneath it is a tiny stamped sigil used by Ashford & Daughters to mark “unsanctioned transfers,” and a date that matches the week Wren’s mother vanished.

One slate marker nearby bears lichen arranged like accidental lace, but the pattern is too tidy: it hides a second set of initials cut shallowly into the stone—initials that do not match the name above. The shallow cuts are recent, as if someone re-remembered the dead and tried to tuck the truth back under green velvet.

inventory: Folded strip of thin clean linen
Rusted tin with a few bent nails
